content:
Posted: December 28, 2012
												Many have dissected, analyzed, and downright devoured Spec Ops: The Line. Many theories have been concocted regarding the game's complex and incredibly disturbing narrative. But only one thing is certain: The Line is the most mature, intelligent, and introspective video game ever created. I would go as far as to call it the first post-modern video game ever made.It is, thus far, the only video game in existence that manages to ask so many questions of the player in such unbelievably subtle and imperceptible ways. It may be the first video game that truly is about something. And not only is it the only video game that truly made me question my perception of reality, it's also the only video game that made me truly question the ending I chose. But did I actually choose at all?Well, whatever Spec Ops: The Line is, it's well worth the price of admittance. The gameplay can be lackluster, at times (it's still very much playable and enjoyable, though), but the profound and compelling story more than makes up for any of its faults.

												Honestly way better than I expected, it's not too often a game makes me feel like I'm a bad person. From the start it feels very generic which turned me off of it initially but once you delve more into the story it's pretty good. Gameplay wise it's a third person console port so there are the expected bugs with moving around and aiming but nothing that really got in my way aside from not being able to move my mouse much while scoped. Story wise it wasn't what I expected, I figured it'd be just a 3rd person call of duty game but there's a good story in there so don't count it out after the first 30 minutes of hearing your guy scream "RELOADING". The setting was another huge plus, I'm a sucker for post-apocalyptic environments and I felt this was a damn good one especially with the sandstorms. Though as per usual this game is pretty short with me finishing it in around 6 hours so while I would strongly recommend it I would suggest you don't pay the full price for it.  7.5/10 I don't feel like a hero.

content:
Posted: May 16, 2016
												There's probably nothing I can say about this game that hasn't been said already, but since I enjoyed (maybe not the right word) it so much, I'll say it anyway.Spoiler Free-Spec Ops: The Line is more of an experience than a game.  It's something that all gamers, particularly fans of the shooter genre, should pick up at least once.  If you haven't played already, quit reading reviews (it's better to go in blind) and pick it up, on sale if you need more persuasion.  The gameplay may not be great, and downright infuriating at times, but there's a reason for that, too.  Keep that in the back of your mind as you play.  Pay close attention to what's going on around you, how the people act, what they say.  Keep an open mind, and be ready for♥♥♥♥♥♥to go sideways.Spoilers-Wow.  Yager did a fantastic job of creating a game that challenges the norms of the genre, and speaks volumes for video games as an art form.  The gameplay may be frustrating, but it only serves to emphasize the fact that while everything tells you that you/Walker should stop playing/fighting, you continue to push on.  Losing your sanity, the difficulty ramps up, anger builds, the game openly professes its hate for you, and it's not even fun to play - but you keep going.  Why?  What does that say about you?  Is simply reaching the end worth what you'll have to do to get there?  The line between player and character is blurry.  You can justify your actions by saying that it's the only way to move forward, that the game is forcing you to do it, but you - and Walker - always had the choice to turn away, to leave Dubai, to put down the game.  But you keep going.  Notice how some of the transitions fade to black, while others fade to white?  Notice how often you begin a new segment of the game by falling, rappelling, descending?  Even though you were just underground, you're now above it just so you can descend another thousand feet into insanity?  "Welcome to hell, Walker."  My hat's off to you, Yager.

number of helpful: 10 of 11 people (91%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 22
												Wanna know a good argument for games being art? This is one of the pieces you should use.Spec Ops: The Line is like watching the Challenger  explode: It's horrible, people are dying, but you can't look away because you're too awe-stricken to move. Spec Ops has one of the rawest portrayals of war in videogames, and it knows it. Spec Ops is full of symbollism, anti-war sentiments, and morally ambiguous choices that you'll wrack your brain over. The game doesn't shy away from occasional fourth-wall breakage to make fun of modern war games like Call of Duty either, and I can appreciate a game that treats its audience with respect. Multiple endings and consequences for your actions make you want to play through multiple times, assuming you can handle the guilt.The game is also gorgeous; Dubai is full of scenic backdrops, hellish sandstorms, and Crumbling architecture. You'll even get a full HD picture of a gut-wrenching scene involving phosphorus.Spec Ops' only noteworthy flaws are, unfortunately, the gameplay. It actually works fine, and it won't glitch/crash on you. But the third-person cover and shoot mechanics are very simple and plebeian, and as a result the strict shooter sequences are nothing to write home about. Similarly, multiplayer is eh. Again, it works, but definitely not the game's selling point.Spec Ops is not an easy game to play. By the end of it, you WILL hate yourself. You'll rethink why you played it and what could have possibly changed anything, or if it was worth changing at all. You'll feel pain for the characters, and solace in their resolution. And a video game that makes you think like that, as far as I'm concerned, is art.Gentlemen; welcome to Dubai.

												One of the best games with a narrative bend to come out in quite some time, the game ends up sitting on a pedestal next to the Walking Dead in terms of sheer story brilliance in the way only a game could pull off.While gameplay wise it ends up just being a passable Gears of War-styled, cover based third person shooter, the story ratchets up big-time at the end of the first act, proving to be the main pull of the game.Ignore the multiplayer, enjoy the single player (raise the difficulty if you want a real challenge, naturally), and you might find yourself blown away, even if you think you've seen every modern shooter so far.

												I was skeptical starting this game, I didn't expect much from it. What I got was an overall impressive gave with a fairly awesome storyline to boot. *No spoilers here*.The combat is pretty intense and seems very fluid, the visuals are quite nice, and the soundtrack is great. I enjoyed nearly every moment of the game as I was playing, and though it was short, it was sweet. There are a few moments that seemed a bit rushed and choppy, but in the larger scale of things, they're minor issues. If you pay close attention while playing, there are subtle surprises throughout the entire game that simply made me want to sit back and appreciate the work that went into creating this game. Seeing as Spec Ops: The Line is a bit old and outdated now, you may actually be pleasantly surprised if you decided to purchase and check it out. 8.5/10  -- I'd definitely recommend and will continue to play for SnG's. :D

number of helpful: 10 of 11 people (91%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 2, 2015
												Best way to put it into a TL;DR is by stating that this is like Rainbow Six type of gameplay mixed with a story that was the sole reason I played this game through and enjoyed it for it's uncensored gruesome nature. War isn't rosy, nor is it cozy. It's crazy. And this game displays exactly that very, very well. You can behead people with sniper rifle, pop their heads off with a shotgun and turn them into bloody giblets with explosives.But that's not the reason you play this game, no. The gameplay is very mediocre 6-7/10 as one would rate it. It's the story that keeps you wanting to play and find out what happens next more than anything. The characters are all well crafted into believable and realistic feeling experience as you play the game and advance within the story. The witty comments, yelling in combat and the terror is all well displayed and feels authentic. The soldiers you fight against yell orders loud and clear, just like you would in combat to relay the info. The game just feels right atmosphere wise. If you're looking for a game that displays how f*cked up a war can be when there's no clear answers, and how it can affect your morale and choice making, and how ruthless some things you must decide on can make you feel like a complete d*ck for doing so. This game extremely well relays the weight of your choices, if you f*ck up, you will feel and see what it will cause.A must buy to people who want to experience something different, and enjoy a really well made story.

content:
Posted: November 25, 2016
												Spec Ops: The Line presents a really interesting idea, but fails to execute it in a believable way.I can't understand the praise this game gets. I appreciate what this game is trying to do by tackling the stress and horrors of war, a subject most games skim over, but it fails to tackle the subject in and engaging way and only supported by mediocre gameplay.To its merit, this game does have some good Call Of Duty action movie style set pieces, a great, but sparingly used soundtrack, a couple of really good characters, and good voice acting to go with them. The game is about 5 hours long, which is a little on the short side to me.However...The third person cover based game play works, but really has nothing that makes it particularly exciting or even interesting. The opponents AI is predictable and tends to only charge the player, which seems strange since they are meant to be a professional military. Many of the guns feel very similar to use, and the game is rather easy if you stick to cover (although I only played on medium difficulty). There is a lot of big action sequences in this game that while really cool, are not very realistic. I think that perhaps a different approach to gameplay could have helped convey the story better.I was recommended this game because of its story, but I found this to be its biggest let down. The story just isn't believable and player character is annoying.I'll try to avoid spoilers.Spec Ops is advertised as a game that will "challenge players' morality by putting them in the middle of unspeakable situations," however this never really happens, because in these 'unspeakable situations' you have no choice at all. Failure to perform whatever horrible action will cause the mission to fail, and you must load a checkpoint. I think this idea would me much better executed if instead the player was forced to choose between two bad options, rather than being simply forced to do something or the mission fails.The player characters scripted decisions further detract from the believability of the story with him very quickly disregarding his original mission, and instead deciding to try and fix everything himself. His two companions realise that he is making bad decisions and comment on it, but for some reason never actually do anything about it and just follow along.However there are some pretty cool action movie bad guys in this game, however their placement is what is meant to be a realistic war just makes the story less believable.Perhaps I just don't see what everyone else does, but this game just didn't do it for me.Spec Ops: The Line isn't a bad game, it's just not anything special. If shooters are really your then, then you might want to pick this one up when it's on sale, but if you're looking for a deep and harrowing story then you had best look elsewhere.

content:
Posted: December 8, 2015
												I started playing this game with fairly high expectations and I must say I was not dissapointed. Even though the game is fairly linear - with little decision making in terms of the events unfolding - it still instills a sense of freedom as to how you choose to go about it.The game is clearly trying to grapple with the moral choices during times of war and battle, survival and necessities and in many ways it succeeds quite well.The setting and graphics are both very nice, while the locations are well thought out and quite detailed. The story (while nothing to jump out of your clothes for) drives you forward quite well, more than anything because it succeeds in instilling the feeling that you have to move on, that there is no choice but to move on...There isnt extraordinary variety in the weapons and most dont feel much diferent between them, but the momentum of the game doesnt really allow you to think about it much. You mostly grab whatever weapon you have some ammo for.I played it at the hard settings, which in some situations challenged me, but was overall an enjoyable experience (I believe normal dificulty might be a bit too easy).Finally there are a few points in the game where your (moral) decisions affect [if only partially] how the game unfolds.All in all it is a very nice story driven third person shooter, full of intense moments of combat. Not sure if there is a lot of replayability, unless you are after all the achievements, but I can see myself going back and playing it all over again.

content:
Posted: May 22, 2014
												There's no glorification in war. A conflict of ethics and code of conduct. What's the importance between one's conscious and one's choice just to survive. Spec Ops: The Line define such philosophies. The game's narrative is one of the most memorable in video game history as modern first-person shooters are too mainstream and cliche. There are certain scenes in the game that might or will make you pause, reflect, or even quit the game just to remind yourself on what war is. However, Spec Ops: The Line is NOT an anti-war game. It just tell what war is like. Many people and gamers can compare this game to Apocalypse Now. Sure, that's comparable but the game can be interpret to many literatures and certain documentaries like Waltz of Bashir. The gameplay is decent and typical but I believe that the developers strongly focused a lot more on the story and its message rather than gameplay. Spec Ops: The Line is a memorable game, but its more of the "one-time play" game mainly because of its heavy subject matter. Would I recommend this game to others? Yes, but it is up to you if you can handle the game's content. Best purchase this game on a steep discount.

number of helpful: 8 of 8 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 28
												Spec Ops: The Line is a third-person tactical shooter that does an excellent job of portraying the grim reality of war in a unique setting that seamlessly mixes desert and concrete jungle. One minute you are fighting through a sandstorm, the next you are hundreds of feet in the air, dangling from a zip line with a surreal backdrop of a dead city behind you. The visuals are simply breathtaking, and the desert is as much a character as the people in this superb, if disturbing, narrative. The gunplay is very enjoyable, but the experience is somewhat marred on the highest difficulty level because squad-mates are way too eager to charge without orders and get themselves killed, making it a chore to babysit them, and some areas much harder than they should be. The cover system itself is a bit cumbersome as well, and multiplayer is dead, but these are easy to overlook because the campaign is simply fantastic. Welcome to Dubai!

number of helpful: 9 of 10 people (90%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 25, 2014
												This is a game that, the moment I completed it, I sat down to write a review. I was conflicted about the storyline and content, as it's a game that it's nearly possible to complete in good conscience. Spec Ops : The Line is a common 3rd person military shooter in a lot of ways, save one : Its narrative. Some will find this game to be overly preachy, but having completed the campaign I think I know what the developers were going for. Military games of the last few years have shown players a lot of things. New graphics, firearms, and storylines that encompass many historical geopolitical campaigns. Spec Ops intends to show players something they've never been forced to confront. Themselves. In many ways, it's incredibly difficult to put a rating on this game as it's mediocre gameplay is carried by the narrative and (more importantly) the narrative's intent. It's also difficult to avoid spoiling as this is a game you will only experience the first time once. (duh) But the first time will be a troubling journey. During this game you will do horrific things simply because the objectives say so. The developers prod at you by saying "Just because the objectives dictate you should, doesn't mean you have to. You could simply turn the game off." In this way, Spec Ops is more of a mirror than anything. It puts a storyline in place which makes you angry, frustrated, and saddened by what transpires. It then steps back and allows you your chance at revenge. Sure, you're railroaded from a gameplay standpoint but as the Colonel says near the middle of the story, "This could have all been avoided if you just stopped." He's right. I could have stopped at any point. Spec Ops features imagery that is horrifying; war crimes are committed and witnessed in plenty. Yet you keep playing simply to make it all justified, to somehow convince yourself that the ends will justify the means and that everything will come out ok. It's not your fault. You were forced. In the end Spec Ops : The Line was the first game I've ever completed that I didn't feel happy about finishing.  Not because the gameplay was bad, but simply because no one with a conscience can finish this game without feeling dirty. I should have stopped somewhere in the middle of the game, and said, "Nope, this objective has gone too far. ♥♥♥♥ this game." But I didn't. My impressions of this game are almost the same as though I were reviewing A Clockwork Orange or Inglorious Basterds. You're not supposed to feel comfortable while you watch. Spec Ops is a bit different though, as you're in control of the "ultra violence" that's taking place. Maybe it's because I grew up in a violent neighborhood, where actions were always justified by their ends that this game hit me so deeply, maybe I'm just soft. In any case, if you've been on the fence about Spec Ops I'd strongly recommend a purchase based solely on its interperative value as it stands apart simply by having something to say about combat and war. I've been scratching my head about the ending all evening. 9/10

												Graphics: 8Sound: 9Gameplay: 8Good Points-Good character graphics-The combat & action are really good. Dying is part of the game, even on normal but that gives it a thrilling experiencing where you really got to fight for your life.-Full of action.-An ending I did not expect at all.Bad Points-You can only take two weapons with you. I think having 3 weapons at least is a must.-Environments can have ugly graphics.-Game is short. Finished the main campagne in 4.5 hoursOverall, is this game worth playing?Yes it surely is. It is not the same as other war games. It's a game that leaves you thinking. I would surely recommend this game to every one who likes action games or who like a game that touches you.Is it worth buying right now?This is a though one... I would say yes cause it is such a good game but when I look to the price tagg (20€) then I also think about the fact that I finished the game in 4.5 hours... If you do not like multiplayer or co-op there is nothing much to do after you completed the game. And from what I hear and see MP and Co-Op are dead... You should have played this game but since it is such a short game I would wait untill the price drops. Do not get me wrong it is a very good game and many people will say that it is worth 20€. Let me say it this way: If the campaign would have taken at least 8-9 hours to complete it I would say Yes buy it right now! But it is not like that and thats a shame cause it is really a good game. Damn I really would like to say to hell with it, buy the game right now! But I can't.

content:
Posted: August 28, 2014
												Spec Ops is a third-person shooter with a run-and-cover mechanic.While there is nothing new about this, I couldn't help but love this game, because this is so much more than your average TPS. It's also really, really well optimized.The gameplay is nicely done, and you handle it pretty fast, being immersed into the universe and the action really quickly. But what really makes it a unique game, is its story.In this game, you are not just an almighty stereotypical soldier, you are also just a man, with his weaknesses.The story features some choices; and while you're playing, I'd like you to think twice about everything that happens. Is everything justified? Can anything be justified at all?I won't spoil the story for you, but this game is much more than an action game. The scenario reminded me a bit of Shutter Island, and this is a good thing.TL;DR - If you want a game with a lot of action, this is for you. But if you also want an interesting and deep enough storyline, by all means, PLAY THIS GAME.

number of helpful: 19 of 29 people (66%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 1, 2015
												Spec Ops the Line at first seems quite carelessly executed FPS, a match for last Medal of Honor. But it is only an envelope which brings you emotionally affluent, strong message. Message about soldiers, war exhaustion and very basic one - about role of destruction in our system of values.For a gameplay Yager offers you a railroad shooter with a bit of squad support. If you seek a glorious, challenging gunplay - look the other way, that's not about Spec Ops the Line. For some reason, the most of the action feels like you were shell-shocked from the start of the game. Shooting part not really engaging. Two big notes about AI: 1) your companions are not that bad, as you can expect, playing in games like Bureau: XCom Declassified or Battlefield3. They scoring kills, and it feels like in normal difficulty setting they can bend opposers almost without your support. If only they were not rushing forward before it's clear sometimes, I'd say they are a perfect team.2) Quite opposite, behavior of your enemies usually is quite weak from the point of battle effectiveness. Even in the hardest difficulty setting where they shoot very precisely, and you dying alot being both outnumbered and outgunned... Still they a prey, and you are the hunter. You mow them, in dozens and hundreds.Being quite a mundane FPS, Spec Ops the Line offers a rather spanning visual experience, though. Sights of Dubai, all those sand and weather features are gorgeous. Impression when you destroying something to let another portion of sand, symbolizing chaos, gets even more space over a once-a-great-city... Can't buy it with mastercard, obviously.And music! Music part is fabulous. Maybe the best part of whole game.Overall, an artwork, audio and visual feast, all of this combined - is what keeping your interest, where the rush for gunplay challenge leaving you.But again, all of that - gunplay, visuals and one of a kind soundtrack - still just a cover for story with guaranteed catharsis in the end. For that Spec Ops the Line is taking such inordinanar reviews, like "take a PTSD in 6 hours. 10/10!" That game Will Be Remembered.Story what starts like "Only the dead have seen the end of war", and goes with "I destroy therefore I endure". What we observe as happening with the protagonist, Erich Fromm called "splendid isolation". This philosopher was describing destructiveness as a defence mechanism to preserve a human integrity, which is offended by some unexpected trials. That mechanism is never working like you think it should. See the game for it.Overall mark 7.5/10 killed Americans

content:
Posted: January 15, 2013
												Spec Ops The Line is a game I find it difficulty to accurately explain. On the surface, it's just another below average third person cover based shooter with nothing to set it apart from the hundreds of similar games on the market these days. Once you dig in a little, once you look at what is beneath you find a game that pushes the boundaries of video game narrative and tells you to look inward and feel a little ashamed.It would be hard to call Spec Ops The Line a fun game, because it isn't, the generic shooter mechanics grow old after about 2 hours. But it's not a game that's trying to entertain you. It's a game that wants you to feel bad, to get angry, to get sad. It's a game that talks to you, as a gamer, and just to the protagonist you play as.As you start off the game it is the classic scenario, something has gone terribly wrong in a middle eastern country and you are in command of a small special forces team that has to go in there and see what's happening. The specifics, Dubai has been encompassed by a gigantic sandstorm that pretty much ate the entire city and it's population, a US battalion disobeyed orders and went there trying to evacuate the civilians but haven't been heard from since.As you go through the opening motions the game fills you with the classic stereotypes, you and your team makes crude jokes as they walk past bodies of those that didn't make it out in time and quickly enough you run into a bunch of locals with guns and find yourself shooting your way downtown. With a great degree of subtlety however the game quickly changes as things get progressively darker and more grim without you being able to pinpoint exactly where things went off the rails.Spec Ops The Line is a game I would recommend that everyone plays, even if just to see how a video game narrative can potentially evolve. I doubt Spec Ops The Line will become that great of a success story. I even doubt it will have that much of an impact on how games are made. But it is still a very important game because it does something that you have never experienced before and that is rarity these days.

content:
Posted: March 18
"Do you feel like a hero yet?"That's the line you will always have in your mind during the game. Just this line."Spec Ops: The Line" is the most brutal and shocking game I have played. It gets you to a point where you don't want to continue, but you continue, because you are a Soldier. A soldier who keeps fighting, no matter what.This game makes you think about war in a new way, because it approches the subject in a way I haven't seen in any shooter I played. It doesn't glorify it, there are no heros, no winners. Only people who are defeated and broken. Civilian? Soldier? In the end it doesn't matter, just another soul that died or survived.It has one of the best stories I have ever played, because it makes you think alot..For everybody who wants to play it. Keep your eyes open in the Epilogue. You can make a huge discovery.

content:
Posted: October 3, 2014
												It's hard to comment on this game without spoilers, but I'm trying my best to avoid them. Also note that I didn't try the multiplayer and I'm only going to comment on the single player campaign.The game presents a well-crafted story that starts out as a mission to scout the city of Dubai as it suffers from the destruction caused by a gigantic sand storm. Civilians are trapped inside mile high dunes of sands after the military lost contact to a former evacuation squad and they send Martin Walker and two companions to investigate after they received a distress signal. The deeper the squad dives into the city, the more gruesome events get. You witness atrocities done by American soldiers who lost track of their goal as the horrible story of the fallen Dubai unfolds with your discoveries and the game doesn't hesitate to shock you when it wants you to see what terrifying things people can do in a struggle for survival. (if you don't have a thick skin, you might want to plan to take breaks)If it weren't for the story, the game would be forgettable, and that is the biggest danger if you don't know it yet - those who don't know what to expect will easily lose interest. The shooting itself plays well enough to work - there's cover-based shooting with various real-life weapons, there are melee attacks and finishers, a small selection of squad commands, you can sometimes destroy terrain to take out clusters of foes with sand dunes. There's not much traditional gameplay evolution, except that the selection of weapons grows as some weapons only appear later in the game.If you ONLY come for the shooting, you will most likely be disappointed or even confused through the first couple of chapters. If you want to give this game a fair chance, keep on playing until the end of Chapter 8 at least. If you get there and still only come for the shooting, but want to give the game a chance nevertheless, start over again and pay close attention to the dialog and try to think about the twists that happen in the beginning of the game, which are admittedly a little hard to follow the first time around.A word about the length of the game: The play time is rather short (I beat the game in 6 hours on easiest difficulty.. there is a reason you don't want to turn up the difficulty in the late game, which I leave up to you to find out), but if you get into it, it probably won't let you go for a while, especially since many discussions on the internet send you away with spoiler warnings right away. Once you've played through the game and see the revelations, you will want to play it again to see things in a different light. If you find yourself in an obsession about the meaning of the game, a good reading after you finish it is "Killing is Harmless" by Brendan Keogh. It's an affordable eBook that expands on a lot of details that you will easily miss on a casual playthrough. It links a good amount of articles on the internet, some of which include stances by the developers and lead writer. My Steam profile says I've played this game for only 16 hours, but I spent well over 30 hours reading up and watching on YouTube on what others thought about it.Spec Ops: The Line deserves more attention for the sheer courage the developer showed for demonstrating such a cruelly honest truth through a video game, and I recommend it wholeheartedly to everyone who likes unconventional games. It makes you think about the nature of good and evil and takes a harsh stance on recent topics like Western military interventionism and the cruelty of modern warfare. It made me think for long, and it pulled something off that is impossible to do with a book or a movie. I want more people to play this game, because it deserves to be talked about, but can't be talked about unless you've given it at least one complete playthrough.

content:
Posted: November 10, 2014
												I normally avoid first person shooters, which sadly is what I thought Spec Ops was when I picked it up in a bundle off of the glowing praise it’s story has reviewed. In reality, it is a cover based third person shooter. Sadly I’m sure most people glazed right over this game amongst the veritable sea of cover based third person shooter garbage flooding the market. In many respects, it’s hard to blame them. The controls are average, squad AI is passable at best, the shooting isn’t weak, but at the same time doesn’t carry as much weight as you would expect. The difference with Spec Ops is that the narrative is absolutely fascinating. I can’t in good conscious point out any specifics of the plot because to spoil it would ruin the impact it would leave on anyone who hasn’t yet played it. What I can say is that at the end of the final cutscene I sat back and really thought about all of my choices and actions I took throughout the campaign. I can only think of a handful of games which have ever made such an impact on me.Spec Ops: The Line breaks the mold and is a must buy if nothing more than to see what modern military shooters have to offer us besides 10 year old multiplayer daycare.

content:
Posted: May 2, 2014
												This is easily the best game I've ever played. You shouldn't go into this game for gameplay, it isn't anything new but it works perfectly fine with guns being relatively fun to use and enemies having good AI. At times you will find yourself dying a little too quick while some enemies feel like bullet sponges, but that's about right considering how little you wear while they are fully armoured. Now that we're done with the gameplay, the story is the real hook to buying this game. You will find yourself in a gripping story where you are put though many different situations to test your morality, most of which are no win scenarios and give no obvious good choices making you feel worse the more you play. The game is not black and white but rather the complete opposite with the game itself questioning you on whether or not you're really the hero as you fight your way through an entire army in order to find Konrad and end the nightmare he brought to Dubai when him and his soldiers were unable to evacuate this forgotten city. As the game progresses both you and the main protagonist will start to question what's really happening and your current mental state until you reach the ending which left me in such shock that I was left speechless and felt the need to replay the final mission numerous times to see all the endings. I personally felt dead inside after my first run. By the end of my experience I encountered so many twists and turns I didnt know what to expect next and after everything was over, I wanted to go back through the game and make different decisions from my first run to see how my teammates, myself and how everyone around me would react. Overall This was the ultimate video game narrative I've ever experienced and found it more than worth my time, this game took me about 8 hrs to complete due to some moments that took me a few too many tries, keeping it from being fun at all times, but for most people this shouldn't be much longer than 6 hrs though for most who play it on normal difficulty. I found that this game's length was excusable due to the fact that it was so immersive it felt at least twice as long. In the end this game has the best narrative in just about any game I have played so far including Telltale's Walking Dead games and it conveys a great message for the players, making this more than worth the cost.

number of helpful: 9 of 11 people (82%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 20, 2015
My score: 8/10Playthrough time: 8.5 hours (not rushed, watched all cutscenes and including retrying some sections a few times) Did not try the multiplayer mode.Pros:+Excellent graphics (Unreal Engine).+A good selection of weapons at your disposal.+Nice gameplay, it's a cover based third person shooter that works really well+The story offers a different take to the military shooter type of game, dealing with the consequences of killing hundreds of people in combat.Cons:-The game might be too much for some, it's not all fun gunning down enemies, you have to deal with the consequences of your actions (in a more realistic manner than most games) as well.Performance notes:Runs very smooth (60 fps) with an R9 280X @1080P and max settings. The Xbox 360 controller works well (even though you don't get the same precision as with the keyboard/mouse) and this game is a good one for playing on the TV from the couch, but it's just as good in front of a desktop computer controlled with the keyboard/mouse.Main review:I was very positively surprised by this game.The story starts out in Dubai, where most of the population have been evacuated due to heavy sandstorms. Your team is sent on a recon mission, and when discovering dead American soldiers, you continue further in to the city to investigate and look for survivors.


Spec Ops: The Line 
A Screenshot of Spec Ops: The Line
By: tso184




The basic mechanics of the game are those found in most third person cover based shooters. Most of the time you're behind cover, returning fire at any enemies present. You also have grenades at your disposal, and you can issue simple commands to your squad members (target certain enemies, and in some situations order one of them to throw a flashbang).The game mechanics themselves are good enough to make the game worth it, but as the game unfolds, you discover that there is more to it than most other modern action games. You are faced with some difficult choices, and have to live with the consequences of your actions in the game.


Spec Ops: The Line 
A Screenshot of Spec Ops: The Line
By: tso184




The choices are few and far between, and don't really change the storyline, this is not a role playing game, it's more of a cinematic experience (the player is even credited as a "special guest star" in the credits) where you take control over the action. The level design is quite linear, but this isn't necessarily a bad thing.I don't want to reveal too much about the story, but when you in other games kill hundreds of enemy soldiers and don't think much of it, this game makes you think about what you're doing. You experience the trauma through the main protagonist, and chances are, you won't feel great about what you've done after playing through the game.


Spec Ops: The Line 
A Screenshot of Spec Ops: The Line
By: tso184




Excellent graphics, solid game mechanics, and a story that makes you stop and think. I would definitely recommend Spec Ops: The line.

content:
Posted: August 10, 2014
												There is one basic and important thing to know about Spec Ops: The Line, and that's that it is at the same time a deeply satisfying and a deeply frustrating experience. Gameplay-wise, it's a fairly competent shooter marred by some very poor design decisions- checkpoints often come before cutscenes and are too far apart, which, combined with the surprisingly unforgiving difficulty (even on Normal you can find yourself gunned down in seconds) can be teeth-grindingly annoying. The range of guns you can pick up is unremarkable and there are nice secondary functions to a lot of them; you can carry three kinds of grenades; the cover mechanic is just flawed enough to be irritating but functions tolerably for the most part.This is not a game about gameplay, however.Were it to be judged purely on its design and mechanics, Spec Ops: The Line would be pretty forgettable, but it has an ace in the hole: a story so out of the blue in its direction and message that it's a miracle a major publisher put this game out at all. What you think you're getting- particularly if you only play the demo- is another gung-ho gun-wielding slice of Americans saving the day by killing all the brown people. What you actually get is a slow, spiralling descent into madness that wears its Heart of Darkness/Apocalypse Now inspirations proudly and uses them to forge a modern-day commentary on the type of video game you thought you were going to play. Captain Walker is no godly Call of Duty avatar who can murder a thousand people and walk away- he falls apart mentally, visually and audibly as the game continues, his professionalism is stripped away and raw ego left exposed. "Tango down" becomes a more chilling, "Kill is ♥♥♥♥ing confirmed" as the game confronts you with issues of culpability and responsibility. It's incredibly unsettling.If you don't come away from Spec Ops: The Line with questions and doubts about shooters, I have serious concerns about whether you're dead inside. Do your best to ignore the sometimes-frustrating controls and systems and try and appreciate just how important this game is in the history of, and commentary on, shooters.

number of helpful: 6 of 6 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 15, 2013
An Honest Illustration of War & the Scars It LeavesThe demo does this game no justice. Do -not- play it."Being in the modern military is probably one of the hardest, most trying things a person can do and it's so great to see a game make more of that than a simple power fantasy." - Extra CreditsIf you're looking for a mindless, nationalistic military shooter, you're not going to find it here. No other shooters have explored the weight that comes with pulling the trigger in war more than this game has. Although the mechanics are a part of the storytelling, the gameplay isn't as advanced as the current flurry of Call of Dutys, Battlefields, or Medal of Honors but the trade off is worth it. Those games don't even bother trying to touch on half of the things Spec Ops addressed; they actively avoid PTSD to opt for comic book heroics and focus on glorifying and romanticizing war. It's honest, visceral, and engaging in all its literal and metaphorical symbolism.If you decide to pick this up, and I strongly suggest that you do, experience it for the single-player story. The multiplayer was just an added bonus but don't judge the entire game by it if you decide to try that out first. It'll be one of the most eye-opening gaming experiences you'll ever have. The game trusts you to make your own decisions. Spec Ops: The Line is worth it full price if you think you'd enjoy a military shooter that gives more thought into its story and character development rather than mechanics. Yager really took a risk with this game and it's an experience I will always remember.10/10 - JUNEBUG'S FAVORITES

number of helpful: 6 of 6 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 23, 2014
												CAUTION, THIS REVIEW CONTAINS SPOILERS!To begin with, Spec Ops: The Line is not a typical action shooter. Spec Ops is a game that will indeed shock you in some parts of the campaign. The developers wanted to show us the other side of the war where everything that you think will be all right, goes wrong and you are the one blamed for that. The campaign takes place in destroyed by storm Dubai where we have the mission to rescue any survivors. The game shows us then a very good perspective of how a such a powerful city as Dubai can be destroyed in days by thirst, hunger and civil war. The campaign then also shows how rest of the world just do not care about other conflicts. The game takes then focus on team-work where you and two other soldiers are going through the city trying to survive. I also felt like the campaign was slowly turning you into a murderer, where you began as a friendly soldier and ended as a killer.                                                                                                                                                              The game itself is very good. The shooting mechanics are great, there is also some stealth gameplay. The game offers a wide list of weapons which is also great. The missions are ´´OK´´designed, so do not expect much. The game offers some decent graphics, but it´s still the gameplay that shows most potential. Spec Ops: The Line offers also a great addition where you have to find several ´´intelligence files´´ so it´s also a great thing for achievement hunters. Unfortunately I haven´t played the multiplayer yet, so I can´t review it. I personally liked the game. I bought it on Humble Bundle for several dollars and I can´t really say it was not worth it. The campaign after all was great experience in my opinion even though it shocked me in some chapters. The game itself was also good; the AI, weapons, Dubai perspective are definitely its best features.Overall I would like to say that the game was great and I truly recommend it to anyone to try it out. I give the game a solid 7/10

content:
Posted: July 16, 2013
												"Military shooters don't often rank high on the narrative front, usually favoring gung-ho G.I. Joe antics and flag waving over character development. And, at first, Spec Ops: The Line falls right in line with that stereotype--you take control of Walker, a soldier sent into a sandstorm-ruined Dubai to find a missing Colonel. But as time goes on it becomes more and more obvious that there's something more devious afoot, and the shooter's story transforms from run-of-the-mill to one-of-a-kind.What unfolds is a damning criticism of shooters themselves, questioning everything that gamers have grown accustom to. Walker's journey sends him marching into the nucleus of the genre, playing with the storytelling in ways no other game has. By the end you might feel anger or sadness, but the important thing is that you'll feel something, and that's pretty rare in military shooters." I strongly urge you to play this game. This has to be one of the greatest stories every written.

content:
Posted: October 30, 2015
												Now this is a game that has impact on you. Throughout the chapters you come to feel what means to be human, to make mistakes and to learn about the weight of your actions. Three main characters (though only one is playable, but you get to like all of them), each one with their own personality and showing different reactions to the situations they come across and the things they have to do and choose to do. Yes, this game is a master at making you think if you ever had a choice, if you could have made the outcome different. You'll most likely get yourself wondering what you would have done or how you would have felt in their places.Storywise this game could hardly get any better. It's epic, it's moving, it's personal.Gameplay could see some improvements, movement sometimes is your worst foe, but it's not bad, many guns, squad commands, smooth aim, some strategy, some possibilities and the most useful grenades i've ever thrown (the enemies fully agree with this, believe me).It has a decent amount of replay value, if you want to see the different paths you can take, make different choices and see all the possible outcomes. You can also increase the game difficulty and replay it, things can get very challenging.So, in a nutshell, this game is a gem, completely worth playing, an amazing experience that still doesn't receive all the attention it deserves. I highly recommend this one.

content:
Posted: July 6, 2014
												WARNING: A LOT OF FORESHADOWING HERE, BUT NO SPOILERSThe best works of art are created in a time where they are most needed, and found in the places no one would bother to look. In today's gaming industry, many are looking for the next great narrative to be found in a small indie game, or an expertly crafted RPG. Absolutely nobody was expecting a third-person military shooter to be the breakthrough they were desperately searching for, and that just adds to the utter brilliance of Spec Ops: The Line.As you may have heard, the game is very much intwined in the same themes as Joseph Conrad's incredible novel, "Heart of Darkness". You are a Special Forces captain sent in with your 3-man squad to the ruins of Dubai. The way the city is presented is unlike any other world design in recent memory, as you truly feel the suffering of the survivors, from the rotting, strung-up corpses to the creepiness of the multiple murals and graffiti you will stumble upon. Even with the bright aesthetics of sand and sun, make no mistake; Dubai is a wasteland with nothing left to offer.However, world design takes a backseat to narrative here, where the characters you encounter and the actions you take break down every preconception you might have had about military shooters. From the eerie antagonist to the journalist who could've very well been the brother of Dennis Hopper from Apocalypse Now, every character here feels needed. You will be forced to take actions that will genuinely shock you. By the third hour, I had committed what was by far, the most horrifying thing I have ever done in a video game. And make no mistake, none of this is purely for shock value, but truly necessary thematically, in order to build up to an unforgettable finale.By the end of the game, you will wonder why you bothered to play this game at all. But really, that's just it. In this game, you are not meant to be the hero. You are not supposed to have a happy ending, you are not meant to be the great patriot fighting for his country. It is the war epic that is needed after America's decade-long conflict in Afghanistan. It is what "The Red Badge of Courage" was to the American Civil War, what "The Deer Hunter" was to Vietnam. Even the game asks you towards the end, "Do you remember why you came here?" But that's just it. You may have forgotten why you played this game, but you'll be glad you did.

content:
Posted: January 24, 2016
It takes a strong man to deny what's right in front of him..."In the beggining it seems like just another CoD style corridor action game. After few minutes when the story opens, it really grows on you and makes you curious. Then you don't care that much about the overplayed gameplay style that doesn't bring anything new to the table, because it's made like this just to let the story shine.The multiple endings are worth watching and all of them are very, very powerful. I will never forget that moment when we bombed the base with soldiers and also hiding civilians. When I saw to the bone burnt dead woman holding her child, and tried to protect it, I just hold my face with goosebumbs, saying to myself "What have I done" If a game can give you unforgettable emotional moments, you know you played something special, and this little known game (unluckily!) is something special."Do you feel like a hero yet?..."If you want to unlock all achievements, prepare on very mentally challenging FUBAR experience. As I said, gameplay is very CoD and those few heroic moments are OK if playing on first 3 difficulties, but it's absolutely horrible on FUBAR, especially in solo parts when you are outmatched 1v10 and you have few bullets and low HP. Took me definitely more than 60-70 replays through whole campaign, so good luck with it.

content:
Posted: March 29, 2014
												Spec Ops: The Line...Ladies and gentlemen... Welcome to Dubai.StoryStarting my review with commenting on how good of a story this game had (IMO).Dramatic twists of events. Taking choices you wouldn't want to. Going through a deep slow path of insanity by each chapter.I'm usually not amused by any type of story an army game has to offer and I must admit in my eyes most of them are more or less the same.However out of the bucket of clichés and reused material Spec Ops: The Line stands out.The fictional concept told here is so well blended that it kept my interest through the whole time from start to end.I even did 4 runs of the game itself in order to experience all 4 different endings.Can't say it is original, after the amount of movies and games that have been out so far, there's hardly anything new to be served in militaristic games. However it is the way the content is served that makes the difference in this type of games, this one right here gets the cookie for me.DirectionThe game is very very well directed. The way the story is balanced through action sessions, intense cutscenes, sweet environmental designs, and impressive musical options.All combined so smoothly with some of the very best voice acting I've seen for an action shooter.GraphicsNeatly scripted on Unreal Engine 3, the game has sweet physics and sandstorm and smoke dynamics. Of course there have been titles a lot more famous for their graphics for 2012.But for the experience offered, Spec Ops: The Line's graphics are just perfect and it's lacking major bugs or issues.GameplayVery easy and comfortable to handle. Ammo and amount of weapons is just about right.Destructible environment (just a few details here and there) add a good taste on the style of the shooter experience and of course not missing the ability to take cover and using commands to make your crew help you dynamically in various situations.Difficulty makes a difference from the easiest to the hardest mode and it gets more and more challenging, sometimes kinda too hard in the hardest difficulty level.MusicThe music used in the game is AMAZING.Not only the acoustic backrgound is very good, but you will also hear a brilliant collection of songs through the game, every single one very accurately put in each situation like a glove.SoundCool environmental and battle effects that seem about right at any moment of the game. No problems with blending music or voice acting.AverageConsidering that this game was implemented by a very small team and the studio itself is not even famous for having any other major titles around the market (Yager Development only have one other game implemented which is very old)It was freaking amazing. With a story that has a beginning, a peak, and an end. Well made, balanced, satisfying, with good action and even a well done multiplayer and co-op modes.Considering how shallow other a lot more famous games from bigger studios have ended up being, Spec Ops: The Line is by the full meaning of the phrase 'a job well done'.And for the asked price, this title is pure gold!Do get it. 100% recommended!

Posted: September 24, 2016
												Post-traumatic Stress Disorder can occur following a life-threatening event like military combat, natural disasters, terrorist incidents, serious accidents, or violent personal assaults like♥♥♥♥♥♥ Most survivors of trauma return to normal given a little time. However, some people have stress reactions that don't go away on their own, or may even get worse over time. These individuals may develop PTSD.People who suffer from PTSD often suffer from nightmares, flashbacks, difficulty sleeping, and feeling emotionally numb. These symptoms can significantly impair a person's daily life.PTSD is marked by clear physical and psychological symptoms. It often has symptoms like depression, substance abuse, problems of memory and cognition, and other physical and mental health problems. The disorder is also associated with difficulties in social or family life, including occupational instability, marital problems, family discord, and difficulties in parenting.If you are suffering from PTSD, or know someone who is, the following list of resources and information will help you find help in dealing with PTSD and related conditions.Each VA medical center has PTSD specialists who provide treatment for Veterans with PTSD. Plus, the VA provides nearly 200 specialized PTSD treatment programs. A referral is usually needed to access the specialty programs. You can use this VA PTSD Program Locator to see if there is a specialized program near you.NOTE: If you are in crisis dial 911 or 800-273-TALK (1-800-273-8255).Other VA provided information on PTSDWhat is PTSD?Find out about the symptoms of PTSD and how they develop.Symptoms of PTSDLearn about PTSD symptoms and when to get help..How Common is PTSD?Find out how many people have PTSD and who is most likely to develop PTSD.Treatment of PTSDDescribes the treatments shown to be effective for PTSD and what you can expect from your therapist.What Can I Do if I Think I Have PTSD?Learn what to do and answer an questionaire to see if you need to be assessed by a professional.Understanding PTSD TreatmentView this interactive module about PTSD treatment options. A companion to Understanding PTSD, it has full color photos and videos of clinicians who provide care. It can help overcome any myths you might have about PTSD treatment.Frequently Asked Questions About PTSDBasic information about PTSD and its treatment. Includes links to resources for getting help.

number of helpful: 8 of 10 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 15, 2015
												In a world where everyone's a hero when they launch a shooter, Spec Ops: The Line crushed that stereotype. Never had a game make me question my morality as much as Spec Ops: The line. This game surpassed the level of a game, bringing to me what I can only described as "a very real experience".The strong emotions of the graphics and voice acting emersed me into a setting where I ponder over every decision I made while playing as the protagonist. I can still vividly remember the very first time I was shown the repercussions after I made a "mistake". Without revealing spoilers, I can only say I regretted so hard I did not make a save before making that decision and it "haunted" me for the rest of the game, quite literally.Together with This War of Mine, I'm pretty sure Spec Ops: The Line can be arguably the next most realistic war game ever scripted. It introduces as a shooter, but jolts you back up and shake you vigorously, reminding you that every single round that connects with an "enemy", someone out there lost their loved one.I have been late in picking up Spec Ops: The Line, and I regret letting it grow dust in my collection and not playing it sooner. The experience of this game is as good as reading a great novel. Kudos to the screenwriters for writing such an outstanding story.Update: Voted for The “Whoooaaaaaaa, dude!” Award 2016

content:
Posted: March 30
												Spec Ops: The Line is something... more than a game. Obviously it is a game, because it features gameplay--specifically, gameplay where you and two squad mates are sent into a war-torn Dubai on a recon mission that turns into something so much more. Spec Ops has the most basic, mundane third person shooting that one can wish for: you can hide behind cover, you shoot humans with guns, your health recovers by waiting, and there is a ton of sand. But that's the point of Spec Ops. A mundane facade designed to undermine your expectations, because nothing can prepare you for what the game's story puts you through. There comes a point where you stop shooting the enemy and you question what you're even doing--you get so caught up in the gameplay that you don't even realize the decisions you're making, and furthermore, the decisions out of your control.Spec Ops: The Line is, essentially, a deconstruction of the modern military shooter genre. It grabs hold of the likes of Call of Duty, Battlefield, and other contemporaries and asks them: why?

Posted: May 14, 2014
												Without giving out too much of the plot, this is a modern military shooter that deconstructs modern military shooters. The things that you'll do in this game will haunt your dreams weeks after you finish, and you'll question the things you do in other games for nearly the rest of your life. This third-person shooter blows the♥♥♥♥♥♥out of crappy, big budget FPSs like Call of Duty and Medal of Honor. Spec Ops: The Line is a must-have, must-play, and is worth every penny. By the way, I suggest that you find someone willing to hug you and tell you that you're still a good person once you finish...You'll need it......Why haven't you bought this already, damn it?!UPDATE 12/31/14: I've been ruminating a bit more on this and gaming's place amongst other media, and I want to say something else: Gaming may not yet have its 'Citizen Kane', but it damn sure does have its 'Apocalypse Now'. Also, as I'm writing this, the Steam Winter Sale has this at $5.99 US, which is 80% off its normal price. Anyone else dragging their feet on this purchase has no financial excuse. Buy this game as soon as possible.

												Wow! Simply said WOW!!!This is not your average "America saves the world from Terror"-crap story that most military shooter bring us today. No, this is not sir, this is an engaging tale of survival amidst the "Heart of Brightness in Dubai", exlporing themes commonly overlookedin other games of the genre. While some players may be complaining about certain events in the game that might make you feel bad, it should make you think about war and what's going on - or better what is/may/might happen in a warzone. Thus Spec Ops The Line becomes one of those rare to find "anti-war" titles. An arousing story that shouldn't upset us but  make us think.

number of helpful: 115 of 215 people (53%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 24, 2014
												While Spec Ops is a difficult game to recommend based on its mediocre gameplay, performance issues, and frustrating controls the story packs a real punch and is the sole highlight of the game. The 'Do you recommend this game, Yes : No" is very limiting here because it depends. If you are looking for a good game this isn't it. If you are looking for one with a great story that is a military game no less than you found it. In this "I'm offended" generation where someone always has to be offended by something and demand its removal the devs went all out and didn't care who they offended. They had a message to send and pulled no punches.Game wise Spec Ops The Line suffers. I was constantly fighting with the controls and couldn't help but be bored to death whenever the shooting started thanks to the mediocre mechanics and bad AI. It came to the point where I was trying to rush through the game just so I could be done with it and that's a shame because it somewhat took away from the impact of the story. The visuals are average and the aliasing hurt my eyes but it runs worse than Crysis 3. On a rig equipped with a 3770K, 16 Gigs of RAM, and a GTX 780ti I was getting frequent stutters, shaky mouse movements, and framerate drops. With that said the creators of Spec Ops The Line clearly had a vision and they must have fought tooth and nail to make it happen. What starts off as a cliché military shooter ends up as something far more. The story is grim, depressing, bold, and a big middle finger to military games which rely on unquestioning patriotism and make war seem like it's fun and cool. It is not afraid to tackle the horrors of war and PTSD. It's designed to make you feel uncomfortable and it's about time a military game goes this route.It's a shame then that there isn't a good game here to compliment the work put in by the writers. I am glad to have experienced Spec Ops The Line but it is not something I can easily recommend.

number of helpful: 5 of 5 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 30, 2016
Spec Ops: The line, how not to be a good personEvery now and then a game comes along that takes everyone by storm, games that will in 10 to 15 years be called classics. Spec Ops: The line Is one of those games and I wish I decided to buy it earlier.At time of writing this I have put a fair few hours into Spec Ops and have completed it twice, when I first started playing it I simply rushed through each area at a time not really paying attention to anything. just the knowledge that I am the "good guys" and anyone who shot at me were the "bad guys" I saw an enemy, I shot them and then moved onto the next one and kept moving and had fun doing it I thought that I would finish and game and feel pretty happy about itHowever when I had finished Spec Ops I was silent. I thought about my actions and what they caused, how many people I had killed in a senseless fantasy to do "what was right" and why even after completing it I never felt happy I never felt that I was the hero of the story that I had become the savior of Dubai. A particular moment stood out to me during the playthough, a moment when I on impluse, shot into a crowd of unarmed, innocent people because I wanted revenge I wanted to do what was right and I was determined that I could do what was right. but that same drive to do what I percieved as right, lead to the deaths of so many others. I went into Spec Ops wanting to do good and thought that I could always choose the least evil option when I was given the chance and in the end It would all be fine. I was wrong and the game made me realise that I truly didnt know how hard it is to "be a good person"Get this game on sale, use a friends copy but atleast play through the game once, get to understand what it is trying to tell you and learn that PTSD is not a damn joke.

number of helpful: 5 of 5 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 23, 2014
												I just finished a lenghty Spec Ops achievement marathon. Played this game a lot in my freetime and now I finally can put it to rest. While I don't want to consider myself an achievement ♥♥♥♥♥, I like to pay games I really enjoy a tribute by completing them 100%.Now, this introduction perfectly fits (more or less) into the message of the game. Are violent games really just games, you play and get an achievement for your 50th headshot? Is it okay to sit back and enjoy war, while you are the hero, kicking the♥♥♥♥♥of all the terrorist scum that threatens to destroy the world? I can't really compare Spec Ops: The Line to Battlefield, Call of Duty setting-wise or Gears of War and Mass Effect gameplay-wise, as I've never played them. But what I can say is, that, in my humble opinion, Spec Ops: The Line is a masterpiece. Not without its flaws, but a masterpiece nonetheless.Gameplaywise, you get the typical brown modern war 3rd person shooter thingy. What do you expect? You play a badass dude to murder tons of evil dudes. Simple as that. But storywise, you are encountered by some moral questions, you might not have asked you yet. And suddenly, all the dull gameplay makes sense in a more complex way.I don't want to spoil too much here, so I'll keep it short: If you are expecting a breakthrough in modern warfare gameplay and gunfights, this game is nothing for you. If you are interested in a good and gripping story, with one ore the other twist and an underlying message, you must play this game, even if you don't care about war shooters, like me. Highly recommended!

Posted: May 24, 2014
												While Spec Ops is a difficult game to recommend based on its mediocre gameplay, performance issues, and frustrating controls the story packs a real punch and is the sole highlight of the game. The 'Do you recommend this game, Yes : No" is very limiting here because it depends. If you are looking for a good game this isn't it. If you are looking for one with a great story that is a military game no less than you found it. In this "I'm offended" generation where someone always has to be offended by something and demand its removal the devs went all out and didn't care who they offended. They had a message to send and pulled no punches.Game wise Spec Ops The Line suffers. I was constantly fighting with the controls and couldn't help but be bored to death whenever the shooting started thanks to the mediocre mechanics and bad AI. It came to the point where I was trying to rush through the game just so I could be done with it and that's a shame because it somewhat took away from the impact of the story. The visuals are average and the aliasing hurt my eyes but it runs worse than Crysis 3. On a rig equipped with a 3770K, 16 Gigs of RAM, and a GTX 780ti I was getting frequent stutters, shaky mouse movements, and framerate drops. With that said the creators of Spec Ops The Line clearly had a vision and they must have fought tooth and nail to make it happen. What starts off as a cliché military shooter ends up as something far more. The story is grim, depressing, bold, and a big middle finger to military games which rely on unquestioning patriotism and make war seem like it's fun and cool. It is not afraid to tackle the horrors of war and PTSD. It's designed to make you feel uncomfortable and it's about time a military game goes this route.It's a shame then that there isn't a good game here to compliment the work put in by the writers. I am glad to have experienced Spec Ops The Line but it is not something I can easily recommend.

												i owned this game more than 1 year without playing it, but now i regret that i did not played it earlier.the game is also having the message that we all can make a stupid decision, which we will regret later.in the first hour of gameplay this isnt much different compared with any other 08/15 3rd-person shooter.but with further progress in the story, the true strenght of the game will be revealed.the game is taking place in dubai, where heavy sandstorms isolated its whole population.the player is taking the role of cpt. martin walker accompanied by his squad members lugo and adams.this squad was sent to investigate the misterious vanishing of the 33rd Battalion who was sent earlier to start a rescue mission for the survivors of the catastrophe.the story is showing the "dark side" of war on a high psychological level.several choices will be given to the player, during the playthrough.at the end of the 5 hour long story, cpt. walker is getting confronted with "the truth", and what the hell happened there.the decisions the player made will come back to him in a very uncomfortable way.spec ops is the first game that made me feel like an ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, through its simple but awesome plot.i can highly recommend everyone finishing this game at least once.it is truly a masterpiece of a shooter  Criteria Rating   Gameplay 7/10   Story 10/10   Graphics 7/10   Atmosphere 9/10

content:
Posted: September 2, 2013
												Modern Military Shooters (MMS) are some of the biggest budget games that are released every year, with "extreme" realism and crappy storyline that look copied from a children's book and tries to get under our skin, but epic fails and falls flat.WELL, Spec Ops: The Line skullf*cks the formula by giving one of the most epic single player experiences, making it one of the best games of 2012 for me and one of the best stories of all time in a game, despite the barebones competitive multiplayer and Co-Op missions...Graphics are really good, detail is nice, voice acting is stellar and so is face animation. Some of the controls, however seem to be directly ported from console as the key to vault over cover is the same as melee, and sprinting is the same as getting into cover (wait...what?!), however, after a bit of playing it, you will get used to it, but you may get some cheap-shot deaths from those awkward controls in the start...As for story, the game nails it. It happens in a corrupt war-damaged Dubai, where a squad of 3 soldiers battle to get civilians out of the mess that happened, however, you face many decisions, that fight your moral principals and can make you feel bad for the sh*t you've done throughout the game. Your choices, like an RPG, affect the ending and most of them are really tricky as you don't know which one to take, since all of them have heavy consequences. Spec Ops: The Line makes you use your morality and ethical code to the extreme. Something rare nowadays in the gaming industry...Multiplayer is just...there, it can provide fun moments but not many, since it feels tacked on, you can clearly see that all the effort was put in the SP Campaign. Co-Op can be fun with a friend but not much else as you only have 4 missions, but they are really hard to pull off so an extra hand can be a life-savior, too bad the Co-Op isn't for 4 players or 3 (like a squad, like from the campaign), it's only for 2 players, but i'm ok with it actually unlike, MW3 survival mode for example, as 4 players would make much more sense.Also, gameplay is well done, the gunplay is smooth but some guns come punch a bit harder...The cover system works well (one of the best and most fluid I've ever seen!), and other mechanics (execution for example) work nicely too, despite the confusing controls, but although the gameplay mechanics work, it isn't groundbreaking in any stretch of the imagination so the game may get repetitive after your first playthrough so the final difficulty unlocked after beating the game may never be experienced due to the repetitive nature of the gameplay.Spec Ops is one of those "don't miss it" games, and, despite it's *minimal* flaws, it deserves an 9.5/10While the game doesn't really surprise in the beggining, the situation gets better in the middle and end, so youtube gameplay may not be helpful to make up your mind. Also, only when you *are playing the game yourself* does the game appeal, not in gameplay videos, in my opinion. It's like 20 euros now on steam, much lower on sales (like 4,99 €) so, you can't miss it!

content:
Posted: October 3, 2014
												Do you know this feeling when there are two voices in your head arguing over what is the right thing to do and it makes you extremely uncomfortable? It's called cognitive dissonance and Spec Ops: The Line makes you take a nosedive into a sea of that feeling. It shows war as what it is. Not as the glorified, heroic, romanticized ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t that we get stuffed with from games like Call of Duty and Battlefield, but as horror, pure, unfiltered horror. If you felt like the moral choices in games like Fallout punched you in the gut, what you'll have to do in Spec Ops will leave you feel like the game punched you in the face, wrenched open your jaw, reached down your throat and ripped out your guts.Spec Ops makes the player feel what the main character is going through, but not simply via making you identify with the character you play. Its gameplay, world design and everything makes you feel uncomfortable, nauseous and morally torn apart. It really is brilliantly crafted.I'll stop here to avoid possible spoilers or how you perceive the game while playing, but if you feel like dropping the game after playing for an hour because the combat feels generic and/or bad, please, please don't do that and press on, it's well worth it.There's one last thing I'll say, if you decide to play it: When you hear the line "Because you wanted to be something you're not.", that's aimed at you, not the character you're playing.

content:
Posted: July 25, 2015
												Spec Ops: The Line, is not really a fun and enjoyable game at its core, which is why it's so interesting, especially as just one (pretty short campaign with not very much multiplayer) shooter in a world where shooters are released en masse. Mechanically speaking, Spec Ops is a pretty standard third person shooter - two weapons at any one time , three throwables, and a selection of alternate weapon options with a comparatively smooth cover system. I did not really like the inability to aim and fire while sprinting, but that's a bit of a minor issue that I feel can be overlooked.The graphics are reasonably good, especially for a game released in 2012. The background and setting is particularly well done, well able to convey a sense of a city tearing itself apart, and also the issues that have arisen from a city cut off from the rest of the world. It is a pretty brutal Dubai that you find yourself in, and the game conveys the sense of horror that has descended on the city very well.The soundtrack is fantastic. Both it, and the storyline, short it may be, are probably the standout features of the game for me. Evoking imagery of Apocalypse Now, Spec Ops: The Line shows just how nightmarish and hellish war really is, apart from the glorified imagery that certain media has portrayed it as. Offering a look at the damage that can be done to a soldier's psyche from tours of duty, it also offers a look at the chain of command, something that is explored comparatively rarely. Offering questions regarding morality and cause and effect, while short, Spec Ops: The Line is well worth playing through.

content:
Posted: September 27, 2014
A masterpiece in DubaiHere it starts. Finally I completed this game third time (2 times like not license version and one more time here) and I can say with full confidence -  it is the best shooter I've ever played. But let me tell you more closely why I think so.Graphic. In this game, you might find one of the best images in all shooters. Since the beginning you will be amazed by the fantastic scenery of the desert ... detailed characters, weapons, and equipment. Due to the game engine Unreal Engine 3 you'll subjugated by landscapes in this game .. it's just something incredible (for 2012).Gameplay. The gameplay is also at a very high level. I can say with full confidence that it is much better than in CoD or Battlefield (yes, I played all these games). Every movement, every jump clearly and realistically worked out. To stay alive you need as quickly as possible to cross from one shelter to another, 'cause here you can be killed by EVERY bullet. Here is a great combat system and a large selection of weapons. You can kill your enemy with machine guns, pistols, shotguns, grenade launchers, different types of grenades. You can kill with his bare hands (it looks fantastic, and not just waving a knife as in CoD)! Or even just to fill their enemies great bunch of sand, which almost break out the windows or rooftops.Story. Apparently, I have not enough words to describe it. For me - this is the best story that I have experienced in the game world. This story, the story of three brave friends deserves an Oscar! Welcome to Dubai, paradise on earth, which turned into hell! First, we have an intriguing start that somehow draws you and you want to know more... During the game events are fantastic, I will not spoiling, but the game has a heap of points that can cause you to fear and even tears. As for the end of the game ... I am quite sure that by the end of the game you will overfill different feelings... There are several different endings, and you have to make it for your own choice .. no matter how difficult it will be... This story impressed me to the core. And I really happy that I passed this way together with Delta team - Captain Walker, Lieutenant Adams and Sergeant Lugo.I can talk for a long time about this game. Because for me it's really clever game that I'll always want to play. I want to say thanks studio Yager that they gave me this small miracle. I am so depressed that many players don't pay attention to this really fantastic game and continue to play CoD and Battlefield which  just turned into a boring conveyor.Thank you for reading my own point of view.Definitely 10/10
