content:
Posted: June 24, 2016
												I can hardly begin this review. I devoured this game in one sitting which does not happen often for me, so that is a start.If you like war games and shooters, you need to play this game. Not because the action is intense and brutal (which it is), but because the story is intense and brutal.	 Never in a game before had I felt the atrocities of war so acutely. This game made me not only realize how horrible we can be, but how EASILY we can slip into hell, especially on a battlefield. That type of statement pulled off in a game that was fun to play is in my mind a genre changer. God help other military shooters for what they will have to do to keep up with this. I have a few gripes about the game, they are not small, but they are demonstrably overshadowed by the storytelling.  The cover system sometimes is very inadequate, you step away from walls you did not mean to and get shot in the face. And sometimes you cover to walls you did not mean to and expose yourself in that way too. I feel they could have made the order system better as well as you have no control over where your team members go, just what targets they kill, and if you are lucky enough to get the prompt, who gets a flashbang before getting gunned down. The order system does have the benefit of being simple and therefore keeping you focused on the pace of the story, but this gets countered a bit in a few sections where your friendly AI gets killed by running ahead of you and into the open.   You do have to save them which puts you in terrible spots. I can only think of 2 spots this happened to me more than once, so it’s not that big of a deal. What is a bigger deal is that towards the end of the game the checkpoint saves get ludicrously far apart in my opinion. I would have to play one section over and over, just because the guy (a very heavy trooper) at the end of the section what giving me issues. In another section, the same sort of thing happened but I had next to no ammo when it put me at the checkpoint (I was not low on ammo when it saved)…that was a bit of a drag. ALL of that said, on a scale of one to ten the game would be in the high 9s no problem for how well done everything else was done. Buy this game, play this game…but by something happy for yourself too. You are going to need it after the war.

content:
Posted: January 2, 2016
												Spec Ops: The Line. From all the praise, I was expecting something unique and different. I can't say I got any of that.Good things first. The setting. Sandstorm weathered Dubai is something truly unique, I can give it that. Skyscrapers buried in sand with the constant threat of storms where civilians and armed forces try to survive is absolutely fresh. The strong glaring sun and bloom, although most of the time very distracting, added to the hot weather feel.Voice acting was quite nice. Felt pretty good to listen to although some lines were really awkward but that's just the script.Sand worked quite nicely as a mechanic also, although it kinda died off the further I went on in the game.Well, the bad things. Let's start with the big praised and awarded morale. Did the game make me feel like a hero? No. Did the game make me feel bad? No. Why? I was wondering, why would it? I was stuck on rails. I went on how the game wanted me to go and suddenly what I did was wrong in the end. But I didn't have much of a choice. It was like reading a book. There was only one outcome. There were a couple choices to be made but I felt like they didn't make much difference. I picked one option and I was told, "Well, that's how things go". There are three different endings but I'll just say nothing you do between start and end matters. I couldn't feel bad for "Wakuhs's" (player character) choices because I couldn't affect his larger choices and I couldn't relate on him at all.Maybe I was supposed to feel sorry for the characters but the thing was that my squad was "The Bro Delta Squad" kind. I didn't like the fact that I was a superior and my squad could just act like brats because we were such bros. It made me feel annoyed and I wanted to personally end my squad mates. So whatever quarrel we had made me want to slide under the table in shame. The civilians were angry for a good reason but they felt like complete idiots. Our objective at one point was to issue an evacuation order but I felt like I might have missed something. Why haven't the civilians left? That makes them stupid, except the sandstorm keeps them there. So they can't really leave. So why are we trying to tell them to leave in the first place? That makes us stupid. If our solution was to round up some nice vehicles and then escort them but no. Our plan was just to tell them to leave. Tell a bunch of angry mindless civilians to march into their doom.Gameplay. Clunky, sticky, unresponsive at times. Aiming and shooting was plausible. Running and using cover, awful. Spec Ops: The Line falls under the category of games that handles most things with just one key. Running and taking cover happens from space. However, other things such as vaulting happened from shift. It just didn't feel natural. I felt like cover related actions should've been in one button and movement related in another. On top of it all, my character didn't feel like staying in cover sometimes. He would just pop his head out and refused to take cover. Firefights felt like a chore because the enemy threw grenades with pinpoint accuracy constantly. There were times when they threw grenades through my cover as well. So I couldn't stay in the cover for more than a second or two. I had to retreat away from the fight because I was pretty much as far as I could be from the enemies. Once I returned to the cover, another grenade was lobbed at me. Not really fun. A cover shooter that punishes you for using cover?tl;drPretty average cover TPS. Morality executed poorly. Clunky controls. Nice story, voice acting and visuals though. Not a super long game. If you enjoy a good story, get it. If you favor gameplay, don't get it.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 27, 2016
Spec Ops: The line is a third-person shooter, with a strong storyline that's worth of Hollywood attention. However, that's not where the game really shines.You have to be a fan of action games to truly appreciate Spec Ops: The line, and if you played on FUBAR difficulty, you know what I mean. The developers made sure everyone could enjoy it, but once you play on the hardest difficulty, small details start to make even more sense.The aiming, the blind-fire, the cover locations, the level's details on positions and even diversity make this one of my favorite action games.Adams and Lugo team up with our main character to take Dubai to its righteous path, under heavy fire from the rebels, U.S troops and even private military. Although there is no online co-op, the campaign is pretty much intensive. But if that's not good enough, then killing heavies on the hardest difficulty will make you feel happy!The design team worked extensively to make sure this wouldn't be forgotten, and they nail'd it. Dubai under a crisis is perfect, with the sunsets far away on the horizon... The afternoon desert storms, the despair reflected in the abandoned luxury cars... A city in despair, and with a backstory to make you go wild.In Spec Ops: The line you make decisions that don't really matter, but they tried it, and that's halfway through. Speaking of things that could be better, we also have the stealth, that could have been away more improved, but still... Playing an extreme action game, would you go quiet? :)I really love this game, I love how tough it is, and how well it works under pressure! Of course we all hate when our teammates die because of the stupid AI, but they have a pace of movement, and I learn it while playing on FUBAR. Once I did, I start having so much fun.If is there any negative feelings, they are towards some areas, where playing on the hardest difficulty, become annoying. Two in particular; Last part on the Chapter 6 "The Pit", where the player needs to escape, and the entire thing is based on luck. No skill, no strategy, nothing. Just luck.The other is the famous last part in Chapter 10, where protecting the water truck can be awful due to the lack of checkpoints.I wish everyone could have the same excitement I had with this game, and either if you're playing for the story line, or for some extreme action I highly recommend that you try it.One of my favorite War Games!8/10

content:
Posted: January 5, 2014
												Bottom line, I recommend this game.  If you like shooters, can stomach some very dark content, and want to play something a little bit different... this may be the game for you.I am reviewing this as a single player title.  I have no interest in the multiplayer content, and have not tried it to provide feedback on it.Before the good, I need to be clear on something many might view as bad.  I finished this game in one sitting last night of about six hours.  Some people hate short games, but this game is surprisingly deep, keeps you wanting to stay and play more, and I already am thinking about playing through again as its obvious there are different ending possibilities.  I view the shortness of this game as the one standout thing against it.Moving on though... there was a lot I liked.This game is about people who are in very dark situations, confronted by nothing but dark and challenging choices.  You are not either saving the damsel, or killing her dog.  I once read a review that seemed intriguing.  It said that once you realize whats going on you will be hooked and want to see the rest of the game through.  I got there.  I was hooked.  I had to see how it ends.The gameplay was good, and by the time I realized why -- I was actually surprised.  Too many games have cover systems that aren't necessary.  Enemies that could fire 1000 bullets and maybe hit your water canteen once.  Etc...   Spec Ops:  The Line is not such a cake walk.  The enemies can hit you accurately, and they will.  Your AI team mates will be a necessity, but they will also be vulnerable.  There are times where you will run out of ammo and even if you don't like this gun or that based on your own style... you will think its a god send to have a way to fight off the enemy, and play accordingly.  I found myself using cover at every possible avenue.  Grenades were not an afterthought.  It was FUN.I've played numerous shooters dating back to Wolfenstein 3D and Duke Nukem.  I've played Medal of Honor, Call of Duty, Battlefield, Halo, and more.  I have to say this game really felt different and drew me in how many AAA games have.When everything was said and done, it was the story and presentation that blew my mind.  Mature modern story in a believable setting.Random number score system? 9/10.  I was that impressed.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 29, 2015
												Spec Ops: The Line looks a lot like the typical modern third person action shooter on the outside. The gameplay is merely servicable, functional and mediocre.But it's the basic concept of this game that actually makes this really fantastic in some ways that couldn't be described without spoiling your experience. The game takes a look at the typical war setting and portrays it in such an emotional way. It's deliberately mundane and that's partially why it has a ton of depth and really makes you consider everything that occurs. It's a 100% feels trip. You just simply wont play a shooter that is as story rich as The Line.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 16, 2014
												Spec Ops: The Line is a basic 3rd person shooter with a great and impacting story.The gameplay is pretty much your standard 3PP game. However it can be very challenging if you're not careful. You don't feel like the Terminator pushing through pumping bullets into meatbags. You have to have somewhat of a strategy as you move about the levels.The best thing about the game itself though, is the story. From the time your boots on the ground in Dubai to the heartstring pulling choices to the compelling end you will stay hooked. The scenery is also great in this game. While obviously not boasting some of the best graphics, it holds it's own against other games of the genre.I highly recommend this game, expecially if you can catch it on sale.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 13, 2015
												If you enjoy third person shooters, you have reason enough to play this game. If you appreciate a story that tries and succeeds in being a truly unique experience, you will be in love with this game. The amazing voice acting from Nolan North puts you in the blood-soaked boots of Cpt. Martin Walker, and the story will have you questioning what makes a hero. Spec Ops doesn't use experience or skill unlocks to simulate progression in the game, but rather utilizes an ever increasing amount of violence and difficulty. The combat will keep pushing you, and also rewarding you, in a subtle way that doesn't make the player feel stupid like many other shooters have a tendency of doing. In my opinion, this game is one of a kind.So.What are you waiting for? Dubai needs to be saved.

content:
Posted: July 21, 2015
												While this game might seem like a normal military fps, it isn't. This is another game made by 2K https://www.2k.com/games . It's interesting to note how many of the games are made by 2k when we asked the various gaming groups to nominate games with the best story. This particular one entitled 'Spec Ops: The line' is actually the 8th one in this particular series though it shares nothing in common with its former installments of the games with the same namesake.(Spoiler Alert)The story basically follows a soldiers personal journey through limbo. You take control of a captain Walker who is in charge of a 2 man delta squad. The three of them are on a rescue mission to find the 33rd battalion and their captain Konrad who is someone considered to be of noble rank since he saved your life in a previous battle.Dubai has become somewhat apocalyptic thanks to huge never ending sandstorms requiring that the whole city to be evacuated. The politicians and the elite downplayed the situation while at the same time evacuating it themselves in secret leaving countless thousands of refugees behind. The 33rd battalion coming home from a war in Afghanistan volunteered their services to help with the relief efforts.The United States government however ordered the 33rd to abandon the city and its refugees, but the 33rd led by Captain Konrad ignored the command and insisted upon their wishes of leading a caravan of 1,000 people out of the city. However the sandstorms grew worse and the caravan promised never arrived at the proposed time given. Future communication and travelling was severed and the 33rd was publicly disavowed for treason.After significant time a looped radio signal could be heard coming from the city again. It was a brief one from Captain Konrad. It basically stated that the attempted evacuation was a complete failure and the death toll was too many. The US military then decide to send a covert 3 man delta team in to locate any survivors and then radio for extraction.Problem is as you guide this 3 man crew into Dubai, things begin to seriously not add up. The refugees are trying to kill you, the 33rd battalion wants to kill you and so does the CIA operatives. As you begin to hallucinate voices and visions, you also begin to witness some atrocities that each splintering faction of the city has done to each other. The game unfortunately forces you to make some of those atrocities yourself in order to push on and find answers and hopefully in the vain attempt to nobly save someone. Somewhere at the end of the game you will be haunted by the dead faces of those that you have killed asking you why you committed such acts and for what purpose? Eventually you will realize that your character is suffering with severe effects of PTSD.There are 18 campaign chapters to play through with a somewhat highly decorated abstract version of Dubai buried in the sand. These chapters are spasmodically broken up with several morale choices placed throughout the game. The importance of these morale choices and the effects they will have on the game are purely there for illusion. None of your choices will really matter. No matter what you choose or how you go about things your character will be haunted by the people he has killed. There is no pleasant way out of this. The game literally forces you to make a decision which unknowingly at the time will kill thousands. It will then show you the consequence of that decision regardless of the fact that you had no choice about it and it will ask you why did you do it?Here's where the nobility of the story fails immensely and does not have the same power or punch to a story where your choice really does matter. Any morale judgments are quickly dismissed under a rigged gaming framework. While it does get you to think about things and it has moved and inspired countless people to think about the consequence of actions, I personally think it could have been delivered better to make more of an impact on gamer's than what it already has.Definitely worth a look...

content:
Posted: March 12, 2015
-Quick Review-Spec Ops: The Line is a third person shooter who takes a warfare story telling aspect, and mixes in gritty realism, coupled with very solid cover-based-game play.-Detailed breakdown review-Story:  How do you talk about the story in this game without giving away any great details? The story goes in a very unorthodox direction from most Shooter games I've played. Additionally there are choices that you make throughout the game, and it's not just "go right or go left" as the saying goes "indecision is a choice".In the words of William T. Sherman we hear the well known quote "War is Hell" To be quite honest not very many shooter games run with that concept, in Spec Ops: The Line, you will see far more gritty details of consequences of warfare... and the people effected.As a final note regarding the story length, I after playing through the game my first time I put in 5.5 hours. I generally play slower trying to find extra items and do restarts for achievements, so that should be longer then a standard player will take to get through the game.Game Play: Spec Ops: the line is a cover-based third person shooter, meaning while you're being shot at you will move from cover to cover, most of the mechanics are quite straight forward, but do take some getting used too, you can jump over cover, change cover quickly by looking or pressing a movement key in that direction THEN pressing Space, there is a fair bit of learning to be had.It should be noted that the controls will take some getting used too, I had already played a few third person shooters so those old controls were messing me up while I was trying to learn the new ones. Once you learn the controls the rest of the game is quite enjoyable to play through.Even if you're unfamiliar with cover-based-shooters the starting difficulty is friendly enough that you can get the hang of it while gunning down your foes. (I would still recommend getting used to hiding behind cover)Achievements: There are 50 Achievements in Spec Ops: The Line, after my first play through I had 33 of those achievements, there are four achievement category types: Find the lintel (collection), Get kills or special kills with weapons, Make this choice in the story, and standard story quests.Price Spec Ops: The Line is priced at $29.99, by this point most people should be used to games (especially shooters) being priced there, as I always say "I recommend waiting for a sale". Conclusion: Spec Ops: The line will appeal most to people who enjoy the two qualities of "Third person shooter", and "story telling". If you just want a shooter where you run in and pew pew pew, this isn't the right game for you. If you like playing games with meaningful stories, making hard ethical decisions while gaming or just looking for a change of pace this game will provide it.To quickly recap: Story - Outstanding story telling methods. Game Play - Controls might be a bit tricky at first, but the cover based combat is very good. Achievements - Pretty Standard, there are a few tricky looking achievements though. Price - Standard, wait for a sale.

												This game was the biggest emotional ride ive ever taken in a videogame. The stereotypical gravely voiced protagonist made me actually care about him by actually questioning his actions. Most games dont show the emotions for all the people who are slaughtering (instert american enemy here). This game showed some of the true horrors of war and i love it for that. Be prepared to feel like you had just been punched in the face by the ending. I do wish it was longer than 7 hours tho.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 22, 2016
												I bought this game, not really knowing what to expect. I had heard it was good and it was on sale so I though "why not?".Starting playing it and seemed like a typical FPS war game. The further I got into the game, the more it started to...eat away at me.The decisions that I made. I though that what I was doing was for good. To save people. The further I progressed, the more I started to doubt my decisions and my morals. Was I really saving people? Was I really doing this for good? Or was I doing it for myself?I completed the game and decided to have a 2nd play through to see if my actions and decisions would have a better impact. Now I completed the game twice and I feel an emptiness inside of me. A void which I have trouble dealing with. I lie awake at night thinking about what I had done. How can I save people when I cant save myself?The horror....the horror....

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 5, 2014
												I've played this on a console before and it is safe to say this is one of the best shooter of this generation.Spec Ops does not reinvent the wheel in any way with its mechanics or graphic engine nor brings up action sequences never seen before in the history of gaming and the gameplay is pretty much your usual shooter. The controls are good, the graphics too, but it does nothing different tech-wise from other action games, really. So how can I think so highly of such a "generic" game?Well, there the game's plot. It is a reimagination of Josephs Conrad's 1899 short novel "Heart of Darkness". Don't worry, I won't spoil anything. While the game kicks of as a standard "military squad vs the world" thing as the game progresses it gets darker and darker and what appeared to be just a commom history turns into a very deep critique of violence, human mental health and even the own game industry tendencies, some might say. Well, there's TONS of articles out there the discuss the importance of this game's plot, but you'll have to play first.TL;DR: the game "disguises" itself as a generic game (and in its mechanics, it really is) but there is so much subliminar stuff going on in this plot that turns Spec Ops in one bizarre phenomenon of the game industry. I dropped the game a few times because he was just "OK" but I'm glad one day I had the motivation to finish. It really is worth it if you're into good stories and some grim♥♥♥♥♥♥

content:
Posted: August 26, 2015
												I really liked the singleplayer experience. Good story, and the voice acting was also spot on.SPOILERS BEYOND THIS POINT!This game will make you feel bad, really bad. Seriously. As you progress you will eventually (if you live into the game as i did) realize that you are the bad guy here. Especially at the part where those civilians killed off Lugo, i felt anger and wanted to end every single life of those ♥♥♥♥ers. You believe along the whole game that you are doing all this for the greater good.. but in the end, you were so focused on taking Konrad down that you completely derail from your original objective and that eventually lead you to your own downfall.Can't say the same for the multiplayer part, it feels like a degraded dull third person edition of Call of Duty with a touch of sandstorms. If you are in cover and a grenade lands in front of you.. you are ♥♥♥♥ed, no time to run away and i feel (my opinion) that the cover system is bugged. To be honest, it feels like it doesn't even belong here and was just added for the sake of "we need people to come back to our game" but fail miserably. I played a couple of hours just to get a hang of the multiplayer i got to rank 10 or so.. Absolutely garbage. Also, if you hope to find alot of multiplayer action, you will be disappointed. There's almost nobody playing it anymore and finding servers will take alot of time.But i will recommend the game anyway for the amazing singleplayer experience!

The further I progressed, the more I started to doubt my decisions and my morals. Was I really saving people? Was I really doing this for good? Or was I doing it for myself?I completed the game and decided to have a 2nd play through to see if my actions and decisions would have a better impact. Now I completed the game twice and I feel an emptiness inside of me. A void which I have trouble dealing with. I lie awake at night thinking about what I had done. How can I save people when I cant save myself?The horror....the horror....

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 27
												I appreciate Spec Ops: The Line for being one of those rare games that actually tries to make you actually think about and feel bad for killing people. It's a bit more heavy-handed than other games that also try to make you feel for those you are killing (for example, the original Deus Ex, and This War of Mine), but the heavy-handedness and extreme situations you are in where you do extreme things seems to be one of the main focuses of the game. The setting is interesting: Dubai after it has been ravaged and isolated by lethal freak sandstorms. The gameplay is that of a typical 3rd person cover-based shooter, but the dialogue and in-game choices make you think more about what you are doing, and the overall story and relatively mature treatment of killing compared to other military shooters definitely make the game worth playing if you are familiar with the genre.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 5, 2014
												I've played this on a console before and it is safe to say this is one of the best shooter of this generation.Spec Ops does not reinvent the wheel in any way with its mechanics or graphic engine nor brings up action sequences never seen before in the history of gaming and the gameplay is pretty much your usual shooter. The controls are good, the graphics too, but it does nothing different tech-wise from other action games, really. So how can I think so highly of such a "generic" game?Well, there the game's plot. It is a reimagination of Josephs Conrad's 1899 short novel "Heart of Darkness". Don't worry, I won't spoil anything. While the game kicks of as a standard "military squad vs the world" thing as the game progresses it gets darker and darker and what appeared to be just a commom history turns into a very deep critique of violence, human mental health and even the own game industry tendencies, some might say. Well, there's TONS of articles out there the discuss the importance of this game's plot, but you'll have to play first.TL;DR: the game "disguises" itself as a generic game (and in its mechanics, it really is) but there is so much subliminar stuff going on in this plot that turns Spec Ops in one bizarre phenomenon of the game industry. I dropped the game a few times because he was just "OK" but I'm glad one day I had the motivation to finish. It really is worth it if you're into good stories and some grim♥♥♥♥♥♥

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 23
												Spec Ops: The Line is a decent third person action shooter with an amazing single player campaign story! You play as captain walker, a delta squad leader who thinks that he is helping the survivors in dubai with his actions but not everything is as it seems... During several moments in the campaign, you are given moral choices and what you choose would affect the narrative of the story in a small extent. There are also plot twists in the story which might surprise you and would also entice you to play more to find out more of the story.The gunplay is pretty standard but decent. It is basically a cover based third person shooter with a good variety of guns. The game is also really challenging on a higher difficulty as you can die in around two shots and that would encourage you to make use of the cover system more if you do not want to die. The character models looks really dated at the time of this review, however the environment (e.g Buildings, shops, desert, etc ) looks really detailed and beautiful.The multiplayer and co-op of this game is basically dead at the point of this review as I could not find anyone in matchmaking. However, you can still play the co-op mode alone or with a friend. There are only 4 missions in the co-op mode and they are really short and is also not replayable as the same mission would play out the same way everytime.In conclusion, the single player campaign has a great story with a serviceable third person shooter gunplay mechanic. The multiplayer and co-op matchmaking are dead and not worth checking out. If I were to rate this game, I would give it a 6/10!

												Underated game. Glad i picked this up. At first glance it looks like any other 'pew pew murica to the rescue' sort of shooter but it goes far beyond that. Gameplay seems pretty generic but the battles are quite fast paced and action packed. The environment is really cool. Fighting amongst a city swallowed by sand is defs one the games coolest features.Now for the games winning feature..the story.Words dont do it justice. The story sheds light on the side of warfare that is not often seen. It brings forward the harsh realities of warfare, how it changes people, that sometimes there are are no right choices. The game forces you to make choices that are definetely not easy to make and you will hate yourself for making them. Give this a playthrough if you see this on sale. It will seriously suprise you.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 23, 2014
												This is a truthful, heartfelt and deeply grim perspective of war. As close as we gamers will ever get to the real feel of what it is like. The real depth and weight of our actions.For years we have been desensitized to violence. To be taught it's kill or be killed - and the more gratuitous the kill the better the gameplay is. We never truly feel the weight of the kills we so effortlessly dish out to anyone who dare stand opposite of us. We're just trying to get from point A to point B and kill as many as possible.Spec Ops: The Line changes the formula of traditional military shooters really making your decisions resonate with you. Making you thoroughly evaluate your moral scale and the horrific decisions you will have to face during war.Absolutely outstanding, it made me feel like a monster when I was fighting for my life.Highly, highly recommended.10/10

												Any attempt to describe this game is futile - to truly grasp what it has to say, you just have to experience it. It's almost more an interactive piece of artwork (not in the sense that it's aesthetically pleasing, but in the sense that it challenges your preconceptions and forces you to view something in a new light) than a game.   Overall, playing SO:TL is a rather unpleasant experience, but if you step across the line you'll be rewarded with a thought-provoking meta-commentary on the shooter genre, choice in games, and the act of gaming itself.

												There's not much to tell about this shooter gameplaywise: an intense shoot'n'roll with dumb team AI. However, all this is tolerable.As for the story, I can't remember any other action game that carried such a strong anti-war message. The closest thing that comes to my mind is not even a game, but a movie "Apocalypse Now". The protagonist descends into his own world of madness. Through his eyes you will see the real side of the war: not the heroic propaganda ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t, but despicable, unimaginable scenes you wish you'd never seen.Spec Ops: The Line does a 100% fine job of making you remember that while you live your comfy life, somewhere in the world there's war going on. And it's nothing but horror.

content:
Posted: December 25, 2014
												I've had this game for a while now and have just got to playing it, and I have to ask myself: Why have I not played this sooner?Without spoiling anything, the story and plot are completely beautiful and heartwrenching, on the edge of your seat surprising, and will completely question your morales and those of the characters you interact and meet. I jumped in expecting another mindless shooter with loose story, but found myself in love with this game and its story.On the technical aspect, the gameplay is relatively simple and easy. Suicide difficulty is not incredibly challenging, but a large factor of combat is to utilise your Delta squad and hide behind cover. The game can be completed in under 7 hours, probably less, which seems perfect as the story isn't drawn on and combat seems fast enough behind cover that you aren't getting entirely bored. Graphically, I am also surprised at how beautiful this game can look. Your Delta squad continues to degrade and gain battle scars, blood, and torn clothing as the game progresses and otherwise looks like days of fighting in Dubai. The scenery and city looks amazing as well! I play with a GIGABYTE P35K-1 with nVidia GTX 765m and ran everything to the max and had no flops.Story: 10/10Gameplay: 6/10Graphics: 9/10Strength of Denial: 100/10

												What can be said about Spec Ops The Line? This is a tough one. I mean it is a ♥♥♥♥ing cool game, but the emotions it gives you can really be tough to deal with. Games with  Stories like this should be in every gamers library and every gamer and non gamer should experience a story like this.  We hold for granted what war is actually like. We go around blowing♥♥♥♥♥♥up and blasting the ♥♥♥♥ out of whatever moves without any ideas to the reality, the actual truth of war. I recognize first hand what war can do to somebody. I know the mind can become damaged with PTSD. My father is a Vietnam veteran and is  100% disabled with PTSD. He has been suffering all his life and will for the remainder of his lifetime. We don't understand the horrors and choices of war if we have never experienced them for ourselves. Well, this game brings out some of those feelings and choices that War can bring people to. What is right or what is wrong? Who is bad and who is good? What must we do to survive?  The game play is not the greatest cutting edge style.. You may get♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥off at your NPCs or at the controls of your character, but the story and really nice visuals will overpower these flaws. Don't get me wrong the gameplay is fun. I truly love playing cover style shooters. They just seem more real to me because if you're in a fire fight the first thing you're going to do is jump behind whatever you can. The cover system does have its flaws, but nothing that ruins the fun.  If you want a game that is not your typical shooter a game that really gives you tough choices you should play this game..This game is the chronic♥♥♥♥♥♥

number of helpful: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 22, 2014
												Spec Ops: The Line is the hidden gem of 2012. FTL would be my "hidden gem," but after the whole massive Kickstarter success thing, it was obvious FTL was going to be good in my point of view. Honestly, I used to play Call of Duty and Halo. There. I said it. However, after Black Ops 1, I quit the Call of Duty series and haven't played any of the games since MW3. Halo Reach was the Halo that I played the most, and was the only Halo game (Halo 3 and Wars were good though) that I loved and played often. However, above all of these games, Spec Ops: The Line has one of the best stories of all time. It isn't like Call of Duty how you're fighting as some American soldier running around solo armed to the teeth with weapons and murdering terrorists and in the end "saving the world." Not at all. Some people believe there are "good guys" and "bad guys," but this game is solid evidence that war is just opinions being decided to the death, sometimes costing one's sanity, social health, emotional health, and physical health. Spec Ops: The Line proves war in no way is enjoyable, cool, or humorous in any kind of way. War is horrific, and this game is enough to prove that.GraphicsThe visuals are absolutely outstanding. The environments look beautiful, and the atmosphere is bright on the outside, but dark and horrific on the inside. The characters look amazing, and it's rare you can actually see the sweat of a character in the middle of combat. This game is able to do that. If I were to compare these visuals to The Last of Us, Spec Ops: The Line would win by a mile. These graphics are extremely realistic, but the only con to this is that the facial animations can look weird. For example, when Walker is talking to Lugo or Adams when it isn't a cutscene, it looks like he's gaping every time, like he's shocked at everything for some reason. During cutscenes though, Walker looks fine and doesn't gape like that when he speaks.GameplayThe gameplay is suprisingly the weak point to the game. Although this game is a shooter, Spec Ops is more for people who want a story based game, rather than a gameplay based one. The AI is suicidally bad and the difficulty spikes at times and the awful gunplay ruins it even more. My squadmates keep bumping into me and I die, one enemy shot 3 RPG rockets in a row without reloading for some reason (He had an RPG, I saw him with the weapon, I swear!) and the AI prefer running toward me like overconfident barbarians. However, the game understands the meaning of "limited" unlike other games *cough* Call of Duty *cough* *cough* and makes ammo a bit more difficult to get, so that's something few games did that aren't in the zombie survival genre. StoryThe story is the reason Spec Ops is highly praised. Like I said before, it proves that war is a terrible thing and (quoted from Fallout 3) "never changes." Lugo, Adams, and Walker's bond with each other was strong, like they were old friends, then all of a sudden, Lugo and Adams part away from Walker, realizing that he's gone insane, but Adams is still merely following orders, while Lugo wants to make a stand. You realize that Walker is in no way a hero, but calling him a villain is illogical. The plot twist around the midst of the game was amazing and blew my mind. I'm going to do another quote, but this time from one of my favorite songs: "This ain't no place for no hero, this ain't no place for no- better man, this ain't no place for no hero, to call home." -"Short Change Hero" by The Heavy. It perfectly describes the story, mixed with the atmosphere, and how the characters develop over time in the destroyed and now insane city of Dubai. I assure you, this game has one of the finest stories in gaming. It seems like 2012 was the year for gaming, since games like this and The Walking Dead came out and wowed us with their storytelling. In the end, the story for this game is simply outstanding.AudioThe audio is also amazing for this game. The voice actors did an amazing job with their roles, and all showed personality. They  weren't androids and were kind of like the Mass Effect characters, in a way you grow attached to them because they feel like real, breathing humans. But you still gotta hate Walker. Then, hate yourself while you're at it for doing all the harsh decisions. Name me a few other games that truly make you want to hate yourself that much. The music is similar to those found in a zombie apocalypse game, like the recent ones State of Decay and The Last of Us. It's usually a guitar backed up by a few other instruments or the guitar playing solo. It sounds beautiful and fits in perfectly. The audio in this game is some of the finest in recent gaming.ReplayabilityIt's a bit more difficult to provide replayability to a game like this, unfortunately. However, you could go back and get all the endings. The multiplayer is pretty dead, so I haven't had any chance to try it yet. Either way, I suppose the replayability in this game is determinant. VerdictIn conclusion, Spec Ops: The Line proves war is terrifying and that it's not fun at all. However, the horrible gameplay holds it down significantly, along with a dead multiplayer and the jaw drops that happen when Walker talks while playing (Not in a cutscene) hold it back. Either way, Spec Ops: The Line is a must have for any story based game buyer. I highly recommend this gem.Graphics- 9.5/10Gameplay- 4/10Story- 10/10Audio- 10/10Replayability- 5.5/10.:8.2/10:.+Pheonominal story+Outstanding visuals+Developed characters+Top notch voice acting+Amazing music-Dead Multiplayer mode-Horrible gameplay-Walker frequently gaping

content:
Posted: January 27, 2015
												Spec Ops: The Line it's a third person shooter released in 2012 by 2k Games. It looks really generic and for absolutely sure I can tell you that there's nothing generic about this game.Yeah the gameplay it's not something out of the box, but it's well crafted, a lot of weapon diversity, online cooperative and also a bunch of achievements to go for.But the point here it's the story, the details of it that makes this game so enjoyable. You're Cpt. Walker, accompained by Lt. Adams and Ssgt. Lugo, you three are sent as a three-man Delta Force team to carry out reconnaissance.You will really get into it and will question every decision that you and your fellas make. In fact your decisions impact the ending of the game. I won't spoil anything, but for sure it's not easy to be a hero.Spec Ops shows what many shooters can't achieve: a great story combined with a well crafted gameplay.Gentlemen, welcome to Dubai.

content:
Posted: June 24, 2014
												“It takes a strong man to deny what's right in front of him.”Spec Ops: The Line is the prime example of how you should never judge a book by it’s cover. The first thought anyone had when they first saw this game is that is a bland simple modern military shooter.Spec Ops: The Line provided one of the most amazing story experiences I’ve ever had from a shooter, proving that not all of them have to be bland stories.This has to be one of the only games that have actually made me feel bad for doing what I’ve done. Things the game told me to do. I had to do these horrible things, murdering people to progress with the story, but was it the right thing? Was it better I not play in the first place?This feeling is resonated in the protagonist own character arch, did Walker have a choice to do what he did? Was it truly his fault? Who should pay for his crimes?The game-play is average, the shooting is fun and challenging at points, and you certainly won’t be bored. There is also an additional option to command your squad mates to shoot certain “enemies” and help heal other. It’s simple and it works. I feel as though the game is making a even further point with it's game-play. It’s fairly mundane, making the whole point of the story even more profound. You went through the whole game mindlessly killing people without a second thought.If you're looking for a good story and don't mind the typical shooter gameplay, pick it up.

												I AM NOW COMPROMISED. THE DETAILS WOULD ONLY SCAR YOU. ALL I HAD TO DO WAS WALK AWAY, NEVER WAS THE EXIT CLOSED, BUT GOD HELP ME, I WANTED TO SEE WHAT WOULD HAPPEN. THE KNOWLEDGE HAS COME TO CONSUME ME. WHAT OTHER EVILS HAVE I BORNE ALOFT PURELY FROM AN UNQUESTIONED DESIRE TO "SEE THINGS THROUGH"? WHAT ELSE HAVE I BLINDLY JUSTIFIED? THIS IS THE LAST SORRY DISPATCH OF A RUINED SOUL. LET MY CARCASS BE A SCARECROW. LET IT WARN OTHERS THAT THESE FIELDS ARE FALLOW, THAT ONLY A DEAFENING BLEAKNESS GROWS HERE. THAT THIS IS THE LAND OF THE EMPTY, WHERE THOSE WHO ASSUMED GLORY WAS THEIR BIRTHRIGHT SHUFFLE FOR ETERNITY. THEIR AGONY IS SILENT, AND THEIR PHOSPHOROUS TEARS BURN, OH GOD, MOTHER, HOW THEY BURN.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 15, 2015
												I don't often go out of my way to review games. But this game? As a a gamer in the first person shooter era - and especially being an American - I feel this piece of art should be experienced unspoilt by everyone. No other game will make you feel so strongly connected to a storyline as this one will.Spec Ops the line has fairly average third person shooter mechanics. This sounds like a negative: it isn't. Why? Because Spec Ops: The Line is a commentary as much as it is a game. Since the story is what makes this game gold, I'll avoid saying too much, but the game does a good job of making the player aware of the struggles on all sides of war. On top of this, it continually references the destructive military culture of America, and questions the player whether they are truly okay with the way media treats war in general.It's all done in a way that simply poses a question : Do you feel like a hero yet?

content:
Posted: June 28, 2014
												Well... this was certainly something. Spec Ops: The Line mechanics-like is a competent shooter, even if PC port is a bit crappy. Shooting mechanics would play better with a controller, but they work just fine with mouse and keyboard. What really distinguishes this game from other shooters is the story. Don't get me wrong, it's not a really great story with powerful characters. What this game does is... it shows the war. And it shows how morality gradually ceases to exist in a combat zone. It has some really powerful images, and is quite unforgiving showing them. It plays well, and I recommend it for everyone who still thinks that war is fun. Some images shown by this are almost too much to handle for an anverage consumer... but the game is worth playing. Okay, time to stop this blabbering and play some more stuff.

content:
Posted: March 8, 2015
												Specs Ops the Line is so much more than just a tactical shooter: it's a wonderful experience.You will find yourself in emotional situations, taking imposible decisions, regreting them every step of the way. This game is so complex it feels like a Nolan's movie at times, it even messes with you in the loading screens. The graphics are very committed to the desert feel but still manages to take your breath away at times. The music is just amazing, ranging from Hard Rock to Motown and you may feel not all this songs are fitting to a shooting game, but they are to the emotional feeling of it, which is the game's strongest point.One of the only downsides is how the difficulty scalates, I was so mindblown by this game I decided to replay it in the FUBAR difficulty, which is the hardest possible, it gets you thinking outside the box most of the time, looking for different ways to achive your objective, picking your shots carefully, but sadly at times it's just ridiculously hard with unskippable instadeath scenes that you will replay DOZENS of times to get through by sheer luck, and it feels like the game is trying to be longer in a really cheap way.Other than that this game is a jewel that deserves to be appreciated.I am yet to try the coop mode, will update this review when I do.

content:
Posted: October 9, 2012
												You know, I would have already recommended this game on the basis that it's a well-disguised pushback against the insane military worship present not only in video games like Call of Duty and Battlefield 3, but in American culture in general. But it's also a pushback against American imperialism, military intervention, our actions towards the Middle East, war itself, and also the player for going along with the game, no matter how insane it gets. It's a thoroughly horrifying game and I'm frankly surprised to see that it even got published at all. And the genius of it is it's like Call of Duty mixed with Gears of War, so any teenage ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ can just get sucked into it and then made completely horrified. Get it for the kids at Christmas!

												An exceptionally good game. Decent 3rdperson cover-based combat, fairly well balanced for a singleplayer shooter, but it's the story that makes it stand out. The situation it puts you in makes you question the decisions you make, try to justify things you'd otherwise think unspeakable and unforgivable. number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 16, 2014
												This is probably one of the best games I've ever played.Why?The gameplay is pretty standard fare for the shooter genre, with some somewhat interesting squad dynamics thrown in. I've heard the multiplayer is terrible, if you can find anyone still playing it at all. So why is this game so amazing? The story in the campaign. It plays on your psyche, messes with your head, and makes you question why you even play games like this. It's a critique of the entire genre, one that desperately needed to be made. Why do we, as gamers, typically like to shoot things for fun? Is killing people in a video game truly harmless? If so, should we still enjoy it as much as we do?The story draws from some classics for inspiration (most notably Heart of Darkness, by Joseph Conrad), but it takes what it needs and expands on the rest. It takes some classic conventions, and finds a way to use that to tell its own story, and tell a completely new and fresh message."To kill for yourself is murder. To kill for your government is heroic. To kill for entertainment is harmless."

content:
Posted: August 24, 2014
												The truth is, you're reading this review because you wanted to feel like something you're not... a Gamer.This game is not fun, but it is engaging. You'll feel bad. Although the mechanics and graphics feel like something from 2008, the story, emersion (or lack thereof) swath the player into examining his or her choices in a manner that most modern games simply do not.I beat the game in about 5 or 6 hours. I got it on sale for 6 bux. I recommend picking this title up on sale most certainly, but I also recommend picking this title up for a "modern warfare first person shooter" title that is anything but a modern first person warfare shooter.

content:
Posted: September 5, 2014
Para análise em português, leia mais abaixo.Spec Ops The Line - Review: Lost and DamnedDubai. An oasis of technology and lust in the middle of desert. Magnificent buildings in a developed city. But nature is always more ruthless than our ability to oppose. Destroyed by intense sandstorms, a city in ruins. The 33rd Battalion of the American army is sent to town for a rescue and extraction operation of the survivors. And then, they disappear from the map.You are Captain Martin Walker, leader of an elite team of Delta Force of the Army of the United States of America, leading his fellow Lieutenant Alphanso Adams, heavy gunner and Sergeant John Lugo, sniper. Sent to Dubai after a transmission captured after six months without contact, his mission is to locate, reunite and rescue possible survivors.Beautiful scenarios, even among ruins. The opulence of Dubai can be seen in the ruins and in few places that remained intact. Even the desert, displays an exotic beauty that brings a melancholy tone to the game.Spec Ops is not just a shooting game in third person. It is a psychological plot. Every dialogue, every action, every event in this journey shows you more than bullets flying. Dubai is alive. Dubai is at war. And war... war never changes. The horrors of war are not shown as simple digital polygons falling to the ground with AI off. You will really feel them. You will hesitate. You will have anger and and will be thrilled. And maybe you even cry. You'll be confused. Do not stop. Go straight. Reflect, try to understand. Do not come to this game to play. Come to this story to live it. And so, you will not regret it.Gentlemen, welcome to Dubai.  My Personal Score   Fun: 9/10   Gameplay: 9/10   Ambientation: 9/10   History: 10/10   Replayability: 6/10   Multiplayer: 1/10 --Spec Ops The Line - Análise: Perdidos e CondenadosDubai. Um oásis de tecnologia e luxuria em pleno deserto. Construções magníficas em uma cidade extremamente desenvolvida. Mas a natureza, é sempre mais impiedosa do que nossa capacidade de nos opor. Destruída por intensas tempestades de areia, uma cidade em ruínas. O 33º batalhão do exército americano é enviado a cidade para uma operação de resgate e extração dos sobreviventes. E então, eles desaparecem do mapa.Você é o Capitão Martin Walker, líder de uma equipe de elite da Força Delta do Exército dos Estados Unidos da América, liderando seus companheiros Tenente Alphanso Adams, artilheiro pesado e Sargento John Lugo, franco-atirador. Enviados a Dubai após uma transmissão ser captada depois de 6 meses sem contato, sua missão é localizar, reunir e resgatar possíveis sobreviventes.Belos cenários, mesmo entre ruínas. A opulência de Dubai se destaca em traços que podem ser percebidos nas ruínas e em poucos lugares sobreviventes. Mesmo o deserto, exibe uma exótica beleza que traz um tom melancólico ao jogo.Spec Ops não é apenas um jogo de tiro em terceira pessoa. É uma trama psicológica. Cada diálogo, cada ação, cada acontecimento nesta jornada te mostra mais do que balas voando. Dubai está viva. Dubai está em guerra. E a guerra... a guerra nunca muda. Os horrores da guerra não são mostrados como simples polígonos digitais caindo ao chão com IA desligada. Você realmente irá sentí-los. Você irá hesitar. Você terá raiva e se emocionará. E talvez, você até mesmo chore. Você ficará confuso. Não pare. Siga em frente. Reflita, procure compreender. Não venha a este jogo para jogar. Venha a esta história para vivê-la. E assim, você não irá se arrepender.Senhores, bem-vindos a Dubai.  Minhas Notas Pessoais   Diversão: 9/10   Gameplay: 9/10   Ambientação: 9/10   História: 10/10   Rejogabilidade: 6/10   Multiplayer: 1/10

Shooting mechanics would play better with a controller, but they work just fine with mouse and keyboard. What really distinguishes this game from other shooters is the story. Don't get me wrong, it's not a really great story with powerful characters. What this game does is... it shows the war. And it shows how morality gradually ceases to exist in a combat zone. It has some really powerful images, and is quite unforgiving showing them. It plays well, and I recommend it for everyone who still thinks that war is fun. Some images shown by this are almost too much to handle for an anverage consumer... but the game is worth playing. Okay, time to stop this blabbering and play some more stuff.

Its nothing that really stands out, unless you cound nice responsive controls and good feedback special, because it almost is nowadays. But whats important is that it doesn't detract from the narrative, which makes it all the more impacting. I won't spoil anything, but the plot mainly focuses on PTSD, as well as commenting on the current trend of Modern War, essentially saying they're bad like we already knew. content:
Posted: March 8, 2015
												Specs Ops the Line is so much more than just a tactical shooter: it's a wonderful experience.You will find yourself in emotional situations, taking imposible decisions, regreting them every step of the way. This game is so complex it feels like a Nolan's movie at times, it even messes with you in the loading screens. The graphics are very committed to the desert feel but still manages to take your breath away at times. The music is just amazing, ranging from Hard Rock to Motown and you may feel not all this songs are fitting to a shooting game, but they are to the emotional feeling of it, which is the game's strongest point.One of the only downsides is how the difficulty scalates, I was so mindblown by this game I decided to replay it in the FUBAR difficulty, which is the hardest possible, it gets you thinking outside the box most of the time, looking for different ways to achive your objective, picking your shots carefully, but sadly at times it's just ridiculously hard with unskippable instadeath scenes that you will replay DOZENS of times to get through by sheer luck, and it feels like the game is trying to be longer in a really cheap way.Other than that this game is a jewel that deserves to be appreciated.I am yet to try the coop mode, will update this review when I do.

content:
Posted: February 17, 2015
												There were over five thousand people alive in this city, the day before you arrived. How many are alive today, I wonder? How many will be alive tomorrow? Story Captain Walker, sergeant Lugo and lieutenant Adams go to the destroyed city of Dubai to rescue any survivors that they are able to find. At least, that is what they think they are doing here. Upon arriving in Dubai the Damned 33d is in a war with the CIA over control of the destroyed city. Many civilians are still alive and breathing, but know no rescue is coming for them. Walker and his comrades walked straight into hell and need to get out, even if this means doing some of the most inhumane things. The story is the best aspect of the game, everybody who likes third person shooters should've experienced this story. Gameplay Spec Ops: The Line is a simple third person shooter, with fair third person shooting mechanics. You, Captain Walker, can take two weapons with you everywhere you go, but these weapons can go out of ammo fast so you'll have to pick up weapons from your dead enemies. sergeant Lugo and lieutenant Adams are some very helpful friends. You can order them to kill a specific enemy, which is very handy from time to time. Sergeant Lugo is able to make long ranged shots with his sniper rifle and lieutenant Adams is able to flash your enemies if they're standing in a small group. They gameplay may be a bit clunky, but fun for the duration of the game. Conclusion A solid third person shooter with an amazing storyline, every chapter has its own setting and never really gets boring. The game has multiple endings and choices to make, so a there is some replayability. Spec Ops: The Line is a game everyone should at least played once purely for it's amazing story. The gameplay does have some hiccups, but can be forgiven. 7.5/10

content:
Posted: October 11, 2016
												Surprisingly good. Spec Ops: The Line is not just another shooter set in the modern day. It's very story-focused, putting you into the shoes of Captain Walker and his squadmates, and making you live through the harrowing events they had to face when deployed in war-torn Dubai. The game has a very cinematic feel to it. The scenes build up gradually to big climaxes, and the squadmates discussing what's going on and arguing with one another the entire time, making them seem like real people and not just mindless NPCs. In addition, the game presents you with some moral choices at times, making you think twice on your decisions and putting you in situations where neither choice can be considered good. Without giving away any spoilers, the game concludes on a mindblowing ending, or more precisely - endings, whilst leaving some ambiguity behind to let the players interpret the rest. I would highly suggest to play the game to the end and then to check the Youtube videos to see all the endings and their interpretations. Story aside, the gameplay is pretty fun as well. The combat is fun and for the most part consists of your typical third-person cover-based gunfights. There is some variety in the environments where you fight, ranging from desert outposts to insides of malls and other semi-broken buildings, as well as rooftops. This in turn presents some interesting challenges from time to time, such as defence sections and the like. It could get a bit repetitive, however, and some of the bigger gunfights do feel a bit messy at times. Additionally, the squadmates and the enemies wear similar-coloured uniforms, so it's very easy to mistake a fellow ally for an enemy during a heated combat. The crosshairs of some weapons turn red when on the enemy, but this isn't the case for all weapons, so it's easy to accidentally hurt your allies.Overall I've enjoyed my time with this game. Although the combat started to get repetitive and a bit frustrating towards the end, the story makes it well worth playing the game through from start to finish. Recommended.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 16, 2014
												This is probably one of the best games I've ever played.Why?The gameplay is pretty standard fare for the shooter genre, with some somewhat interesting squad dynamics thrown in. I've heard the multiplayer is terrible, if you can find anyone still playing it at all. So why is this game so amazing? The story in the campaign. It plays on your psyche, messes with your head, and makes you question why you even play games like this. It's a critique of the entire genre, one that desperately needed to be made. Why do we, as gamers, typically like to shoot things for fun? Is killing people in a video game truly harmless? If so, should we still enjoy it as much as we do?The story draws from some classics for inspiration (most notably Heart of Darkness, by Joseph Conrad), but it takes what it needs and expands on the rest. It takes some classic conventions, and finds a way to use that to tell its own story, and tell a completely new and fresh message."To kill for yourself is murder. To kill for your government is heroic. To kill for entertainment is harmless."

content:
Posted: March 15, 2014
												The Dubai Game! Really, just for its setting it's worth being played. Spec Ops puts you in the shoes of a Delta Force squad leader who - along with two members of the same squad - must uncover the truth behind the disappearance of a famous colonel. Search is immediately started after receiving a radio signal and your squad eventually finds itself in the middle of a war.The game is a relatively difficult tactical 3rd person shooter - you control the leader but can give orders to the squad members.  You clear one room after the next - while the game is linear it offers a great story that tries to portray the dark side of a war, a war where it's almost impossible to make good choices. The game has stunning visuals and superb voice acting - all delivered from the best in the gaming industry. Replayability exists due to the different difficulties and also the different endings offered based on the choices to be made by the players.I never tried its multiplayer mode but did not plan to do so. Just for the single player experience this is a highly recommended game not just for those in favour of the genre but for those who like a good story.

content:
Posted: January 20, 2014
												Spec Ops: The Line plays like a rebuttal to the jingoistic chest beating espoused by the CoD and MoH series in their later iterations. This is a story which puts war under the magnifying glass, and examines its horrific consequences, both on the individuals who fight those wars, and those caught in the crossfire. Essentially, it is gaming's Heart of Darkness/Apocalypse Now.The Gameplay is standard cover shooter fare, so it begins to feel a bit tired towards the final third of the game, but given the story content, I almost feel that this exhaustion with the game mechanics helps reinforce the themes of the game - which I will not comment on here, and instead say: Play this game, it is an amazing piece of work that is sadly vastly underappreciated."Survivors: One too many."

content:
Posted: December 29, 2013
												I want to bash the gameplay and controls because they were sub par; I was pretty disappointed with them. And yet the more I thought about it after I finished the game the more I thought this was done intentionally. Either way, it really doesn't matter. If it was done on purpose it's something to think about. If it wasn't, it's still something to think about.Oh, you'd like to know more? No. I'm not a Hollywood movie trailer.1) Buy the game (a moderately important step).2) Finish the game (tough it out if you really have to, ya sally).2a) If you're like me you'll either want to save before the end and experience all the endings or at least watch them on YouTube (you bought the game - play through them!)3) Form your own opinions (don't let the Internet think for you!).4) Go online and check out the wealth of information and opinions on this game.5) Sit back and take the time to truly enjoy what a fine piece of art (yea, I said it) this game is.This game literally does not care if you like it or hate it. This is also why it's a masterpiece. Did it get you to think? There. Done. It has you and you didn't even realize it.I will pay you back the cost of this game if you honestly did not spend more than a minute of your time thinking about everything this game laid out.

												Dude, Spec Ops: The Line, what a trip to hell... if you like stories, not the stereotypical stuff with the happy ending and♥♥♥♥♥♥ im talking about something to make you think, something to make YOU feel... anger, sorrow, guilt, madness, then you're in for a treat with this game.I should say that some games have evolved so much that they are also an expression of art, not only in the visual context but in the narrative side, putting you in the perspective of the protagonist, making your choises somehow important to the development of the plot, which is also fun as hell, these games are the artform from the present era.About graphics, i loved them, Dubai city is presented in such great detail, even the climate is represented accurate, always seems to prevail a horrid heat wave and the characters sweat and get injuried in a realistic way. About the cutscenes, the editing technique is very well done and the graphics are the same as the rest of the game keeping the action style, the main character suffers an insane transformation to get the end of the game, you can see him as a wild animal cornered trying to save his life by destroying his hunters, look at his eyes.About the sound, is all realistic about gunshots, blasts and enviromental, the voice acting is superb, i read they hired Desmond from assassins creed, in that game he kinda sucked but here he really delivers all his lines, the interaction with the characters is also really good, lets say something like at the begining he sounds like all technical and professional soldier, but later on he becomes sadistic and full of rage and you can hear him getting all psychotic, its insane.About playability, what, lots of guns, explosives, properly represented-- and is really friendly to master combat techniques, there is also some interaction degree, like firing heavy machine guns or issuing orders to squad members, also destroying certain parts in the map to let sand bury your enemies alive, all the good♥♥♥♥♥♥ but is in the command to your guys stuff that i found the weak point in this game, The AI is mostly lame as it gets, if you fail to cover them, your guys will run into certain death and that is more troubles for you. About the dificulty level, easy is for dumb ♥♥♥♥s, on the other side, FUBAR dificulty will get your♥♥♥♥♥on the grill, hard as nails, it is a big challenge.Last words.. man i loved this adventure, but it left me with a weird feeling in my soul (?), something other war games failed to portray, lets say call of fruty, where enemies fall just like shapes under your relentless gunfire, this game will make you think over your choices, war is not fun, i really dont know when we desensitized so much about killing other humans, i know ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, its just a game but think about it, you're getting used to the idea of unloading your mag upon other humans without feeling anything, thats not right. We need more games to think about it, we need to THINK more.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 15, 2014
												The Dubai Game! Really, just for its setting it's worth being played. Spec Ops puts you in the shoes of a Delta Force squad leader who - along with two members of the same squad - must uncover the truth behind the disappearance of a famous colonel. Search is immediately started after receiving a radio signal and your squad eventually finds itself in the middle of a war.The game is a relatively difficult tactical 3rd person shooter - you control the leader but can give orders to the squad members.  You clear one room after the next - while the game is linear it offers a great story that tries to portray the dark side of a war, a war where it's almost impossible to make good choices. The game has stunning visuals and superb voice acting - all delivered from the best in the gaming industry. Replayability exists due to the different difficulties and also the different endings offered based on the choices to be made by the players.I never tried its multiplayer mode but did not plan to do so. Just for the single player experience this is a highly recommended game not just for those in favour of the genre but for those who like a good story.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 26
												Spec Ops: The Line is a hard game to define. Going into it, I expected a regular old FPS or other type of military shooter game. What I got, however, was one of the most compelling stories I've ever seen in a video game. This review will be spoiler free. The story of SO:TL was one were you are always a step behind. You're  lost, confused, angry, scared, frustrated, and a million more descriptions that couldnt be fit here. You experience all of these emotions. These real, visceral feelings are elicited by this game, and it does it spectacularly. Some of the controls are awefully clunky and can be a pain, but if you look past a shoddy control scheme, and the mediocre console port, You are thrown into one of the best story driven games I've ever played. If your a fan of story games, or Third person shooters, or just games in general, I can't recommend this enough9.25/10

content:
Posted: January 20, 2014
												Spec Ops: The Line plays like a rebuttal to the jingoistic chest beating espoused by the CoD and MoH series in their later iterations. This is a story which puts war under the magnifying glass, and examines its horrific consequences, both on the individuals who fight those wars, and those caught in the crossfire. Essentially, it is gaming's Heart of Darkness/Apocalypse Now.The Gameplay is standard cover shooter fare, so it begins to feel a bit tired towards the final third of the game, but given the story content, I almost feel that this exhaustion with the game mechanics helps reinforce the themes of the game - which I will not comment on here, and instead say: Play this game, it is an amazing piece of work that is sadly vastly underappreciated."Survivors: One too many."

content:
Posted: December 29, 2013
												I want to bash the gameplay and controls because they were sub par; I was pretty disappointed with them. And yet the more I thought about it after I finished the game the more I thought this was done intentionally. Either way, it really doesn't matter. If it was done on purpose it's something to think about. If it wasn't, it's still something to think about.Oh, you'd like to know more? No. I'm not a Hollywood movie trailer.1) Buy the game (a moderately important step).2) Finish the game (tough it out if you really have to, ya sally).2a) If you're like me you'll either want to save before the end and experience all the endings or at least watch them on YouTube (you bought the game - play through them!)3) Form your own opinions (don't let the Internet think for you!).4) Go online and check out the wealth of information and opinions on this game.5) Sit back and take the time to truly enjoy what a fine piece of art (yea, I said it) this game is.This game literally does not care if you like it or hate it. This is also why it's a masterpiece. Did it get you to think? There. Done. It has you and you didn't even realize it.I will pay you back the cost of this game if you honestly did not spend more than a minute of your time thinking about everything this game laid out.

content:
Posted: September 6, 2015
												A really good game with OK gameplay as in you go from cover to cover and you shoot the bad guys and throw grenades and stuff, however the ability to give your squad members commands such as attack, stun and heal the other squad mate is KINDA unique.The real cream of the crop here is the story. It is pretty short though, you can complete it in about 5 - 7 hours on the normal difficulty. After replaying this game about 5 times to get every single achievement even the one for completing the game on FUBAR (which was brutal and almost made me commit a war crime on my computer) I can safely say that I understand the story of the game (at least that's what I say to look cool). I won't be revealing details about the story for people like Vikezor who don't want anything to be spoiled for them even though they may never even play this game in their lives, but what I WILL say is that it isn't your typical military shooter story about taking out a terrorist leader threatening to blow up Pluto or something. The story is pretty unique and left me questioning ''What happens next?''. The story makes you think about war and the attrocities people commit under speciffic circumstances. It also has multiple endings about 4 I think and a few descisions you have to make during the story. The soundtrack to this game is also amazing, it fits the story pretty well and makes me wanna replay it to be able to battle enemies while listening to some rocking tunes. Without going into the hostile spoiler lands I can't really say much more so I will cross the border into them for a few seconds to say this:SPOLERS YO KIDS SPOILERS RIGHT HERE The game left me wondering what happens to Walker after he leaves Dubai in that one ending where you shoot at Konrad in the mirror and don't kill the US soldiers that arrive to extract you. Questions like ''What's he gonna do now? Will the things he's seen and done haunt him forever? And did he even have any family to return to?'' popped into mind while watching Marty boy leave Dubai.	END OF THE SPOILERS KIDSIn general I personally think this game is amazing because of the story. However the developers have revealed that they won't be making a sequel or another game in the Spec Ops series for a while because as amazing as the game is it didn't make them a lot of money, not as much as they hoped for at least.Final score: 578/603P.S. Bailey shut the heck up.

content:
Posted: August 16, 2014
												This is probably one of the best games I've ever played.Why?The gameplay is pretty standard fare for the shooter genre, with some somewhat interesting squad dynamics thrown in. I've heard the multiplayer is terrible, if you can find anyone still playing it at all. So why is this game so amazing? The story in the campaign. It plays on your psyche, messes with your head, and makes you question why you even play games like this. It's a critique of the entire genre, one that desperately needed to be made. Why do we, as gamers, typically like to shoot things for fun? Is killing people in a video game truly harmless? If so, should we still enjoy it as much as we do?The story draws from some classics for inspiration (most notably Heart of Darkness, by Joseph Conrad), but it takes what it needs and expands on the rest. It takes some classic conventions, and finds a way to use that to tell its own story, and tell a completely new and fresh message."To kill for yourself is murder. To kill for your government is heroic. To kill for entertainment is harmless."

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 11, 2016
												Surprisingly good. Spec Ops: The Line is not just another shooter set in the modern day. It's very story-focused, putting you into the shoes of Captain Walker and his squadmates, and making you live through the harrowing events they had to face when deployed in war-torn Dubai. The game has a very cinematic feel to it. The scenes build up gradually to big climaxes, and the squadmates discussing what's going on and arguing with one another the entire time, making them seem like real people and not just mindless NPCs. In addition, the game presents you with some moral choices at times, making you think twice on your decisions and putting you in situations where neither choice can be considered good. Without giving away any spoilers, the game concludes on a mindblowing ending, or more precisely - endings, whilst leaving some ambiguity behind to let the players interpret the rest. I would highly suggest to play the game to the end and then to check the Youtube videos to see all the endings and their interpretations. Story aside, the gameplay is pretty fun as well. The combat is fun and for the most part consists of your typical third-person cover-based gunfights. There is some variety in the environments where you fight, ranging from desert outposts to insides of malls and other semi-broken buildings, as well as rooftops. This in turn presents some interesting challenges from time to time, such as defence sections and the like. It could get a bit repetitive, however, and some of the bigger gunfights do feel a bit messy at times. Additionally, the squadmates and the enemies wear similar-coloured uniforms, so it's very easy to mistake a fellow ally for an enemy during a heated combat. The crosshairs of some weapons turn red when on the enemy, but this isn't the case for all weapons, so it's easy to accidentally hurt your allies.Overall I've enjoyed my time with this game. Although the combat started to get repetitive and a bit frustrating towards the end, the story makes it well worth playing the game through from start to finish. Recommended.
