content:
Posted: February 2, 2016
												A wonderfully, terrible third person shooter that you can finish in a weekend. Spec Ops: The Line will draw you in with its generic box art and derivative gameplay, and then flip you on your head and stomp on your gut because you're a terrible person. The game opens in medias res with (all together now) a helicopter chase scene wherein you mow down other helicopters with an infinite ammo minigun, until one of them crashes into you. flash back to the beginning where our protangonists are on a mission to find out what happened in Dubai after a record sandstorm hit. You fight some local insurgents, explore some interesting sand infested buildings, and slowly learn about a CIA operation and a rogue American Infantry unit. After about an hour of run-of-the-mill shooter story, things start to get a little strange. First you start killing other American soldiers in self-defense. Then you're trying to figure out if you can trust the CIA agents or not. pretty soon you're raining down white phosphorus on an entire platoon of your fellow soldiers and innocent civilians!Wait what?Yeah, it only gets better from there, and the best part is the story ramps up so smoothly and the gameplay is integrated into that story so well. The loading screens start off with helpful hints about gameplay then slowly shift to unnerving messages directed at the player in real life. The animations of the characters even change over time! The early game will see Cpt. Walker punch or rifle butt a downed enemy to finish him off, but later on he starts getting more viscious by shooting them in the face while they beg for mercy. Even the mission objectives are integrated into this mad scheme. They start off like any other game: go here, defend this, eliminate that. But then they change: obey, murder, and so on.Often in games we see a sort of cognitive dissonance between what the game is telling us about a character and what the character actually does in the game when we're controlling them (see the Tomb Raider reboot). Spec Ops is both a great example of how to not have that problem AND is the greatest display of cognitive dissonance AT THE SAME TIME!I could go on, but the Extra Credits team has already articulated my thoughts better than I can. I do have a few closing thoughts though. First and foremost, yes the gameplay isn't very good. You run. Your gun. You take cover. Enemies spawn in obvious spots. It's all very early 2000s shooter. However, that's all done on purpose to highlight and critique those very same generic shooters. Second, this is strictly a single player game. There is no multiplayer, nor should there have ever been (although maybe they also tacked it on just to show a point). Finally, and most importantly, I'd like you all to remember: you choose to play this game. You choose to do all those horrible things. Really, the only way to win this game is to stop playing it. But even then, you'd still be losing.

content:
Posted: April 3, 2015
												A vailiant effort, but flawed and shows the limits of video games and how they can never be considered art.Specs Ops: The Line has received much praise in weaving a horrific tale of an op gone wrong and the horrors of war. The game expertly puts you in the shoes of the main character as he teeters on the edge of sanity as his PTSD nightmare slowly consumes him. But in the end, the game's greatest strength is also its greatest weakness.The game not only encourages, but actively pushes you towards making crazy "gamer" decisions that leads to the story spiraling out of control. Executing a downed enemy is a common video game mechanic that players have come to expect. Executing a downed enemy also gives you ammo for both weapons. However, should you choose to simply double-tap them with your gun, you will not spiral into madness at the same rate as a normal playthrough. Although there are many hidden third options to most of your choices, the game doesn't let you make any key decisions that sidestep everything.Spec Ops: The Line does a great job of telling one story but fails to give you the other option of not succumbing to monstrosity. The gameplay is very tiresome and rather boring. Some would say that this is in part of the game trying to parody the meaninglessness of your generic modern First-Person-Shooters, but was this honestly the best way of going about this? Couldn't we have some fun going down this hellish slide?I only wish that there were more choices that we could make that would better simulate PTSD/anxiety/paranoia. Why was there no choice to interact with the civillian NPCs in a way that would test our distrust of the local populace? Why was there no option to deal with groups that were obviously armed and cutious, yet not overtly hostile?Overall, Spec Ops: The Line is a good game to experience but not necessarily to play. I would definitely recommend this game if you enjoy storytelling experiences.

Posted: November 19, 2014
												You've probably heard most of the praise to be given to this game by now, so I'll skip the part where I suck this games♥♥♥♥♥♥for as long as it ♥♥♥♥ing wants and stick to facts:Gameplay (because this SHOULD be your first concern): - Shooting is solid and the guns (for the most part) actually feel like they can do some damage which seems to lack for most games. Hit detection never betrays you and you rarely feel cheated.- Difficult...I mean...enemies can actually pose some form of challenge. They WILL flank you and they WILL toss grenades World at War style but you are usually given a decent enough warning that if you die, it was probably your own fault.- Close encounters/executions are brutal and the game teaches you this rather quickly in a way that doesn't break the immersion.- It's actually fun to play. *OPINION WARNING* I genuinely enjoyed playing through it more than once and will be doing it again in the future.- Both keyboard+mouse and controllers feel good and neither is necessarily preferable to the other.Story:- It's a ♥♥♥♥ing bloodbath of a war/rebellion-torn Dubai ravaged by mass sandstorms...survive.- Okay, there is an initial objective but I don't like spoilers, let's just say there are genuinely concerning questions posed by the twists of a generally taboo topic...think about it...what if the Americans weren't ALWAYS the good guys? Mind-♥♥♥♥ing-explosion, right?!Visuals (last because it's a ♥♥♥♥ing video game, shut up and play the damn thing):- On a high-end machine, it's absolutely stunning the amount of detail placed into the game.- Even on a lower-end pc, the game looks solid and if you don't want your pc game looking slightly worse than on xbox, ♥♥♥♥ing buy it on xbox. Problem solved. - Small stutter upon checkpoints but you'll survive.

content:
Posted: August 10, 2014
												Ever wanted a game which Murica ♥♥♥♥ yeah! is not the winner?Get Spec ops: The Line.Ever wanted a game which showed you the effects of war on yourself and others?Get Spec ops: The Line.Ever wanted a game which not only got you immersed in the game world, but also got you attached to the characters?Get Spec ops: The Line.This should not be classed as a game, but more an interactive work of art. It tells a story of a squad of American soldiers fighting their way through Dubai to try and free the citizens from the evil John Konrad. The game portrays the effects that PTSD has on soldiers and how a simple rescue mission can turn into a mass graveyard.This game is not "FUN" it is a serious story-based game which would be best played over a weekend as it can be beaten in roughly 8-9 hours. Final thoughts:This game is amazing and you should buy it once on sale because it is a short story, but great none the less. Also do not read anything about it until you finish it because the game will be ruined as there are too many spoilers.Also the game mechanics are awful, so play it on normal difficulty because the gameplay isn't fantastic and you can easily get killed out of the blue by things.

content:
Posted: October 18, 2016
												At first glance, Spec Ops: The Line might seem to be another Call of Duty clone, but actually it is so much more than that. Quite honestly, I'm not really into military shooters, but I enjoy playing this game. An amazing story sets the pace with many unexpected twists and turns. This game shows perfectly all the brutality of war. The plot is constantly keeping you guessing and the ending is very mind blowing. Yes, some of it could be a little quirky, but it is still one of the best stories I've ever encountered. Also, the game has excellent character progression.However, the 3rd-person shooter gameplay is pretty unimpressive: the cover system is temperamental, the aiming sucks, the weapons are boring, and stealth is rarely possible. It ends up being repetitive as do most cover-and-fire games. So, to be honest, the gameplay is nothing special and could be considered  quite bad, but I guess that is not what this game is made for.The graphics are quite good, the soundtracks are also amazing and only bring more depth to the game. On top of that, the noise and effects are genuinely special, sounding real and effective. Furthermore, the voice acting is top-tier and sounds very real.Overall, if you go into playing Spec Ops: The Line with the mindset that it is a run of the military shooter you will be disappointing, but if you play it looking for a game that's story is both gripping and thought provoking, try this out. Trust me, this shooter is an outstanding piece of art when it comes to terms of story and picture. Give this game a shot, it might change your perception of the whole genre more than its technically superior counterparts ever could.

												Whoooaaaaaaa, dude! What a game! I beat it 3 times and I still feel like doing it again. A mindblowing experience. I still don’t fully understand the story, but I’m not supposed to. Out of the 4 different endings, the one I liked the most was the one that gives you the Too Late The Hero and The Road To Glory achievements. I’m really proud of myself for getting the Sierra Hotel achievement while on Suicide Mission difficulty and beating the game on FUBAR difficulty. By my third playthrough, I had gotten pretty good at getting headshots, so while it wasn’t a walk on the beach, it wasn't that hard. Enemies don’t respawn forever, so you just have to take it slow and deal with one at a time. The attack order was bugged for me in certain resolutions though, which was really annoying since I had to lower the resolution to 800x600 for it to work properly.

content:
Posted: March 5, 2015
												"Aw jeez... where's all this violence coming from? Is it the video games? I bet it's the video games."I'm just going to start off with overall ratings as I know some people don't like lengthy reviewsMajor aspects:Gameplay: 9/10 Very good for this style which has become so rare (a third person cover and shoot)Story line: 10/10 The best I have ever encountered, far better than even games such as the Telltale's “The Walking Dead” Immersion/atmosphere: 10/10 The atmosphere was incredible, this game is one of the rare games that you can truly lose yourself in.Graphics: 10/10 Despite the game being a few years old I have never seen a game with better graphics.Minor aspects:Realism: 8.5/10 Aside from the lack of friendly fire and the fact that you face hordes of enemies while surviving (though your health is relatively low), this game is rather realisticSmoothness (gameplay): 9/10 This game felt very nice to play and its only fault would be occasionally I would not duck for cover unless I pressed the button several times. Voice acting: 10/10 All the voices suit the characters very well and there is not a single voice actor that taints the immersion of the game.Player involvement (choices): 10/10 The choices were incredible, however I would have preferred it if there were a few more. Overall:I don't really base the score from the minor aspects so the score (from critic point of view) is:9.75/10Though, personally, I believe this is the greatest game I have ever played and would rate it:10/10General review:When I first decided to play this game I thought it was a typical trashy shooter. This was reinforced by the single player being referred to as the "campaign" and even more so when the game started off with a typical Gatling gun in a helicopter scene. However, a few minutes into the game I was proven wrong, this game has the greatest storyline I have ever seen, there aren't really any incredibly “tear jerking” moments as there are with games such as the walking dead, however the game still does an incredible job to connect with the player emotionally as well conveying the emotions and journey of the protagonist. Without trying to give too much away, the game also includes a variation of choices that effect the game and also lead to multiple diverse endings.The game play mainly consists of finding cover, coming up from cover and shooting enemies. Though the gameplay is repetitive the various amounts of guns, enemies terrain variations and other things, make the game continuously enjoyable. The animation of combat is very nice as well, the darting for cover and switching to different cover was a very nice animation that made the game feel extremely nice to play.The atmosphere in this game, contrasted with the outstanding graphics, creates a unique world for the player to experience. The atmosphere in this game is unlike any other shooter and truly makes you feel like a real soldier, rather than just an emotionless killing machine, this is reinforced by the two soldiers under you command that are polar opposites, I won't go into that though for it would spoil a large portion of the game. Overall I cannot recommend this game any more highly, it is easily the greatest game I have every played and the only real drawback would be the length. The game has everything that you could possibly ask and so much more. IT is incredibly unique and simply extraordinary, it is definitely worth buying and playing.

content:
Posted: June 22, 2014
												Spec Ops: The Line is a solid 3rd person shooter that focuses on the horrors of war. It's kind of like "Apocalypse Now!" with Dubai as the setting but that comparison is giving it a little too much credit.  It's more like an ultraviolent summer blockbuster war movie. The story and dialogue come off hamfisted and silly at times. The voice acting is decent for the most part and the sound design is good. I would've liked the guns to be louder and bullet snaps would be great for immersion. The shooting mechanics are satisfying and the intensity of the combat is what kept me coming back to 100% this game. It's no "Red Orchestra" immersion wise, but I think it illustrates the horrors of war well in some ways. Enemies collapse and some suffer while clutching wounds or crawl away. They cough and whimper as blood pools around them. One thing they never do is surrender, which is an annoying trope of modern shooters. At least there are unarmed civilians on some levels, which goes against convention. The game also forces you into some bad situations with civilians which is a great way to show the ugliness of war.The game looks fantastic, even years later and it's surreal to see Dubai turned into a wartorn blood soaked ruin. Every firefight is fun and challenging if played on the harder difficulty levels. It would've been nice to have stealth be more viable. It's also a little funny that a 3 man squad kills off thousands of enemies. I know it's supposed to be somewhat of a satire on the modern military shooter but I would've rather had "Rainbow Six" style squad selection/commands and losses than 2 invulnerable baby sitters. I hope more games try to execute a "military shooter gone horror" vibe. I really like that the game is a train wreck of bad events and it tries to make you feel responsible and bad for it, kind of like the Kane & Lynch series. It was just a little too hamfisted, on rails and "gamey" for that feeling to hit me, but I enjoyed the horrific descent into madness nonetheless. If you are looking for a solid 3rd person shooter with an intense atmosphere, definitely grab this game.  7/10

content:
Posted: October 9, 2012
												Spec Ops: The Line, set in the desert city of Dubai, is an Unreal Engine-based military 3rd person shooter that surely doesn't revolutionize its genre, but certainly stands out because of its mature, intense and moral-conflicting story and its great voice acting and writing.The game doesn't focus on the usual glorifying AMERICA, F* YEAH crap where you blow up stuff and ride into the sunset. It shows you the dark side of war and confronts you with moral choices that will get people killed, no matter how you decide - and you will see the results of your choices, laying dead in front of you.The playtime for the campaign is around 7 hours. The game also features a multiplayer which, unfortunately, is pretty much dead. Additionally, there is a co-op mode that lets you team up with a buddy and fight your way through 4 unique missions.Spec Ops: The Line isn't a game with a happy ending and it certainly won't make you feel comfortable, but that's what makes this game so special and rare.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 8, 2014
												Where to start with this game? Brilliance in the form of a storyline. I was not expecting this game to be all that great. I gathered from most reviews of it that it wasn't, but I still did purchase it. I can very gladly say that I was happily proven wrong. The storyline is so very well structured, with actions, even small ones, having a massive affect of the gameplay. I finished this game feeling terrible. Not many games have done that to me. The morals in Spec Ops: The Line are also represented on a very small scale, such as deciding whether or not to excecute a dying enemy for ammuntion. The gameplay element of The Line isn't the greatest: average is probably a good way to put it. Particular guns, like the snipers and heavier weapons, are completely overpowered in comparison to the others. It does cover based shooting fairly well, though it is a bit buggy in places. Overall, this game is a true emotionally-inducing adventure. It is an absolutely brilliant buy at $20-$30, and well worth it.Score: 7.5/10

												it has been said many times before but ill say it again..this game is ♥♥♥♥ing great. probably the best storyline i have ever experienced in a shooter.pro:-nice graphics-cool soundtrack (also includes some 60s/70s music)-great story (seems like the devs watched apocalypse now and other anti war movies and thought: hey can we make something like this into a game?)-challenging difficulty (at least on the "hardest" difficulty. i didnt play the game on the one you have to unlock though)-not 2 pricey-radioman (robert ♥♥♥♥ing darden)cons:-not a very long game (took me about 8 1/2 hours to beat. and i died a lot!)-while i personally enjoyed the combat a lot of people think its kinda mundane. (its just not something special but i think its fine for what it is.)-might not have a lot of replayability (though there are choices to be made and multiple endings but overall the game is fairly linear)spec ops really DOES make you think of the horrors of war. some scenes will make your stomach turn and your soul die! by the time you reach the ending you will feel kinda sad. but youll  still be happy about having experienced this little gem. sad this game flopped. id take this over CoD and other generic jingoism crap ANY DAY.i can highly recommend this game. you should definitely play it if you have no problem with its short lenght and not-so-special combat mechanics.DONT be fooled by the crap trailers. they deliberately give a false impression.things are not as they seem in this game.if you happen to buy this game : welcome to dubai!thx for reading

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 1, 2016
												This is a weird f#cking game. Feels like the Anti-COD of Doody, and I must say I f#cking love it. However it does have issues that you should know, and that’s where I’ll start:First and foremost, the gameplay. It’s a third person shooter and sticking to cover is a must, however sh#t doesn’t always work as it’s meant to work. At times you try to stick to one cover and end up sticking to another. At times you try to do something simple, and end up doing something else entirely, and probably end up dying stupidly. There are also a few bugs on it, although not game-breaking at all.The only other problem the game has is the multiplayer, and this one must be explained as it’s actually quite interesting: The devs didn’t actually wanted to add it, the publishers however though that a military shooter HAD TO HAVE IT and asked the devs for it. When they refused, the publishers hired ANOTHER TEAM OF DEVELOPERS to make the multiplayer, even against the wish of the original devs. And what happened? The multiplayers sucks balls at sucking balls. The coop is decent if you have a  friend to go through it and have a laugh or two, but I wouldn’t really recommend playing this game’s multiplayer AT ALL. The devs didn’t want it there to begin with, so ignore it as if it didn’t exist. If anything, just insult the publishers for trying to force this game to follow the sh#tty standards of this sh#tty gaming generation.Ignoring that though, what do we have left? Hell, that’s what we have. The game takes a rather serious look at how war actually is, rather than the classic “HELLO, YOU’RE MERRICAN WHICH MEANS YOU’RE A GOOD GUY AND PRACTICALLY INVINCIBLE, NOW GO OUT THERE AND SHOOT DEMOCRACY AND FREEDOM TO ANYTHING THAT MOVES” kind of games. It’s a heavy story-driven game, and you gotta get deeply involved into it to like it, but seriously, 9 times out of 10 you’ll like it every time.The music is also something I liked about this game quite a lot. Not only the licensed music that plays and quite seriously fits in, but the original themes made for the game, especially as it goes on and on.The characters themselves are also worth mention. All the important characters of the game are seriously well written and truly feel real, even if some characters on the story don’t develop too much. The writing is also spot-on with the story and the meaning behind it, and might even make you feel bad once you actually do SEE what they meant.Is it a good game? It is. And it’s quite the experience. However, it’s more like a movie than an actual game, and you should seriously play it for it’s story rather than the gameplay. On a sale, this is quite the steal. Do you feel like a hero yet? TL;DR Edition: It’s a big “F#CK YOU” to games such as CoD, which show that war is all fun and shooting chickens in the head. Really, seriously good story and average gameplay, the multiplayer should be ignored entirely as the devs didn’t even want it and the publishers forced it there. A good purchase on a sale.

												How many times have you played a videogame where at the end you had to question your actions? Question the game? Cry in the bathtub?  With a breathtaking narrative, fantastic visuals and top notch OST you will feel like♥♥♥♥♥♥ But you'll be happy you played this gem. The only downside of Spec Ops The Line is the gameplay. Not that it's bad, it's actually very solid. But it's unoriginal and feels like a chore when there is so much more going on. The rest of the game breaks new ground, the gameplay is just bland. In the end, I think the problem was really what the Publisher wanted to sell as opposed to what the developer wanted to create. If we look at all the promotional material and even the forced multiplayer, the generic (yet popular in other games) that's the conclusion I get to.In any case, the story is fantastic and you should give this a shot.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 19, 2014
												This is hands-down one of the most emotionally engaging and impactful games I have ever played. What starts out as your run-of-the-mill third-person military shooter, quickly turns into a psychological and unique story unseen in modern gaming. The developers did an incredible job of truly making you feel the weight and consequences of the decisions you've made in not just this game, but every game you've played previously.I personally do not enjoy shooters; this is precisely why I loved this game so much. It is not only addictive and engaging, but it's a smart and expertly crafted critique of the very genre it represents. Nolan North's performance is extremely impressive, even given his pedigree. I cannot recommend this game highly enough - if you want to experience something unique and memorable, you need to play this game. I finished it in one sitting it was so addicting.

content:
Posted: February 13, 2015
												Excelent story telling and gameplay. Everything is spot on, save for a couple large issues.1.) Cover is everywhere and reliable almost all the time. I say almost, sometimes you'll take cover against the wrong side of a wall and you'll end up dead because of it. Sometimes the cover doesn't work at all. Some things that look like they should be cover aren't, which can get you killed very easily. But as I said, it's very uncommon for this to occur.2.) The Checkpoint placement is absolutely H O R R E N D O U S, forcing you to redo large battles over and over, considering the game is relatively difficulty. This is a major problem, especially near the end of the game when you lose a squad mate (not permanantly) and are forced to take on droves of enemies on your own. Many battles seem to occur in waves, it would have been nice to overcome one wave of enemies, then get a save, then continue. It has caused me on multiple occasions to quit the game because I just don't have the mental capacity to deal with this kind of rage. This is coming from someone with hundreds of hours clocked in Dark Souls. I know that there's nothing worse than getting far in a tough situation, only to die and have to redo the entire fight. At least in Dark Souls it  makes sense though. Other than that I only have praise for the game The story is powerful, I like the clashing characters (I don't /like/ their clashing, I just find it realistic and a great way to cause tension), the gunplay is top notch. The enemy chatter when not engaged is realistic and immersive, reminds me of the guys in Battlefield Bad Company 2 who talk about the movie "Predator" before you have to kill them. It makes you think that these are real humans, it makes you think about your actions and everything you do. Which is, in the end, the entire point of the game.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 25, 2015
												There is a scene where two guys are smoking on balcony or something, talking about their lives, the sunset, their experiences, their dreams, their family, their friends. They are not very important characters, just another of the seemingly endless supply of bad guys the game throws at you. After I heard their conversation I stopped a moment before my team and I shot them. They would no longer share their stories, they probably did not expect that peaceful sunset setting over those desolate ruins of a debauched city to be the last thing they saw. That is when I realized. I was not killing "bad guys", I was killing people. People who had as much to look towards to as I did, and has lived as fully, and I killed them. That is the feeling you should get when taking a life, not a casual dismissal as another number in the kill count, it seems game developers forget to add this most important element to shooters and action games. Shoot first ask questions later seems to be the purveying rule when addressing this genre. So far this is the only game that has made me feel the morality of such a rule. When I killed those two, I realized there was no right or wrong, just difference of opinions that could never be solved and has escalated beyond any form of civil discussion. This was meant to be a short review, with some dry humour, but this is what this game does to you. It makes you feel and regret and question until you've reached a conclusion that satisfies your morals. I still have to find it in me to find the moral compass required to pick up this game again. To steel myself against the immorality of killing and become numb to the feeling of taking a life. I have to draw the line somewhere.The gameplay and graphics are pretty nice too10/10TL;DR This game makes you feel bad for killing others.

content:
Posted: December 27, 2014
												This is a first person shooterand you can skip the videos and ingore the story.But this game is about the story.The shooting mechanism is good, the cover system is very good, the weapons are fun to shoot with. The game would be a good shooter on its own.But the game shines when it comes to the story. Sometimes you have to make choices. I do not know the differences between the choices or if there are totally different stories depending on the choices. But I do know that I really was sad when my choices turned the events in certain ways.This is not a funny game. It is a sad game for adults.I liked the story, the graphics, the sound, the handling of the character, the weapons, nearly all of it.I disliked that certain situations are so much harder than the rest of the game.If you like shooters where you have to use cover to be able to survive, if you like a good story then you should like this game too.It is not very long, it took me 6 hours on normal difficulty. But this game is really good.I think it is only for persons > 20 years interesting, but I might be wrong there. Don't know.Get it, play it and live with your choices.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 23, 2014
												If you're looking for a game whose plot makes Camus and Kafka seem positively *uplifiting*, well, here you go.  It's both well-written and utterly depressing.  This is *not* a generic feel-good heroic rah-rah shooter.  In a way, it could even be termed "survival horror" in the purest form... the horrors that emerge from within the human mind and form, rather than mere zombies or mutants.Mechanically, it's fairly prosaic -- third-person, cover-based, regenerating health, a variety of modern weapons, a couple of companions generally.   The checkpoint system is somewhat obnoxious but checkpoints are fairly common, and if you repeatedly fail the game will start providing you with extra ammunition and even suggest lowering the difficulty (which you can do at the cost of restarting your current checkpoint).It is not a terribly long game, so don't be expecting a 40-hour run. There are some technical quirks like encrypted INI files (google around for decryption / encryption utilities) with settings that the menus don't let you change otherwise (notably, depth of field, radial blur... and mouse acceleration!).  It's a minor inconvenience since tools do exist, but just be aware.The recommendation cannot be generic, as this game is *definitely* not for everyone.

content:
Posted: June 21, 2014
												To describe this game in short, I will use the words of my good friend Iridon. "Its PTSD the game." This is not your typical war game. It puts the player into the soldier's boots and has you make decisions for the city of Dubai. These choices that are made are not so cut and dry as the other war games. In Spec Ops, your selections consist of picking grey or gray in a world of black and white; therefore, by the end of the game you will be questioning your own motives and thoughts. As a result, your mind begins to play games against you.The combat is well done for being a cover system. This story is mind blowingly good. The AI is smart for the most part on both sides of the fight. Overall, the environment is beautiful; at the same time Dubai is alive and dead as you enter the skyscrapers and walk the streets of this bloodstained, sand filled warzone.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 22, 2015
												I started this game up with little expectations as it like just just a cheap TPS with decent graphics and a surprisingly acclaimed story by a well known gaming writer. Figured the story would be o.k enough to justify the price, so I bought it during a sale.To put it bluntly, yes, gameplay wise it is as GENERIC of a TPS or any shooter for that matter. Guns have little to no punch, enemy AI is basic but otherwise predictable and unchallenging, and weapon variety is decent but limiting with the 2 weapon loadout system... but, BUT... the story...Let me just say the STORY for this game is the REAL SELLING POINT, far above the gameplay. You play Captain Walker accompanied by his boyband of I swear must be Ice Cube and Matt Damon impersinators. They at first seem uninteresting with that classic "HOO RAAAWWW" mentality games like Call of Duty suffer from. As the story progresses they get broken down, beaten up, shot, stabbed, burned, and tortured until only a husk of a human being survives.The stuff these guys go to is the stuff of knightmares and it culminates to shocking revelations, and mental barriers being broken one by one. As each character commits atrocious acts of violence they lose whatever humanity stuck with them at the beggining, degrading into savage killing machines who literally cause the city to burn by the end of it. I dont wish to spoil too much, but it is a serious trip.I repeat DO NOT buy this game if you are looking for a satisfying TPS like Vanquish, Gear of War. Space Marine, Uncharted, Last of Us, etc. Instead BUY THIS GAME if you want a jaw dropping and heart wrenching story that characterises the horrors of War in a very Apocolypse Now esque manner with brutality, savagery, and sheer gut wrenching violence NO MILITARY SHOOTER HAS EVER DONE outside of some obscure Vietnam games. 11/10... would feel like a terrible person again.

content:
Posted: January 20, 2014
												This was a surprisingly engaging game. It looks generic, but Nolan North's voice acting is a nice touch and the story is a change from other military shooters. It's not original by any means, but the characters are interesting enough to play this one until the end. It takes about 8 hours to complete, and the game is well optimized so high frame rates can be achieved if V-Sync is turned off. The graphics are amazing, as well as the audio. The gameplay is a standard third person cover game, but it works perfectly so that's not necessarily a bad thing. Ammo is scarce at times, so you'll find yourself picking up enemy weapons a lot in order to have a functional weapon. I'd recommend buying this game, it's not a Call of Duty ripoff - but instead more character focused... a story based around the effects of war and the hard choices that are made. What is right and what is wrong?

Posted: May 18, 2013
												If you play games just for fun then this game isn't for you. On the other hand if you enjoy a good story and game experience you will have a great time with Spec Ops: The Line but, BEWARE, THIS GAME IS ALOT GRIM! I beated this game in about 5 hours, more or less, and I have to say that I did get bored sometimes with the gameplay. It is in it's own a pretty basic run n' cover  third person shooter with squad commands, there's plenty of these out there. But where the game really shines is in the story. This game, despite it's short length, was easily one of the best 5 hours I spent playing a video game. I have to thank Yager Development for making one of the best, most engaging, stories in recent years along with probably amongst the best character development and character design I've ever seen in a video game.

content:
Posted: August 25, 2016
Product received for free
												It's a worthwhile product. Long story short, play it on easy difficulty and just for the story. The gameplay is used cleverly sometimes in unconventional ways.Not a masterpiece, some narrative twists are done for better drama effect even in Max Payne from 2001 by action game standards. Nothing more and nothing less than a good war drama set up in juxtaposition against "conventional" patriotic action ones. An allure towards the nihilistic unfortunately, as it only questions and doubts without introducing anything new.It's a recycling of previous notable works as "Apocalypse Now".The problem of the game is that the gameplay messes with the "no ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t" approach to traumatized human feelings. The attempt to sarcasm Saving Private Ryan and other action war products of American culture is in conflict with the serious message on the topic of war. Breaking the 4'th wall is far too often used with questionable end result or in any cohesive message delivered.It's awesome to have Spec Ops attempt a new approach. I'm optimistically looking to the future of this message progress further. As a media, video games need more of this. However without trying to use inappropriate tools to convey those messages through achievements, hero puns. I wasn't searching for action in the first place. Did not think it was amusing or well placed.It would also be interesting to hear arguments pro war too. Or how consistent the message was in general, without deconstructions in post modernist style. Again, a lot of weak points in the general anti war message with wide generalisation.--------------------------------------------------------------------------Recommended for familiarisation.  A most thorough analysis was made almost instantly after release but the dedicated team at Extra Credits which can be found here: 


YouTube™ Video: Spec Ops: The Line - I: How to Restart a Franchise - Extra Credits 

			Views: 346,712		

			Spec Ops: The Line questions the very nature of modern military shooters. It completely exceeded our expectations, so let's take a spoiler free look at how - and why.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 2, 2016
												A wonderfully, terrible third person shooter that you can finish in a weekend. Spec Ops: The Line will draw you in with its generic box art and derivative gameplay, and then flip you on your head and stomp on your gut because you're a terrible person. The game opens in medias res with (all together now) a helicopter chase scene wherein you mow down other helicopters with an infinite ammo minigun, until one of them crashes into you. flash back to the beginning where our protangonists are on a mission to find out what happened in Dubai after a record sandstorm hit. You fight some local insurgents, explore some interesting sand infested buildings, and slowly learn about a CIA operation and a rogue American Infantry unit. After about an hour of run-of-the-mill shooter story, things start to get a little strange. First you start killing other American soldiers in self-defense. Then you're trying to figure out if you can trust the CIA agents or not. pretty soon you're raining down white phosphorus on an entire platoon of your fellow soldiers and innocent civilians!Wait what?Yeah, it only gets better from there, and the best part is the story ramps up so smoothly and the gameplay is integrated into that story so well. The loading screens start off with helpful hints about gameplay then slowly shift to unnerving messages directed at the player in real life. The animations of the characters even change over time! The early game will see Cpt. Walker punch or rifle butt a downed enemy to finish him off, but later on he starts getting more viscious by shooting them in the face while they beg for mercy. Even the mission objectives are integrated into this mad scheme. They start off like any other game: go here, defend this, eliminate that. But then they change: obey, murder, and so on.Often in games we see a sort of cognitive dissonance between what the game is telling us about a character and what the character actually does in the game when we're controlling them (see the Tomb Raider reboot). Spec Ops is both a great example of how to not have that problem AND is the greatest display of cognitive dissonance AT THE SAME TIME!I could go on, but the Extra Credits team has already articulated my thoughts better than I can. I do have a few closing thoughts though. First and foremost, yes the gameplay isn't very good. You run. Your gun. You take cover. Enemies spawn in obvious spots. It's all very early 2000s shooter. However, that's all done on purpose to highlight and critique those very same generic shooters. Second, this is strictly a single player game. There is no multiplayer, nor should there have ever been (although maybe they also tacked it on just to show a point). Finally, and most importantly, I'd like you all to remember: you choose to play this game. You choose to do all those horrible things. Really, the only way to win this game is to stop playing it. But even then, you'd still be losing.

content:
Posted: July 23, 2014
												Spec Ops is an interesting game. It's a Third-Person Shooter with a story that is designed to make you think about your decisions. My problem with the game is that the major decisions are out of your control. You have no say what-so-ever in the outcomes of them. The few decisions that you are given are minor and ultimately have no effect on which of the 4 endings of the game you will receive. The endings are based on which of the 4 options you choose at the very end of the game. I have a hard time feeling bad for a decision that the game chose. The "obvious" answer to some who say you do have a choice is to just not play the game. That is a poor answer to me. You would not experience the rest of the story or the game unless you watched it on YouTube, or had someone tell you what happens. The actual combat in the game is typical TPS or FPS run-and-gun. I would recommend playing on Easy if you do decide to play the game. You do not lose or gain anything other than achievements by picking this option. I would play the game for the story and not the gameplay.All in all, it is an interesting game, but I would never say that I had fun playing it. Get it if you are just absolutely interesting in playing. I would recommend waiting for it to be on sale for $5 or around that area, for the 5-6.5 hours that it lasts.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 21, 2014
												Spec Ops: The Line is a seemingly average game at first glance -- linear third person shooter with a selection of current-gen guns that features a near-invincible protagonist killing everything that moves. What's driving the difference between the metacritic score and the rave reviews is that this game has a really entertaining storyline -- it's an homage to Heart of Darkness / Apocalypse Now. The antagonist is even named Conrad. It tries to shine perspective on the choices that you make as a soldier to survive, but if you just want to gun everyone down like I do, the game is still rewarding for that.The graphics are alright, although the sepia tone gets tiring after a while. The sound and music are good.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 19, 2014
												This is hands-down one of the most emotionally engaging and impactful games I have ever played. What starts out as your run-of-the-mill third-person military shooter, quickly turns into a psychological and unique story unseen in modern gaming. The developers did an incredible job of truly making you feel the weight and consequences of the decisions you've made in not just this game, but every game you've played previously.I personally do not enjoy shooters; this is precisely why I loved this game so much. It is not only addictive and engaging, but it's a smart and expertly crafted critique of the very genre it represents. Nolan North's performance is extremely impressive, even given his pedigree. I cannot recommend this game highly enough - if you want to experience something unique and memorable, you need to play this game. I finished it in one sitting it was so addicting.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 26, 2013
												Don't let the title and genre mislead you - this is not your typical war-themed shooter. Spec Ops: The Line explores the horrors of war through its harrowing, psychologically jarring narrative while blending in elements of science-fiction with its dystopian vision of a sandstorm-ravaged Dubai (the setting itself being the real star of the game). The cover-based third-person shooter mechanics, while essentially lifted from Gears Of War, are tightly crafted and well executed enough for the action to fluidly draw you in over an engrossing 10+ hour campaign. A mature game with the brains to match its brawn - a solid A (9.5/10) and Game of the Year material.

												This game is indeed different. The story is very well done, and makes the game something special. The graphics and sound are OK. The action is good, with sufficient variety of weapons and situations. The one thing I disliked about this game were the somewhat broken mechanics. The cover is clunky, yet quite necessary to this game, and the same keys are used for wildly different actions, such as one key for vaulting and melee, and another for sprinting and cover. So sometimes you will sprint when you want to cover, and sometimes you will melee when you want to vault. It would be a 9/10 without this pretty glaring fault, so I'm giving it a solid 7.5/10.

content:
Posted: January 24, 2015
												It's a relatively short game. You can finish it pretty quickly. It's a beautiful game. The graphics are excellent, especially the environmental effects. It's got some good squad-support mechanics, a bit of RTS mixed in when it comes to combat.Where it really stands out is the story. This is no CoD shoot-em-up against the russian/korean/middle eastern/chinese terrorists who pose a threat to MURRICA and the good guys have to go blast 'em with MUH FREEDOMS until they're all dead and a soaring bald eagle screams overhead just before the credits.No, this game takes a much more realistic approach with a small squad in unfamiliar territory as you watch the effects of combat and decision-making on their mental state and relationships.Of course, it's a game, so it is a dramatization. But it's an excellent game. Your choices have an effect. It wasn't made so you could choke on McDonald's while singing the Star-Spangled Banner. It was made to show that on the inside, there is no glory in war.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 20, 2014
												This was a surprisingly engaging game. It looks generic, but Nolan North's voice acting is a nice touch and the story is a change from other military shooters. It's not original by any means, but the characters are interesting enough to play this one until the end. It takes about 8 hours to complete, and the game is well optimized so high frame rates can be achieved if V-Sync is turned off. The graphics are amazing, as well as the audio. The gameplay is a standard third person cover game, but it works perfectly so that's not necessarily a bad thing. Ammo is scarce at times, so you'll find yourself picking up enemy weapons a lot in order to have a functional weapon. I'd recommend buying this game, it's not a Call of Duty ripoff - but instead more character focused... a story based around the effects of war and the hard choices that are made. What is right and what is wrong?

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 22, 2013
												Very few games have made me feel like Spec Ops: The Line has. To me, it seems like an abundant number of shooters are growing increasingly generic. Producing gore for gore’s sake, and scarcely ever using mature or violent content to actually make you feel for a character. Spec Ops: The Line is the embodiment of evidence that not all games adhere to this philosophy. Sadly, the game is also highly overlooked. Many people have, despite its obvious superiority to popular shooters, never been aware of its existence. The story is well written and quite riveting. Spec Ops: The Line places you in inconceivable situations, and imposes morbidity regardless of choices you make. For example, if you were given an option to save either a close friend or a hundred innocent people, you will feel equally awful no matter what you choose. While this might refrain from appearing unprecedented, Spec Ops: The Line does so in a believable setting with well-built characters, conveying emotional and vivid events. I thoroughly enjoyed the graphics. The yellow sands contrast well with the blue and purple hues used throughout. Many scenes are beautiful, the conjunction of ruined city and serene sand paints a stunning landscape. Spec Ops: The Line’s port (the game originally debuted on the Xbox 360) is adequate, most elements perform perfectly, however there are a few things that were not implemented well. Apart from minor issues, the game looks and plays fine on the PC.Unfortunately, Spec Ops: The Line does not innovate further. The gameplay mechanics are similar to an average third-person shooter. Acoustics are acceptable, but far from memorable. I felt that even slight enhancements on these elements would significantly improve upon the overall experience. Nevertheless, it is still enjoyable to play. Overall, I highly recommend this game to anyone who is seeking a shooter with a fantastic story. To me, a good story is always imperative - this one supersedes many others of the genre. Spec Ops: The Line is usually on sale during special events. That being said, I think it is completely worth it at full price, especially considering the quality that rivals many full-priced games.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 23, 2014
												If you're looking for a game whose plot makes Camus and Kafka seem positively *uplifiting*, well, here you go.  It's both well-written and utterly depressing.  This is *not* a generic feel-good heroic rah-rah shooter.  In a way, it could even be termed "survival horror" in the purest form... the horrors that emerge from within the human mind and form, rather than mere zombies or mutants.Mechanically, it's fairly prosaic -- third-person, cover-based, regenerating health, a variety of modern weapons, a couple of companions generally.   The checkpoint system is somewhat obnoxious but checkpoints are fairly common, and if you repeatedly fail the game will start providing you with extra ammunition and even suggest lowering the difficulty (which you can do at the cost of restarting your current checkpoint).It is not a terribly long game, so don't be expecting a 40-hour run. There are some technical quirks like encrypted INI files (google around for decryption / encryption utilities) with settings that the menus don't let you change otherwise (notably, depth of field, radial blur... and mouse acceleration!).  It's a minor inconvenience since tools do exist, but just be aware.The recommendation cannot be generic, as this game is *definitely* not for everyone.

content:
Posted: January 24, 2015
												It's a relatively short game. You can finish it pretty quickly. It's a beautiful game. The graphics are excellent, especially the environmental effects. It's got some good squad-support mechanics, a bit of RTS mixed in when it comes to combat.Where it really stands out is the story. This is no CoD shoot-em-up against the russian/korean/middle eastern/chinese terrorists who pose a threat to MURRICA and the good guys have to go blast 'em with MUH FREEDOMS until they're all dead and a soaring bald eagle screams overhead just before the credits.No, this game takes a much more realistic approach with a small squad in unfamiliar territory as you watch the effects of combat and decision-making on their mental state and relationships.Of course, it's a game, so it is a dramatization. But it's an excellent game. Your choices have an effect. It wasn't made so you could choke on McDonald's while singing the Star-Spangled Banner. It was made to show that on the inside, there is no glory in war.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 2, 2016
												A wonderfully, terrible third person shooter that you can finish in a weekend. Spec Ops: The Line will draw you in with its generic box art and derivative gameplay, and then flip you on your head and stomp on your gut because you're a terrible person. The game opens in medias res with (all together now) a helicopter chase scene wherein you mow down other helicopters with an infinite ammo minigun, until one of them crashes into you. flash back to the beginning where our protangonists are on a mission to find out what happened in Dubai after a record sandstorm hit. You fight some local insurgents, explore some interesting sand infested buildings, and slowly learn about a CIA operation and a rogue American Infantry unit. After about an hour of run-of-the-mill shooter story, things start to get a little strange. First you start killing other American soldiers in self-defense. Then you're trying to figure out if you can trust the CIA agents or not. pretty soon you're raining down white phosphorus on an entire platoon of your fellow soldiers and innocent civilians!Wait what?Yeah, it only gets better from there, and the best part is the story ramps up so smoothly and the gameplay is integrated into that story so well. The loading screens start off with helpful hints about gameplay then slowly shift to unnerving messages directed at the player in real life. The animations of the characters even change over time! The early game will see Cpt. Walker punch or rifle butt a downed enemy to finish him off, but later on he starts getting more viscious by shooting them in the face while they beg for mercy. Even the mission objectives are integrated into this mad scheme. They start off like any other game: go here, defend this, eliminate that. But then they change: obey, murder, and so on.Often in games we see a sort of cognitive dissonance between what the game is telling us about a character and what the character actually does in the game when we're controlling them (see the Tomb Raider reboot). Spec Ops is both a great example of how to not have that problem AND is the greatest display of cognitive dissonance AT THE SAME TIME!I could go on, but the Extra Credits team has already articulated my thoughts better than I can. I do have a few closing thoughts though. First and foremost, yes the gameplay isn't very good. You run. Your gun. You take cover. Enemies spawn in obvious spots. It's all very early 2000s shooter. However, that's all done on purpose to highlight and critique those very same generic shooters. Second, this is strictly a single player game. There is no multiplayer, nor should there have ever been (although maybe they also tacked it on just to show a point). Finally, and most importantly, I'd like you all to remember: you choose to play this game. You choose to do all those horrible things. Really, the only way to win this game is to stop playing it. But even then, you'd still be losing.

content:
Posted: October 9, 2012
												This is one of those games where it's best to play it without knowing ANYTHING at all about it. Unfortunately that means you can't/shouldn't show or tell why it's a great game in screenshots, videos, or reviews. I bought this game blind, not even knowing it was a third-person shooter and not a FPS. Just heard a bunch of people saying "you gotta play this, it's not the generic brown military bro-shooter you think it is." Otherwise I would've ignored it entirely as I'd been doing.I'll say this: the game looks beautiful, it's well-acted, and the gameplay is solid albeit rather conventional cover-based action. It's also pretty darned short. It took me 9 hours instead of 6 on Normal because of repeated dumb screw-ups brought on by the fact that the controls for exiting cover are a little screwy. If you move perpendicular to the cover's orientation...you leave it. But if you can get this for < $20--which you can since it tanked on account that one can't convey why it's unique--it's a must.

content:
Posted: March 27, 2016
												2-sentence review : I came to that game from the hype about the difficult moral choices, but there was none (the marketing guys probably never played any RPG in their life). However, I got a solid TPS with a lot of action and an incredible scenery, packaged in an intriguing but ultimately disappointing story-telling.Pros :- Amazing & original scenery : Dubai lost in a desert storm- Even better, the scenery is well exploited and brings a lot in the gameplay- Solid TPS gameplay ; nothing out of the ordinary, but all the basis are there and well implemented- Good story-telling, but...Cons :- ... But the story doesn't make much sense (yup, I've read all the explanations and they still don't explain correctly a lot of things ; I guess it's just hard to fit what the authors wanted to do with the mechanisms of a shooter game)- Worst, the story setting isn't explained clearly, which made me know less than the protagonists and let me wondering what's the heck was going on during almost all the game- The story setting is actually some kind of Science-Fiction stuff ; it's not bad in itself, but it would have required some clear explanation (in very short : Dubai has been taken in a several months long desert storm and people are going to die soon)- We have to find some intelligence during the game that explains a bit more what happened in Dubai ; some of this stuff is hidden, which means I missed some and it made the story even more muddy... :-/- It is in no way tactical (not a con for me, but it's advertised otherwise, so better be clear on that)Bonus Note :Major Spoiler : I'm going to explain why the moral concept completely failed for me.There's no choice that matters, and worst, no choice I felt implicated into.Story-wise, the point of no return is when our character kills by mistake civilians. However, I had spotted these civilians and consciously did my best to avoid killing them by firing the mortar on the opposite side of where they were standing. The game still killed them all by making that particular mortar explosion much much bigger than the previous ones. Bummer... :-/I also almost never shot 1st, died several times for that, and thus it completely voids the idea we're the bad guys...

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 27, 2013
												This game right here is freaking sick !!! amazing graphics, amazing story.The cover mechanic is ok, kinda like GEARS of WAR without the ridiculous health. i really wish their were more commands for your teammates apart from kill or heal, they get right in the line of fire and get down easy on higher difficulties. The enemy AI can be dumb sometimes, but make great use of cover use real military commands, swear alot and offer a good challenge on higher difficulties. the game's level are well designed i was expecting sand dunes all over the place, with a couple buildings or two, but instead got a semi-destructible environments such as shooting glass to drop sand on enemies, turrets mowing down certain covers.They did a fantastic job on the interiors; the glass, the carpet, plants, piano etc... everything had detail and time put into it. I like the background music alot, there is nothing like a shoot-out with classic rock in the background, it gets you pumped up(recommend putting the music on 10, sfx and voices on 7 amplifies does moments to a whole new level). The choices in this game are minor, but satisfying in a weird and evil way each worse than the other; like capping a guy with a magnum to prevent him the harsher death of being roasted alive might make you cringe, feel guilty and even put your controller away for a while ( or mouse, i like controllers better although admitting mouse & keyboard offers greater accuracy). I made every evil choice in this game and enjoyed it and in the end died like boss(felt like a true Sith lord), dying in the end  is optional this is not a Bioware game after all. Forget about that metascore of 76, this game is a 8.5/10 in my book and thats just because the storyline is kinda short and i never could find someone to play with on multiplayer, there are no multiplayer achievements so i did not worry about that. In the end none of these matters, it's just a vessel for a great story. No amount of buggy controls(extremely minor in this game), glitches (seems like i randomly could not take\switch cover )should keep you away from such a great storyline.

content:
Posted: August 17, 2014
												Spec Ops: The Line is one of the only games I would ever recommend putting on the lowest difficulty on the first playthrough.This is not a game you play for the amazing gameplay, although it's nothing worse than generic. I liked it. Different strokes for different folks.Were it to be judged purely on its design and mechanics, Spec Ops: The Line would be pretty forgettable, but it has an ace in the hole. And it's a bigg'un: a story so out of the blue in its direction and message that it's a miracle, a major publisher put this game out at all. What you think you're getting- particularly if you only play the demo- is another gung-ho gun-wielding slice of Americans saving the day by killing all the brown people. What you actually get is a slow, spiralling descent into madness of one man, that wears its Heart of Darkness/Apocalypse Now inspirations proudly and uses them to forge a modern-day commentary on the type of video game you thought you were going to play. Captain Walker is no tiantic Call of Duty avatar who can murder a thousand people and walk away- he falls apart mentally, visually and audibly as the game continues, his professionalism is stripped away and raw ego left exposed. "Tango down" becomes a more chilling, "Kill is ♥♥♥♥ing confirmed" as the game confronts you with issues of culpability and responsibility. It's incredibly unsettling and so out of the ordinary for the modern gamer that to most people, this might be thrown aside in disgust.This is no Gears Of War/Army Of Two clone. This is the story of one man who loses himself to the brutality of war.To the open minded and for someone who wants a great story mixed with an unsettling message, this is a MUST OWN.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 26, 2016
												This was actually a very surpising game. I really did not think I would have liked it as much as I did since I am not a huge fan of modern military shooters. The main reason why I tried it was because I kept hearing great things about the way the narrative was handled and I was not let down. It does not glorify war or the military and it actually felt like the developers put a lot of time into developing the story. In this game, story came first, and the multiplayer aspect came second, and that is something that is a bit rare in shooters nowadays. So without further ado,  here's my review. Gameplay  The game is a third person shooter and has all the stuff that is considered standard in third person shooters nowadays: cover system, grenade projectory, blind shooting, etc. In terms of shooting, the game really brings nothing new to the table. It is all pretty standard shooting and the enemies provide a decent enough challenge. The player does have a squad that they can order around, but it pretty much boils down to the player telling them to just focus on a specific target or throw the occasional flashbang. A fun little mechanic, but nothing that is very innovative for the genre.At times the controls can be a bit clunky and I have died a few times because my character got stuck in cover, but it doesn't detract that much from the main game. Since the shooting is a bit standard and the controls are a bit clunky, the multiplayer really is not that great, so if that's what you're looking for, don't get this game. In terms of gameplay, it really isn't anything revolutionary. Story This is where the game really shines, and people who have played the game would probably tend to agree with me. It actually does a great job at providing a mystery for the player to figure out and the reveal is very well done.  The main idea of it is that sometimes it is not always clear what decision is the right one, especially in times of war. It shows a much different "war" than we are used to seeing in video games. One where not all the player's actions are not necessarilly the right or wrong choice. They are choices where, at the time, you thought for sure they were the right decision. (Or you thought for sure they were the wrong decision, if you're a bit sadistic.) The characters are actually pretty well developed too. I'll be honest, when I first started the game, I thought the characters were going to be the typical military charracter that we find in lots of media. You know the trope I am talking about, the "I aint got time to bleed" guys. I was pleasantly surprised to see that while the characters were tough, it wasn't their defining trait. The interactions they have after some of the situations they get into are quite believable and the player's squadmates have pretty distinct characteristics. When they disagree with the player, they let it be known. I like how the developers handled this in particular because in the beginning of the game when they disagree with the player, they just give you a certain look or something subtle. As the game progresses and the squad starts to see more and more horrible things, that subtle look of contempt turns into more obvious displays of their dissatisfaction. The strongest part of the story have to be both the main character (the player) and the villain. The trauma that a soldier experiences in times of war is depicted very well in the mental state of the main character. The way they depict how the main character starts to question the morality of his actions and why he is even fighting is just something that you don't typically see in games that are centered around the military. And that's really all I can safely say without completely spoiling anything.  TL;DR  Pros  - Great story- Great character development- Interesting environment- Some genuinely great music thanks to Radioman Cons - Standard gameplay for a shooter- Controls are a bit clunky- multiplayer is not the greatest.Overall, I believe this game is worth buying for the story alone.

content:
Posted: July 6, 2013
												Wow!  What an amazing, story-driven, combat game.  It was like watching a serious and brutally viscious war-gone-bad movie on acid.  The character voice-acting, imho, is the finest yet in all of gaming.  The music is top notch.  The weapons are real military weapons, and there's many.  The visuals are excellent.  The many diverse combat sequences are wild, intense, and sometimes challenging.  Some combat scenes and cutscenes are downright crazy, shocking, and memorable.  I think this is one of the best games ever made, and it's bound to be a classic.  I highly recommend it, but only if you can stomach brutal war images.

content:
Posted: December 18, 2013
												Expecting a standard military TPS with some hamfisted morality message, I was instead treated to one of the greatest psychedelic war stories in recent memory.  The most I can say without spoiling anything is that Spec Ops: The Line calls to mind the 2nd half of Full Metal Jacket, Apocalypse Now, or the burning oil refinery scene in Jarhead.  It is a very well thought-out and self-aware commentary on the insanity of combat, culminating in an immensely satisfying and mindscrewing gauntlet.Mechanically the game is solid, although snapping in and out of cover is occasionally more awkward than it should be.  Ammunition is scarce even on the default difficulty, and nearly every encounter is designed in such a way that the tools for victory are always available if you have the right strategy.  I never felt like I was dying for any reason other than my own lack of skill.  Checkpoints are infrequent, so the sense of tension and reward when you clear a particularly difficult segment is tangible.  Compared to most other recent shooters this was a huge breath of fresh air.  Spec Ops respects your intelligence enough to assume you can figure out a way to shoot everybody in the room if you just put some thought into it.I bought and played this game on a whim (and because of a particular scene which you may have seen on Youtube involving incendiary weaponry).  If you've seen the same scene and felt the game was ruined/spoiled as a result, I assure you it's not.  That particular incident garnered a lot of publicity but only occurs about halfway into the game, with much more potent and interesting twists ahead of it.I still don't feel like a hero yet.

Posted: May 17, 2014
												At first sight when you never play this game to the very end; small levels with quite linear gameplay so a normal rail shooter by today’s standards, worth a look if you like the shooter genre (as you can tell I am not a fan of the genre)When you finish the game: The story just changed everything and makes you think the game is epic because of very unexpected changes.I really enjoyed this game because I hate your typical mainstream hero shooter game with 0 relation to the real horror of warfare. This game emerged me so much I played it from start to end in 1 day a rare thing for me. Your 2 AI companions are surprisingly smart, rarely had to save them from a stupid action + I can order them to focus on my target and I experienced 0 bugs. I only talk about single player but there seem to be a few co-op missions and multiplayer for which I (and most players) did not care.Graphically it was great, the choices and rare use of environment are appreciated but don't mean or change much. The story is the big plus for this game and was well executed. There are no good guys in this game only realistic humans. Wish there were more shooters like this but with more meaningful choices and bigger levels.At the discount I bought it, definitely recommend it. I never recommend shooters at full price they don’t last long enough and offer little replay ability in this case maybe once for a special difficulty, some collectables and the different endings.

content:
Posted: August 11, 2014
												Spec Ops: The Line is a 2012 third-person shooter video game developed by Yager Development and published by 2K Games. It was released on 26 June 2012 in North America and 29 June 2012 internationally for Microsoft Windows, and the Xbox 360 and PlayStation 3 consoles.n Spec Ops: The Line, the player controls Captain Martin Walker, who is sent into a post-catastrophe Dubai with an elite Delta Force team on a reconnaissance mission, where they find dead American soldiers. Upon the finding, Walker declares that the team's mission has changed, and that they will search Dubai for survivorsSpec Ops: does so many good things right, but falls short from a masterpiece. While the game is a brilliant set-piece of PTSD and the true horrors of war, it falls short as a game in whole. While the story, soundtrack, voice acting, visuals and overall quality is amazing, it's gameplay is just so generic and boring. Nothing new will be seen here, unfourtunately. The game is a third-person cover shooter game, with no originality. The cover system and gunplay are mediocre at best, and this is a real drawback from it being an amazing experience in all sectors. But, I really don't want to get too much into such details, it's just something you've played in a hundred other games, let's focus on what's so amazing about this underrated game.The story. It may sounds like something trivial, because people have high standards these days, amazing gameplay, amazing graphics, amazing this amazing that, you get my point. This game is narative driven game, and that's it. Multiplayer is shallow and unstatisfying, but this isn't the point of Spec Ops. It's a game that sets one goal, and one goal only. To trully showcase the Horror of war. War is a gruesome experience that really scars the human mind, and while me and you won't probably fight in one, this game has a trully shocking way of showing us just how brutal things can get between the gunfire. It will surely have a last impact on you, it did on me at least. The game starts pretty standard, a turret section that's pretty bland and boring, nothing too over the top here. But once the game kick off, things start to get heated. We start in the shoes of Cpt. Martin Walker, voiced by Nolan North. The game starts off with you and your squad mates being sent to the new destroyed Dubai, to investigate and search for survivor, call for reinforcements and get back home. Those are your only orders, nothing more. But things get out of hand once Walker gives to order to  open fire on the enemy. This thing will become more relevant down the line, since this game has set out to question one simple thing, Who is the enemy?. And it will teach you that thing, once you complete it.Being developed on the Unreal 3 Engine, the games shines mostly. Dubai is a super showcase of glowing sand, vibrant interiors and a feel of depth and complexity. But it's all just a shell to hide all of the horros that lay ahead of your journey to destruction. The game will soon present to you the brutal, and extremely graphic violence of when things get ouf of hand when people mentally breakdown and can't tell the difference between good or evil. It's amazing, especially since this game breaks once and for all the trope that all enemy's in video games must be shot down immediatly without question, and because they are different or russian/middle eastern. It's superb, to be honest. In the end, since I could talk about this game for hours and hours, even though it's a short, but it's an intense ride, and filled with guilt. Never, ever I have felt such guild after playing a videogame. Like, really. Videogames that make you feel guilty? How is that? One might ask. Well, it's quite easy. This game does not reward you for shooting everyone in a 100km radius at the speed of Clint Eastwood, it will break you down as fast as the protagonists. It's amazing how well the story is crafter, considering at the end of the day, it makes you feel human, it makes you question so many things. Superb. Honestly, superb. In case you don't want to hear all of my rumbling, I will list the things that I enjoyed and disliked about this game and give it a rating.The goodAmazing storySuperb storyBreathtaking visualsRetroactive enviromentUnique settingIncredible soundtrack/voice actingMoral and emotionally heavyThe badGeneric gameplayMediocre gunplayShort lenghtCookie cutter multiplayerNo replay valueThe cover mechanics are a bit awkwardI give this game a 8/10 rating, thanks to so many good elements in it, falling short, unfortunately to such a generic gameplay. Amazing overall nonetheless, I highly recommend this game to everyone.

content:
Posted: February 4, 2015
												8,5/10Spec Ops The Line is an underrated game. If it was advertised like AAA titles it'd be one of best games of 2012.The story is good, giving choices and hcallanging (if played on highest difficulty). Some of moments that occur in the game are morally questionable. In real life they are considered war crime's. The game shows brutality of the war in small manner and complete lack of emotions from the oppressors.I recommend this game to everyone looking to have a great time in the game that is not casual! It can be completed within 7 hours.+ Interesting story with multiple choices at every occasion.+ Not boring with decent combat. Cover system reminds of Gears of War series.+Shows stuff that those pseudo-war games aka CoD and BF will never show.+ Not casual, it is easy to die.+ Low system requirements.+ Replayability value  (different choices throughout the game)+ Co-op+ Nice graphic quality...- ... textures could use higher resolution- too sensitive mouse controls, you need to set it to 1 ongame options at 2000DPi mouse to be playable- Linear story with choices. Yes, those choices are insignificant sometimes they are wrong.Neutral:Game lasts 6-7 hours.Out of all these advantages and disadvantages I recommend this game. Normally it costs 20€, it's good price but if you're saving money get it while on sale for 5€ ;) Regardless of which option you choose, it will be money well spent.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 2, 2015
												A brutal storyline that shows how dark and sadistic human nature can be if that separates survival from death, or just greed and comfort from sharing. Paired up with a relatively short but compared to today's standards completely normal playtime and the well known generic TPS gameplay, it's a masterpiece where you won't even notice that the gameplay feels like the 1000th same TPS, because the atmosphere and the narrative is what gets you hooked on Spec Ops: The Line until you finish it. With all it's horrors and misleading delusions, it could be among the best fictional war movies with a perspective that slowly blurs reality with losing your mind to all the terror happening around you, with you, with your loved ones up to and beyond a point where you can't make a difference of what really happens and what is a delusion, and who is responsibile for all the death and suffering shown in shockingly real instead of overdramatizing and coloring it like the rest 99% of games do. It really is a masterpiece of psychological themed games. It makes YOU, the real person do horrific things and question your own morality, MAKES you want to find a twisted way to justify your decisions and depending on your choices, it possibly makes you feel like a monster.Other games tried it too but it was either too black and white or overly dramatized, almost cartoon-ish to keep the player reminded about this is fiction, and always gave a reason not to worry or feel like you are doing good in some way, even if that requires doing bad things.You'll question yourself here eventually, where were the line you shouldn't have crossed, and how long ago.And this is unprecedented in the gaming history.Throw in all this to the postapocaliptic feeling of Dubai being swallowed by the desert, with the people there being isolated from the world and are starving to survive any way neccessary.And the greatest thing is, that this isn't a selfish way of the developers to make their sick gore fantasy (partially) come to reality, everything you see is part of a greater puzzle, and once you see the whole picture it just blows your mind and leaves you in shock for minutes.TL,DR: It's pure genius worth mentioning (and being recommended) among the top games, even looking back more than two decades in the genre.
