content:
Posted: December 15, 2016
												ONLY SINGLEPLAYER REVIEW:I just finished the singleplayer. I already knew the story, the plot. But even with that knowledge, i wasn't prepared for this. This is masterpiece. The game market is flooded with modern military shooters, there are casuals like CoD, and Battlefield, or mechanicaly realistic like ARMA. But this. This shows what real war is. What PTSD feels like. The game is a third person cover based shooter, with all the right elements. there are around 10 weapons, some might say it's too few, but they are perfectly enough, since all of them feels differently and each has different firing mode. Using the covers feels smooth and natural. Shooting aswell. When you kill with a headshot, or get a multikill the game slows down a bit, you didn't just killed. You killed with brutality. Only thing i didn't like is the cluncy controls. Feels like i'm playing with controller settings on a keyboard. For example: Space - Use cover/Sprint/Drop down (from ledges).  R - Reload/Pick up weapon. This is PC. We have enough buttons, on our keyboards to use. It is annoying, that i want to run along a wall, and my character uses it as cover, or i want to pick up a gun, but i reload instead. Some positivity in the end: You have choices at certain points of the story, and i love that it wasn't: PRESS X TO DO THIS, PRESS Y TO DO THAT. The game not always tells you that you have a choice. But deep inside you know.

content:
Posted: April 19, 2014
												Spec Ops: The Line.To start of with I throught this game was just one of those games were everyone would ignore it, and it would just quietly past by in the corner. But no this game is a hidden gem, here is why.Spec Ops The Line is a 3rd person shooter, with a cover system. But Unlike the rest, this one is more story driven, this makes a massive difference to the way this game plays.Graphics, this game looked stunning when it first came out, and it still does now. The Devs really put alot of attension to detial and passion into this game..The charators look good and they animate very well, voice sync is pretty much perfect to lip movement etc. The guns you can tell what they are, but remember this is a 3rd person shooter.Finally the envirment, just wow, however word of warning which comes with a spoiler alert...This game turns...Dark and sinister quite quickly, now I did warn you that this one is different.Sounds, the weapons sound belivable, but when playing I m spending most of my time not getting shot than I am admiring the sound of the weapons. Explosions have a bassy smooth boom to them, the envirment itself when not in a fire fight is quite quiet all you can hear is the wind howling around the buildings and things moving about in the wind.Music is quite unnoticable during quiet stages of the game, just your standard low intensity tranquil music, till later in the game were the music turns, darker... the firefights the music does pick up but its over showed by the firefight itself.Last, voice acting. These are fantasic I mean they would be, this is a story driven 3 rd person shooter. You can even hear the mood in the voices they are that well done.Story, without giving away too much, this game is based in a storm ridden dubia, you are leader of 3 Spec ops trying to find survers and the "dammed 31St"..But what you acturly find is..a place full of chaos, and civial war. This is all I m wanting to give away.Gameplay, as I said this game is a 3rd person shooter. To that point it plays like any other, it does have a cover system and the controls are tight mostly( althrough they are simifyed for consles) so one button does 3 different things basicly..This can cause issues but I get that.As for its gun play it is very tight, and when one knows how the game works and how to move and get the cover system to work with you, than you are in for a great time. I almost forgot to mention about the basic squad commands, but your AI ( and the enamy ai) is pretty good they can take care of themselves and take down thier foes.Now as I mentioned this game takes a turn, and turns very dark..What I mean is this you get some very odd choices, even through the gameplay is liner its not do this this this..It lets you chose. But in general the devs want you to see the choas and the darkness here, and its that which gives this game a personalilty.ConclustionSpec Ops the line is a great 3 rd person, and it has a great story to back it up, and the way it delivers that story, with great voice acting..Its a great expierance and a joy to see it.This 3rd person is going to be very hard to beat and has alot going for it I feel.8 out of 10

												First of all, let me say that I would love to give spoilers during this review but I will not, I will leave a clean version and then black out the spoiled version (which will basically contain the whole story line)CLEAN VERSION: This game, fights like Gears of War if you've ever played that game, graphics, sounds, everything is a solid and I did not see any bugs during my play through. The storyline is what makes this game a true and EXCELLENT game despite its flawed and boring combat system, the story will keep you on your edge for about a good 3-6 hours, constantly while playing you keep delving yourself into the story until you know you have to beat this game; this game has a lot of twists in it that it will have you leaning to your monitor and when you finally see the end of the game you will gasp with awe and be in shock (which I rarely get shocked or am in awe as I am a very mellow person)SPOILED VERSION: You, Adams and Lugo are all 3 Delta Operatives that are sent into Dubai to find Komrad (a general) and over time you realize Dubai is a utter♥♥♥♥♥♥storm, you try to find everything out and keep pushing you and your men forward. You accidentally kill civilians with a mortar, but you keep going on and at the end of the game, you realize everything you did, all your actions to "help" the people of Dubai, you realize your guy that you're playing as is MENTALLY ILL which is a SICK TWIST but a great twist and you realize as your guy starts to flash back everything that he talked to corpses, made up scenarios as his troops stood by questioning him but followed his orders.You would buy this game for the story rather than the gameplay. Simply amazing.

content:
Posted: March 31, 2016
												Short, but satisfying game. Even after 4 years, the graphics look nice and the engine works well (no bugs encountered). What made me love this game is the soundtrack, playstyle (getting headshots 24/7), and the story, although the last one is a love-hate relationship, as it shows the somewhat real army life - gorey and brutal, rather than running around killing people (though you have that too, from time to time). Also, the cinematics are pretty amazing, especially towards the end of the game - destroying buildings whilst flying a helicopter - what more could you want? You're allowed to make multiple choices throughout the game, which affect your sanity. The only drawbacks for me are the 30 fps/720p cutscenes, and the length of the game (6 to 12 hours), but that can be justified by the quality of the game, and the multiple choice scenarios. Overall, it's a great and original TPS, definitely deserving more recognition. If you haven't played it, make sure you get it on a sale, it can go for dirt cheap, and it's definitely worth playing.

												Certainly the best modern military shooter I have ever played ! Fluid gameplay, tactical and makes you stop and think for the best way to engage your problems or your enemies, instead of just running around and shooting, squad based strategy so you don't have to worry about godlike npc's who never die because you fail your mission if your squad breaks and the storyline makes the game a whole lot to play for. Spec ops: The line, title says it all, sometimes there is a line that must be crossed for the greater good, question is, is it really the greater good? Or is it just a vision of a madman?

content:
Posted: May 16, 2015
												PROS:- The Story... While I didn't get that wave of "le feels" the simplistic reviews professed, this game was definitely heavy and deep. The story is brilliantly crafted and the characters are well voice-acted, ultimately resulting in a plot that does not make you question so much "morality" as some players have said, but breaking the fourth wall and questioning the validity of "choice", particularly in games.- Excellent shooting, guns feel weighty and effective. Ammo reserves are small forcing you to be tactically prudent and careful. - Graphics are artistically beautiful. On the technical side, they are aging a bit, but I got my 60 FPS.- Levels, albeit very linear, are designed very well. Absolutely beautiful with some destructable objects, some of which can be used to harm foes.CONS:- Arrays of unfriendly and abysmal checkpoints. This game was made in 2012 and there are still checkpoints before cutscenes and scripted events, making you sit through them until the "skip" option pops up about ten seconds later.- Multiplayer is a throwaway. This didn't bother me, but it might some. The devs did not intend on implementing multiplayer until the publisher forced them to, so don't let it rub off on your overall opinion.- Don't like turret sections? Too bad! About a dozen of these son'-guns in this game. - Some story elements seem shoe-horned, such as the unavoidable war crimes you commit perhaps intended to make the player feel remorseful.- Squad commanding is a rather two-dimensional feature. You didn't miss out on a lot, but it would have been nice to see something with a little more Republic Commando/Rainbow Six-esque depth.- Probably the biggest complaint of all is that this was obviously a console port. The mouse smoothing and acceleration can only be disabled by decrypting the .ini. Some buttons are annoyingly bound to a myriad of actions. Sprinting, taking cover, and reviving your buddies is all bound to the same button and you can't change that, trying to perform one action and performing another has gotten me killed dozens of times. OVERALL:Had it not been for the story, it's just another modern military FPS with all the guns you recognize in a pretty environment. With the story, it's fairly impactful, sort of a reflection on games in general. The six hours it took me to complete justifies the $6 it was purchased at, but definitely not the normal $30.

content:
Posted: March 7, 2014
												]You are here, because you want to feel something, you are not... A hero!Can a game put a blame on player for his actions? Can it mock the whole industry of so called "Military Realistic Shooters"? Can a game present main protagonist as not a player but his\her personality and deconstruct everything we knew about shooters so far?Spec Ops: The Line proves that it can be done! First of all, if you looking for fun in this game -- FORGET IT! There is no fun, this game has zero fun, and it feels right. that how this game should be; with both main hero and player, game gives both cognitive dissonanse and WTF feeling... Game puts blame on player, but also educates him. It hard to talk about this game without spilers, and I do not wish to spoil this expiriense for you.Know this, game communicates with player. And main hero represent not what you would expect. It build to deconstruct genre and gamers belives. Or maybe just the other way around, in embrasses player and his\her principles and gives a tool to stand a ground supporting second personality?Let's just say, that imagine if you would go into a strip club or bar, expecting to have fun! But the moment you enter, something starts to feel wrong, but at the saame time right -- like this is how it is supposed to be. You sit throug routine, when suddenly before closing, something rewealing strikes. And afterwards you expereinsing something that you never experienced before, of rarely. And you feel like♥♥♥♥♥♥ you want to kill yourself... For what? For doing everything without mistakes. You made zero mistakes, and you was wrong! But was you? Maybe you just missed your actual goal, and acidently droped into a club\bar, ye never meant to be? How to interpretate this experience you got? The only way is to come back and do this again. But it is hard... And not really that rewarding for the second time. And you can't just explain this feeling, you can only interpritate it with your own belives. And game gives you tools to do so! Think about it, like you want, choose the fate of main protaganist and yourself.But at the end, playing Spec Ops: The Line is like diving into a void, that sucks all good, leaving only darkness, pain and misery.

Posted: December 15, 2016
												ONLY SINGLEPLAYER REVIEW:I just finished the singleplayer. I already knew the story, the plot. But even with that knowledge, i wasn't prepared for this. This is masterpiece. The game market is flooded with modern military shooters, there are casuals like CoD, and Battlefield, or mechanicaly realistic like ARMA. But this. This shows what real war is. What PTSD feels like. The game is a third person cover based shooter, with all the right elements. there are around 10 weapons, some might say it's too few, but they are perfectly enough, since all of them feels differently and each has different firing mode. Using the covers feels smooth and natural. Shooting aswell. When you kill with a headshot, or get a multikill the game slows down a bit, you didn't just killed. You killed with brutality. Only thing i didn't like is the cluncy controls. Feels like i'm playing with controller settings on a keyboard. For example: Space - Use cover/Sprint/Drop down (from ledges).  R - Reload/Pick up weapon. This is PC. We have enough buttons, on our keyboards to use. It is annoying, that i want to run along a wall, and my character uses it as cover, or i want to pick up a gun, but i reload instead. Some positivity in the end: You have choices at certain points of the story, and i love that it wasn't: PRESS X TO DO THIS, PRESS Y TO DO THAT. The game not always tells you that you have a choice. But deep inside you know.

												So Spec Ops: The Line was currently on sale when I picked the game up and I thought, hey this doesn't seem to bad I've heard good things about this game so I'll give it a shot. The graphics on the game are nice and in my opinion fit the game well, there is times where you can see the odd things bugging out or not loading properly but that does happen in games so that doesn't really bother me. The story telling is amazing and multiple times I've found myself shouting holy♥♥♥♥♥♥or what the ♥♥♥♥ in to the events that just happened, There are points where you feel like you have no choice but to make a specific decision, then you realise it may not have been right, it opens a side to shooters where it isn't just oh you're doing whats right yay guns guns guns pew pew america, Honestly this game is worth the price if you can pick it up for not too much, I would heavily reccomend this game and advise playing it if you would like a different perspective to a shooter rather than you're doing what's forced on you while you slaughter A.I

content:
Posted: March 31, 2016
												Short, but satisfying game. Even after 4 years, the graphics look nice and the engine works well (no bugs encountered). What made me love this game is the soundtrack, playstyle (getting headshots 24/7), and the story, although the last one is a love-hate relationship, as it shows the somewhat real army life - gorey and brutal, rather than running around killing people (though you have that too, from time to time). Also, the cinematics are pretty amazing, especially towards the end of the game - destroying buildings whilst flying a helicopter - what more could you want? You're allowed to make multiple choices throughout the game, which affect your sanity. The only drawbacks for me are the 30 fps/720p cutscenes, and the length of the game (6 to 12 hours), but that can be justified by the quality of the game, and the multiple choice scenarios. Overall, it's a great and original TPS, definitely deserving more recognition. If you haven't played it, make sure you get it on a sale, it can go for dirt cheap, and it's definitely worth playing.

Posted: November 28, 2013
												Certainly the best modern military shooter I have ever played ! Fluid gameplay, tactical and makes you stop and think for the best way to engage your problems or your enemies, instead of just running around and shooting, squad based strategy so you don't have to worry about godlike npc's who never die because you fail your mission if your squad breaks and the storyline makes the game a whole lot to play for. Makes you think why do wars exist, who kills and who gets blamed, what war does to a mind of a soldier who faces death everyday and lives to tell the story, what are the costs of following your orders and how far can you go to achieve your goal, or a madman's goal, how insane can you become and what's real and what's your imagination, how far can you go and who can you protect. Spec ops: The line, title says it all, sometimes there is a line that must be crossed for the greater good, question is, is it really the greater good? Or is it just a vision of a madman?

Posted: May 5, 2015
												First of all, let me say that I would love to give spoilers during this review but I will not, I will leave a clean version and then black out the spoiled version (which will basically contain the whole story line)CLEAN VERSION: This game, fights like Gears of War if you've ever played that game, graphics, sounds, everything is a solid and I did not see any bugs during my play through. The storyline is what makes this game a true and EXCELLENT game despite its flawed and boring combat system, the story will keep you on your edge for about a good 3-6 hours, constantly while playing you keep delving yourself into the story until you know you have to beat this game; this game has a lot of twists in it that it will have you leaning to your monitor and when you finally see the end of the game you will gasp with awe and be in shock (which I rarely get shocked or am in awe as I am a very mellow person)SPOILED VERSION: You, Adams and Lugo are all 3 Delta Operatives that are sent into Dubai to find Komrad (a general) and over time you realize Dubai is a utter♥♥♥♥♥♥storm, you try to find everything out and keep pushing you and your men forward. You accidentally kill civilians with a mortar, but you keep going on and at the end of the game, you realize everything you did, all your actions to "help" the people of Dubai, you realize your guy that you're playing as is MENTALLY ILL which is a SICK TWIST but a great twist and you realize as your guy starts to flash back everything that he talked to corpses, made up scenarios as his troops stood by questioning him but followed his orders.You would buy this game for the story rather than the gameplay. Simply amazing.

content:
Posted: February 16, 2014
												First thing I want to say before writing this review is that if you dislike strong political statements or anything that breaks the 4th wall you should not play this game. Spec Ops: The Line is set in Dubai after the Country was destroyed by sandstorms. You are a 3 man Delta force unit sent in to find out what happened to a US army 33rd Battalion. Sooner rather than later you find dead American soldiers scattered around and are attacked by an unknown enemy foce that will be revealed later into the game. After the first encounter with the enemy insurgents you are met with a radio broadcast that signals you to US soldiers who have been captured by the enemy. You don't get there in time however and two of the soldiers are executed. One soldier remains who is slowly bleeding out and tells you about the 33rd battalion. Your unit moves into the city and it's all gone to hell.The story of this game is absolutely magnificent and the way that the developers played it out made it even better. The length of the story was perfect and if they played it out anymore than they did it probably would have been boring and would have seemed to be dragged out. It's short, with about 6 hours play time but it has some replayability with the achievements and the unlockable difficulty.There are multiple things to destroy in this game that makes sand smash everything which can be quite hilarious. There are also choices that the player needs to make which can effect what happens with the story and the direction the game is going in. There are also multiple endings which I will leave you to find out. When facing these decisions the player will go through and question themselves when choosing which one to do. There are also a lot of dead bodies in this game, a lot. There are also a lot of burning bodies and burned bodies.Graphics on this game are great, the scenery is very nice and even though most of it is sand and destroyed buildings it still looks great. Even though I played on medium settings it still looked good so if you have it on High with AA turned to the highest it would look amazing.Overall this game is a 9/10 and I highly recommend it to anyone who likes third person shooters which are different and want a bit of variety.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
												A nearly flawless third person shooter.Let's get the story out of the way. You play as Captain Walker who, along with the other two guys, is sent to the destroyed city of Dubai in order to investigate a distress signal by the missing Colonel Konrad. Pretty soon you discover that the city is not empty and is filled with some civilians as well as the AWOL U.S. 33rd Army battalion which was supposed to evacuate the city after being deployed in Kabul. You then quickly proceed to battling and killing your country-men. Neat. I'm surprised this German developer didn't get any heat from critics yet for giving you the ability to kill U.S. army men. Along the way, you unravel the mystery as to what exactly is happening.The scenery is quite breathtaking. The Unreal 3.0 engine makes character models and distant vistas look crisp. The desert is so well made that it reminded me of the Uncharted 3 desert. You also get to leave foot prints in the sand. There are no texture pop ins and every texture is pre-rendered. However, the amount of video options is limited. The engine provides no DX10,11 or anti-aliasing for that matter.The game itself plays like a solid A/B action flick. There are some grand action set pieces, there is plenty of dialogue, there are opportunities to sneak up on enemy and there are some grave choices to be made and alter game in the process.One of the most essential components of the game is the A.I. and boy is it good, both friendly and A.I. The enemy soldiers will communicate with each other, they will give out orders, they will attempt to flank you and sometimes attack you from both sides at the same time, they WILL run away and jump away from your grenades, they will retreat, raise alarms, call for back ups, they will also throw grenades pretty accurately and they will do suppressing fire as well. However, some handpicked A.I. will just stand there without taking cover, just waiting to be shot. The reason is that if they are standing on the glass or next to a mountain of sand behind glass, they can be killed with the force of the surrounding environment.This game forces you to think when dealing with the enemy. They aren't supermen and they aren't pushovers either.As for the friendly A.I., well just about the only way that you can order your teammates around is by telling them to attack this guy or that guy or flash bang them. However, once you do give the order, your team mates will do their best to take out the indicated guy either with regular rifles, sniper fire or grenades. At times, I saw my team mates stand their own ground pretty effectively. This feature is unparalleled with many shooters, wherein even IF you are a part of the team, you are the one getting shot at most and you are the one having to kill every foe. (COD ahem)You also get to collect intel and figure out what happened to the populace and Dubai in general after the biggest sand storms decimated the city.Something about the gameplay feels right, I can't quite put my finger on it. You can only carry two weapons and a handful of grenades. The ammo is always scarce so the game forces you to not waste ammo. I also like how any assault rifle magazine will be out of ammo after just a few bursts - it's all pretty realistic. There is no evasion button and there is no prone button. The constant sand storm atmosphere creates a hostile and extreme environment and the sound of sand storms is quite deafening. Also, what's awesome is that once your frag grenade explodes, it also creates a collateral sand fog which stuns the surviving enemies which can be plucked one by one.As far as the weapons are concerned, well, every other weapon has a secondary feature. The M-16 or whatever has a silencer, so does the pistol, the AK-47 has a three bullet burst feature, the sniper rifle has a 8x, 16x zoom feature, etc.The thing that quite often DOES mess up the gameplay is the sprinting, that's right. When you go forward press "space" for sprinting (default) and then let go of "space", Walker will just keep sprinting for an indefinite amount of time. And if you want to stop immediately, you have to press "S", to back up. So I decided to switch to the good old "shift" for sprinting instead. It sorta helped but the running still feels consolish, especially when you try to make sharp turns and attempt to take cover while being shot at. What sucks again though is that the crappy consolized controls made "shift" stand for both sprinting AND melee. It's like, seriously devs? You could not allocate a separate action key for melee for us, PC gamers? we do have a keyboard, you know.Oh about that, when you are running toward cover and getting shot at, your character will automatically slide towards cover for about 2-3 meters, which is pretty neat because the game does not force you to press the cover button again. That's what they should have done in Operation Raccoon City instead of just adding automatic cover that doesn't work half the time.I've also noticed that the devs put a lot of effort into level design which look as if they were taken from real locations. The flamboyant hotel rooms, the flashy lobbies, the elegant living quarters, the vanity statutes, the artifacts displaying wealth of the city now gone - all bring an engaging dystopian feeling. At times, there are also numerous ways of advancing and flanking your enemies.The wobbly cross-hair is quite neat. The only time your aim is remotely steady is when you come out of cover, however if you sprint and then attempt to shoot, your aim will be all over the place. Thus, every other kill feels like a small accomplishment. If there only was no regenerative health. The good thing is that your team mates cannot revive you when you get shot up. However, you can pick them up and they can pick each other up.I should also add that voice acting in the game is quite exceptional.As for the multiplayer, well, it delivers on many levels. The crappy sprinting is still there, so it's best to not run at all. You get to customize your character as you progress. You get to choose 15 perks as you progress. These range between being invisible on the minimap while sprinting, increasing your protection against explosives, reducing the cross-hair wobble, increasing your weapon damage, increasing your mini-map (radar) range, etc. As for the weapons, there are 5 SMGs, 9 Assault rifles, 4 shotguns, 4 sniper rifles, 6 handguns, 2 machine guns and RPG. The levels are pretty balanced too. Some levels feature active destruction and temporary sand storms that reduce your speed, visibility and accuracy. Sometimes these storms cause collapse of nearby structures so you better stay clear.However, if you are playing a 30 minute match and then all of a sudden "lose connection to server" all your progress is going to reset. Now this sucks big time because after playing for some time, I "lost connection to server" and reverted back to level 1. Now this is a certainly good feature to discourage rage quitters and quitters in generals but it sucks big time when you lose your experience points and perks.All in all, this is a pretty solid M-rated (there is torture, mutilated bodes, up-close violence and executions) third person shooter with some new gameplay elements and addictive multiplayer that will keep your interested. Here are the minuses:1. Limited video options.2. No Co-Op campaign. (This could have easily been a 2-3 player co-op game).3. Medium-length campaign. 15 medium-length chapters.4. The pistol cross-hair sucks. And you can't turn it off.5. No way to turn off indicators when in cover. (Indicators that tell you if you can swap cover; it's cluttering the screen)6. Crappy consolish sprinting.7. Limited destruction.8. Bad grenade explosion animation.9. Having to press "space" for springing, taking cover and reviving team mates.

												Spec Ops : The Line is TPS set in the ruins of Dubai. It attempts to bring a fresh blood to the TPS games using the sand theme and with choices that reflect the harsh reality of war. Pros-Graphics and optimization -Good scenery and atmosphere-Interesting story-Voice acting-It has some replay value to it-ChoicesCons-Biggest problem for me was the gameplay. Controls get in your way a lot of times and aiming feels weird for some reason.-AI is dumb as ♥♥♥♥. For both sides that is. -Some parts of story are really cliche. Well, it's a war TPS so this shouldn't be news for you. -At times I felt like the game tried reaaaally hard to make me feel like a terrible person.Finally, this is a solid overall shooter but don't expect anything perfect, it has it's flaws. If you like TPS games you should give it a shot as it offers some quality time with it's story.74/100

content:
Posted: July 10, 2014
												Finally I get to play this controversial game (because I want to read the book "killing is harmless" solely written on this game).It is a short game, I finished it (at least the majority of the narrative) in 5 hours. But the gameplay, to be honest, is mediocre if not horrible. Plus Multiplayer is dead. Graphics, let's say, mediocre again because it is really not impressive. The whole weight of the game goes to the narrative. It is really a anti-FPS shooter game. I even doubt if they actually made the other aspects of the game deliberately awful so as the player can focus on the "shock" of the narrative. Thus it is most fun to play this game with the expectation that this is just another shooter like GoW etc. The choices (and how impotent they are) the player are asked to make reminded me of Mass Effect series particularly 3 and its ending. The psychological manipulation and guilt-driven portrayal of war all aims at making the player uncomfortable (possibly contemplating). The hero is the villain. It is not the usual "there is no clear cut between hero and villain" rehtorics, but the entire dichotomy is destroyed. There is no justice in a war and it does not matter which side you choose. When the soldier is bodily on the battlefield, the gore and brutality does permanent damage to him. It affects the protagonist to its core while the he strives to maintain his legitimacy through construction of himself as the hero regardless of what he had done to many lives. Now I am going to read that whole book, if I ever got the time.

content:
Posted: December 31, 2013
												This could be just another war shooter, among so many others, but don't be fooled by its look. While in other war franchises where you take place as a cold-blooded soldier, used to face death in all its ways, this game makes you actually feel what is like to be fighting a war, not only physically, but also mentally.The main character, as the game progresses, becomes more and more injured, and his mind, at a moment, starts to twist and be filled with guilt, which causes him to have hallucinations that will affect the behavior of you and your team, from professional soldiers, to out-of-control psychotics, thus affecting gameplay.As of the mechanics, it follows the classic formula for third person shooters: precision aiming, cover system, etc. Being squad based, it gives lots of emphasis on colaboration within your team, and to survive you must work together with your  teammates. Ammo is very scarce, as you are often required to scavenge weapons from fallen enemies. Enemies comes in varied forms, from light soldiers to heavy-armored juggernauts.With a good plot, and a good concept for a war game, give it a try, as you won't find such a realistic approach in another game.It's worth every penny.

number of helpful: 6 of 10 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 7, 2014
												One of those rare third person shooter game with great visuals, great narration, great voice actors and incredibly well written story.Spec Ops The Line never attempts to be great at gameplay. In fact, it tries to be as simple, as streamlined and straightforward as possible. What you need aside of shooting enemies (well , this is third person shooter game after all), is to make a good cover of yourself using environment as a shield. The game literally forces you to hide all the time, and only come out to make a progress. When in battle, AIs force you to hide like 95% of the time and they do a great job at it. There's no upgrades, skill trees, side quests, open world or anything your regular gamers want from today's games. Learning curve is minimal at worst, at best it is no curve at all.This simplicity, however, what makes the game good. It really fits with the game's linearity and storyline that challenges your moral/ethic code.You control Walker, one protagonist, and go on a simple rescue and evacuate mission. During the process, there's many background stories that develop into more complicated moral-driven situations. Throughout the game, I was forced to make some decisions I would not have made in real life - where I have the options, where I have the luxury to do many things I want.. during peace. In a war, all is different. The atmosphere made in game is just perfect depicting that condition - you feel yourself in Walker's shoes - see and think in his perspective. Very rarely does a game try to do that.That said, the game also has stunning visuals where I have no complaints at all. You see a detailed landscape of post-apocalyptic Dubai, along with the occasional sandstorms. Graphic optimization is also great, I've got no problem running this maxed on my laptop rig that's mediocre at best. Audio wise, it's more than enough to accompany the visuals. When fighting, it feels realistic. The sound of guns, explosions, environment sounds are well made make you feel the tense and heat of the battle. Furthermore, with decent voice actors, it makes game's narration just perfect - each characters' dialogues are performed with heart.Game's pretty short, 7 hours should net you almost everything. Nevertheless, as a whole, Spec Ops The Line is a great experience that all gamers should feel themselves. A game that starts great with great end.

content:
Posted: January 22
												Spec Ops: The LineBought game because of positive reviews on Steam. Was not impressed, and I am a military buff for games and documentaries and thought provoking material. Truly am surprised how so many people are 'mind blown' by the storyline that does not give you any power to truly choose. Most likely people who've thought little of war and its horrors, and the philosophy of human nature, might find this 'mind blowing.'Short review first. Scroll down for random rants.Story: Concept was somewhat daring, dark and unique. More importantly, a topic not explored which is why I give it a lot respect for. But ultimately the medium used brings it down, as well as poor pacing of monumental decisions that are made in the game as well as the execution of the story as a whole. Tip: There's a reason this game was not very popular.Gameplay: Good assortment of weapons. Cover system was sometimes clunky. Basic aim for the head gameplay. Enemies types were literally a handful. Boring and reptitive overall.Graphics/Enviornment: Some of the cutscenes were downright terrible looking for some strange reason. Some cutscenes looked good. The textures were bland as expected of a B-Budget game.Verdict: Ultimately, the game did provoke thoughts of actions and consequences. But the game itself did not do the story justice. And the story felt very unreal because of it. The pacing of the story and its content was slow, and slammed all the end. The end was decent. But all throughout the game they make it seem like 'you had a choice' but I really did not feel like I did. The repetitveness made me just want to finish it. Overall I was disappointed after reading the reviews, and if I had another chance I would skip this game. I only paid 5 bucks, but also had to invest 6 hours that did not have a worthwhile end at all.Random Rants: A strange game.Tries to portray a morally wrought story. That is supposed to evoke realism and grey warfare.The moral choice outcomes were somewhat thought provoking thankfully since thats what all the other reviews on here praised and reccomended the game. Though on one big choice you did not know the outcome after you had done it, so it was not really 'fair.' You thought you had picked something, but a different outcome than anticipated came out. Which is good and bad since it makes things not linear, but also means your decision was based on bad information. So I did question what choices would I take had I been a delta operator in this strange unrealistc storyline.Some of the Bad Rants:Then it puts you in an unrealistc settings(the sky scrapers are all abnormally huge and the city is half buried in sand. The local populace is apparently huge in numbers, all males, and armed to the teeth out of nowhere.) unrealistc combat (takes 3-5 body bullets to kill, or 2 bullets to the head) and apparently the main characters have indestructible bodies. (Sliding down sky scrapers, smashing their spines on rocks and metal beams, mid flight catching themselves with bungee cords, walking away without a scratch,  ziplining from sky scrapers.) Makes you feel like youre watching a hollywood action movie. Not a video game trying to evoke the horrors of war and the reality of war.Some of the Good Rants:The dialogue between characters after making moral decisions was realistic and thought provoking.Without spoilers, the enemies you fight leave a bitter taste in your mouth as you find out who they are. Not used to something like that in US games.The combat feels fluid and clunky at the same time. The slo mo effects when getting headshots feel nice. You spend most time just headshotting everyone.The US would never sent 3 delta operators to 'rescue' a battalion. They dont operate in 3 man units. Second they never had radio contact with base. Which would never happen.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 9, 2013
												Spec Ops the line is a cover based third person shooter about a group of soldiers that are sent to rescue someone in the decaying ruins of Dubai, a city drowning in Sand. But much like the sand destroys the city, the mission itself slowly decays into madness as your character and his two subordinates try to do what's right. Character progression is well done as the unit slowly comes to face the horror of their own actions.The game itself is quite nice, the environments are exactly how I would imagine a weathered down Dubai to look like and the game gives you plenty of quiet moments ot appreciate your surroundings. Gunfights feel a lot more realistic too: Cover is your best friend and fights are won through tactical thinking. Enemies will try to pin you as their partners move around the flank.Only downside is that the checkpoints are kind of far in between which gets really noticeable on Suicidal Difficulty. Overall a solid gameplay experience with more depth than any of the recent AAA shooters could hope to display.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 12, 2013
												Wearing the trappings of a modern military shooter, a genre that has become the industry's main enemy of creativity and thoughtful exploration of important thoughts on the hero fantasy and graphic violence, Spec Ops: The Line works its deep cover with such intensity and unflinching honesty that it demands the attention of any gamer who takes games as an art form seriously. I almost passed this one by due to its superficial premise and appearance, but I am very glad I did not.Following in the footsteps and perfecting the ugly tenor of games like Kane & Lynch and Far Cry 2, this brutal exploration of PTSD, gaming's indulgence in violence, and the cost of war pulls no punches in challenging the player to confront what--if any--redemptive or meaningful value there is in parading through a foreign landscape as a hero of war. Forced to make ugly decisions that will demand you square with the game on an emotional level and shouted down for every mistake you will inevitably make, this is the slap in the face an industry drenched in blood and rewarded violence needs. Marking a new era in mature gaming, Spec Ops: The Line is a challenge to us to return from our thoughtless murder and enter into a new era of self-aware, meaningful interactive experiences.

content:
Posted: September 25, 2013
												When I picked up this game, I thought I was buying another faceless brown-and-bloom military shooter on the cheap... you know, Call of Duty/Modern Warfare knock-off with a ruined Dubai gimmick.What I got was so much more. I wish I had purchased it at full price, because the developers deserve much more money than I gave them. This game was fantastic for the story alone. I can't give more detail without spoiling it, but with only a few games have I ever felt this affected or deeply moved by the gameplay. There's a lot of shooting and some of it is repetitive, but it's vastly over-shadowed by the narrative and it's damned beautiful the whole way through. If you haven't played it, I really recommend picking this game up immediately... it's SO much better than it lets on and one of the only games I've ever played that manages to prove its point through every facet of the gameplay.In fact, one of my favorite moments I've ever had in a game happened during one of The Line's loading screens... that's a tall feat, considering. It's that good.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 14, 2014
												I haven't reviewed this game, thats odd. Well,  better late than none at all..A TECHNICAL NOTE:This game was designed for WinXP, and therefore you need to set the combatibility options accordingly. Detailed explanation can be found at PCGamingWiki.com. There is also a bug regarding previously saved games, this causes the game to crash. The fix for this is also found at the wiki.SECONDARY NOTE:Since i'm aching all over, i'm just copying the review i made for this game on Greenman Gaming. (Lazyness FTW)__________________________________________________________________Valtheknight | Feb. 6, 2014 | Review of Spec Ops: The LineOh dear... Well i can for starters say that i'm at an disadvantage since i last played the game through about a year ago and i completely forgot that i bought it from Greenman. Also since there is a "credit"-gain from review so.. Might as well.Before i start, i really should mention that i really cant remember everything about this game. Because of the one year gap. So most of the stuff i say will be mostly about my personal experiences and should be taken with 'nth amount of salt. (Since i'm a little bit biased..)Well the first thing that needed to be done with the game, was to actually get it to run. Since it had some startup-problems with it, this caused some grey hairs at first, but a quick venture into the promised land of PC-GAMING WIKI. Helped to resolve that problem quickly. Unfortunately, since the game uses encrypted options files. Tweaking other aspects of it will prove difficult, if you wish to, for example, change the FOV.(I don't remember if the game was updated to include an FOV slider later on.. Again i last played it at the start of 2013.)Well i think that's the mandatory technical jabber out of the way, onto the game itself.The story is in itself deceptively straight-forward, it starts of with a group of soldiers, (Delta-Force if memory serves correctly.) On a mission to investigate what happened in Dubai after it was supposed to have been evacuated, before some heavy-duty sandstorms started wrecking up the place.And that is pretty much the easiest explanation of how the story starts, i really can't write about it that much since i feel i would be doing it no favors. Instead, i will only say that the story only gets more darker and stranger the further it goes. With some actual character-development and i don't mean the "put-points-to-sht-to get-the-biggest-deathcck" -way, but in the storytelling sense. Some of the stuff you see and hear the team say and do really start to show later down the line.That's enough spoilers for the story part, next!The gameplay is pretty standart 3rd-person cover-based shooting and that is pretty much the thing that kind of kills the novelty-value almost instantly, because people will automatically make references to any other Military shooter almost instantly. I on the other hand right now started thinking about the Normandy landing scene on Medal of Honor:Allied Assault, nicked almost to the T from Saving private Ryan... Oops Digressing statement.Later down the line, the game has a turret section, and another, and another yet again.. That kills the feel a bit, since you wonder "Why did it give me another turret section? Can't i just run around and shoot them in the head instead?" Actually, at one point you can, but it makes it a bit harder. But don't get me wrong, the helicopter segment at the start of the game (and the redo of it later) was well executed. I cannot really say the same from the rest though.Anyway, the biggest sin, i feel from the game-designs part is the linearity. It shows from the start and it carries through to the end. The strangest thing though... I noticed on my last playthrough that i had missed options in the story. All because the game told me to do this, instead of that and now i need to download it again to see the other parts i missed. Since i feel, "if i missed that one so obvious, what others i missed ?"CONCLUSION:Even with its story, The Line seems (to untrained eye atleast) a generic 3rd-person shooter. Even the changes the characters go through during the story, kind of brush by with a big red sign over their head saying "FEEL SH_T". And some of the stuff does have some shock value, but it loses even that rather quickly. All and all, the story (if flawed, yes flawed. Shoot me if you disagree.) is the only thing that is interesting about this game. Is it enough to carry it? No. Is it enough to make it stand out from the rest? Yes. Is it actually worth playing? Maybe.__________________________________________________________________I gave the game 80/100 on Greenman, and at second thought, it might have been a bit too generous. I should have given it a score middling 60-75, since it had all the classic modern era shooter problems. But as it stands, it is still worth the money.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 27, 2015
												Spec Ops: The Line does for games what Heart of Darkness did for books and Apocalypse Now did for films. I do not write a lot of reviews, but this one deserves it for being a great game, showing war from a unique view in modern gaming.This is a game that really shines on it's story and narrative. It pulls no punches and unflinchingly shows you every aspect of war that most other games brush over. This game provokes emotional responses that other games try to avoid and involves the player with the decisions faced in conflict situations, and sometimes those choices are not good, or have no good answer at all, but you are still forced to make the hard decision.It starts off drawing you in as another 3rd person cover shooter, but changes as the game progresses so that you are less interested in the action and more interested in the story, which is masterfully done. It reveals just enough as you are going through so when you get to the end, you remember all those hints that were tugging at the corners of your mind, and catch yourself saying, 'I knew it!' On a replay, there are a lot of those subtle hints that you see that you miss on the first play, and it has been very well written that way. (Think Sixth Sense for this). The twist at the end is pretty clever and makes this game stand out from a lot, but it is not completely unexpected.The action set pieces are done well in the desert city environment and this comes into play in the game a lot, though it can feel a little bit forced sometimes. The whole 'My Squad vs the World' gets a bit tiring towards the end, as you take on just about every living person in the city with a gun. As I said above though, the importance of the action at that point should have faded away.Positives:  The narrative is the best in the business.  Involves the player.  The environment is cleverly realised and used in game well.  The achievements are fun to chase down.Negatives:  Short campaign.  Simple control system that is clunky.  Difficulty does not scale up as the game progresses.  Very linear story, given the emphasis on choice.  Pointless Multiplayer aspect.Conclusion:A well crafted and engaging piece of work. Worth the effort you put into it as you walk away from it with more than just the simple amusement. If you want just a piece of gung-ho action, avoid it, but if you want more from games, dont hesitate, buy it, and enjoy.

content:
Posted: August 29, 2014
												Ignored it upon release as I'd wrongly assumed it was another one-sided AMERRCUHHH, KILL THE TERRORISTS, BE A HERO game (the first 30 or so minutes kind of are, to lull you into a false sense of confidence and righteousness) but it quickly turns out to be anything but - throughout, and increasingly so, you'll be questioning whether you're doing more harm than good, and that's putting it lightly. Surprisingly deep and clever. Several references to Heart Of Darkness which it seems to be based on.Lots can be said about how well it manages it (I ended up writing an essay on the game for uni), but without spoiling anything, you'll feel like a monster by the end. In one small example, there's a part where you're fighting enemies in a shopping mall, with civilians hiding inside. I'd been fighting for roughly 10-15 minutes and hadn't seen a single civilian. An enemy ran down a hallway, and I chased him, ready to shoot back, when a civilian dives out from a gap and ran for cover. Before I had time to think, I shot them, and felt SO bad. It was clear that it was a mistake the game was counting on me to make, and I fell for it.Downsides: criticises military shooty games while being one (whether that works for or against it is up for debate), fairly unimaginative Gears Of War style cover/shooting mechanics.Overall: I really recommend anyone gives it a go, if they're into any shooter games, or are just looking for something different within the genre (hard to find, as anyone'll know). BUY IIIIIIT!(oh, and avoid multiplayer. the devs didn't want it in the game but the publisher got another studio to quickly hash it together, which completely misses/ignores the point of the story.)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 26, 2014
												This is basically PTSD: The Game.As a game, it's pretty standard.  You get into cover.  You shoot guys with guns.  Run to the waypoint to continue getting into cover and shooting guys with guns.  It feels fairly clunky to actually get into cover.  I felt like I had to hit the space bar a specific way to actually get into cover.  There are a handful of weapons in different categories like rifles, shotguns, small arms, snipers and heavy weapons.  Everything feels fairly generic with a few exceptions like shooting a part of the environment to dump sand on your foes and that's about it.  You can give orders to your team, but some orders only pop up at specific times and I could never seem to be able to use the attack order.  I was able to beat the campaign on the hardest availible starting difficulty in under 7 hours.  Again, as a game, it's pretty generic.As an experience, it's a completely different beast.  Never in my life have I played a military shooter that was this shocking.  If you thought the nuke scene and "no russian" from Call of Duty were hardcore, then you haven't seen anything yet.  It's really something you have to see for yourself and I wouldn't dare spoil it.  If I had to compare the story to anything, it feels a lot like the movie "Apocalypse Now" and if you've seen that movie then you should be aware of the levels of shock you are getting into...but even the story here goes above and beyond that.   Again, as an experience, it's quite unique.If you can get it cheap, do not pass it up even if you don't like cover shooters.  This is one game you need to see to the end...

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 24, 2014
												There are few times in your life when you will have the chance to experience something as outstanding as Spec Ops: The Line.The setting is the city of Dubai, a few months after it has been hit by a devastating sandstorm and an evacuation operation has apparently failed. The focus is on three US Army soldiers sent to find out if there are any survivors and getting caught right in the middle of a conflict between the 33rd Infantry Battalion and local CIA operatives. The story shows the atrocities that the protagonists have to commit during their mission and the descent of the main character into madness, as he realizes that there are no redeeming choices in his reality and he can't cope with his own actions. The plot contains parallels from various horrifying situations of real-world war zones, particularly the use of white phosphorus mortar bombs on civilian populations in Iraq and Gaza. At its core, Spec Ops: The Line explores the concepts of PTSD, cognitive dissonance, escapism and the idea that the main character is not the player's avatar but instead, the player is the main character's super-ego.The story is amazing and it is delivered superbly by all aspects of the game. The cutscenes, the direction, the characters' models, the tone and content of the voice acting (not only during scripted sequences, but even in the way the main character addresses his companions during battles), the animations (most notably the executions of dying enemies), the level design and even the loading screen text snippets - everything in the game shifts and transforms in order to serve the story and highlight the increasingly obvious psychosis of the main character, his increasingly violent tendencies, his inescapable and growing guilt, his detachment from sanity (and reality) and his companions' gradual loss of respect, trust and faith in him, as one of the premises of the game is revealed and confirmed ("Ιt takes a strong man to deny what's right in front of him."). The game embraces literally everything at its disposal and raises every expectation regarding what we should accept as character development from modern works of art.The graphics are decent, including realistic and detailed shaders, rich well-crafted animations, just the right amount of post-processing and destructible environments. It is one of the best uses of the Unreal Engine that I've seen to date. When you are inside the extravagant but deserted buildings of Dubai, the art style is often reminiscent of that of the original BioShock.In the sound department, the game performs excellent - the voice acting is simply outstanding, while the soundtrack consists of a post-rock soundscape that blends perfectly with the environments and the psychological state of the characters, coupled with a plethora of known pieces from various artists, ranging from Deep Purple and Jimi Hendrix to Björk and Giuseppe Verdi.The gameplay is that of a typical third-person cover-based shooter, with the right balance between cool (to keep you interested), surreal (to underline that something isn't quite right) and repetitive (to make you feel even more desensitized before it hits you). The levels often seem open but the level design is actually quite linear. The game's idea of tactics revolves mostly (though not exclusively) around finding a good cover, adapting by changing your position, drawing enemies out of their covers and some micromanaging with weapons, bullets and grenades. At no point do you get to choose where you are going to fight your enemies and stealth tactics, wherever applicable, don't make a lot of difference compared to just charging in. You can, however, drown your enemies using tons of sand that's trapped on glass roofs and other places.Where the gameplay shines is in choices: instead of presenting choices with a bland menu that's disconnected from the rest of the game, Spec Ops: The Line embraces them tightly and features them exclusively as part of the gameplay. In many occasions, the game organically recognizes the intent behind your actions without having previously made the choice (or all of your options) explicit. This not only helps maintain the cinematic feel of the game, but also forces you to ponder your choices as real actions with real consequences (rather than items in a menu) and, most importantly, it makes you question your previous actions and constantly reevaluate situations retrospectively, highlighting another premise of the game, the idea that apparently you had choices all along ("There's always a choice!"), but you kept going ("None of this would've happened if you'd just stopped."). There are four endings for you to discover and they are all well-made and perfect epilogues to what your actions say about the protagonist (and you) by the end.Some final things:-The campaign is 6-12 hours long depending on your pace, not particularly difficult once you get used to the gameplay.-After you finish the campaign, a variable portion of the game's events are left open to interpretation. Almost all possible interpretations have at least some plot holes or unconvincing details. For me, they are forgivable but your mileage may vary.-There is a multiplayer mode that I simply won't consider in this review, because this game is essentially its campaign mode and the very existence of a multiplayer mode defeats the point that the story is trying to make.-Some people have said that there are bugs (particularly sound-related ones, which can be overcome, as they say), but I can't comment on those because for me it worked flawlessly.And that's it. This is an extraordinary game and every developer should take notes, because Spec Ops: The Line demonstrates what games should aim to be.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 6, 2014
												SPEC OPS: THE LINE is more or less a critique of the tropes and mechanics that have come to define military third person shooters over the last several years, particularly the narratives those games tend to adopt. It doesn’t do anything incredibly unusual with those tropes, but that’s part of the point.Attempting to adapt Joseph Conrad’s HEART OF DARKNESS, SPEC OPS’s main selling point is its story which succeeds in pointing out how absurd the narratives of many military shooters are. It takes every situation in which the player has been forced to kill massive numbers of people and retells it in the form of a very un-heroic tale. The player follows a trio of Delta Force operators sent to find out what happened in Dubai months after a massive sandstorm isolated the city from the outside world with a platoon of U.S. soldiers and a lot of civilians trapped inside. As they discover a multi-sided conflict, things very quickly spin out of control as the Deltas try to decide who the bad guys are.You ever get the feeling some military shooters have storylines that are just reaching for an excuse for the player to shoot everything they see? You ever realize how rarely some of these games display things that aren’t hostile, and how they use leaps of logic in their storylines to make as many people hostile as possible? That kind of happens in SPEC OPS but with a neat critical twist that manifests more and more as the main characters become increasingly agitated with the situation and their own actions.Most of the time SPEC OPS delivers its themes through cut scenes and in-game dialogue, leaving the interactive aspect of it being a video game to the absurdity of the shooting itself, managing to mess with it in interesting ways as the campaign drags on.As a shooter, I don’t think I’ve ever seen a third person shooter as vanilla as SPEC OPS. It’s almost impressive really. You get behind cover, shoot guys with military guns, order two other guys to concentrate on targets, heal them with morphine shots -- absolutely nothing out of the ordinary. It’s like Yaeger Development was trying to make the most mechanically normal third person shooter ever just to critique the whole genre.This is true even visually. The player character looks as featureless as every other head-shaven military dude in video games and is voiced by Nolan North. Basically the whole game is brown. If you ask me I even think SPEC OPS’s utilization of Unreal Engine 3 plays into the theme. Tech-wise it looks a lot like UE3 games from 2006 or 2007 with relatively basic use of lighting and shadow and little post-processing to speak of.I’m not even sure if Yaeger intended for SPEC OPS to be fun. Later in the game there were definitely moments where I felt uneasy about continuing to play, where in other military shooters I’d just laugh at the absurdity. SPEC OPS drives this feeling in interesting ways. As he becomes increasingly haunted by his actions in the story, the protagonist’s voice clips turn noticeably angrier and darker during normal gameplay, and the mission objectives displayed on-screen slowly become influenced by that rage, driving home the brutality of what the player is really doing.Just like most military shooters these days, SPEC OPS only takes a few hours to complete, but the storyline actually feels worth revisiting and re-examining. It even leaves quite a bit open to player interpretation. It’s certainly deeper and more thoughtful than most action game stories.

The Definitive Military ShooterGem of a game. This is not your day-to-day stereotypic military 3rd Person shooter - the story is the key element of this game. It so brilliantly mixes up with the plot that you can't leave without finishing your first playthrough. The graphics are quite okay for a UE3 engine - the gameplay and the gun mechanics are just superb. MP is dead, sadly. A.I is quite unforgiving even at normal levels, so be sure to stand behind your cover everytime. Just buy this for it's fantastic SP.P.S. This review is coming a lot late from me; i know, but the game deserved another recommendation!

content:
Posted: February 21, 2014
												Excelente juego, con una historia infinitamente mejor, que cualquiera que podes encontrar en un COD o BF. Juega mucho con los conceptos de la violencia en tiempos de guerra, las consecuencias de los civiles inmersos en los conflictos y con como afecta eso psicologicamente a los soldados. El final esta espectacular, bueno "los" finales mejor dicho ... según que decidas a lo largo del juego se desarrolla y termina distinto. Las opciones ademas son fisicas digamos, no hay ningún menú pedorro en el cual tengas que seleccionar algo. La verdad que esta aventura belica es tan recomendable como profunda y eso habla mas que bien de ella.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 17, 2012
												Uma das grandes surpresas dos últimos anos, Spec Ops: The Line é um jogo que usa as convenções de jogos de tiro militares em 3ª pessoa para "enganar" o jogador, passar por "genérico" e de repente, puxar o tapete e pegar o jogador de surpresa com decisões fortes, uma narrativa psicológica e uma crítica direta aos outros jogos de tiro militares modernos. É um jogo *sobre* guerra, não *de guerra*; é o Apocalypse Now dos videogames, e não um filme do Michael Bay como Call of Duty. Já virou um clássico cult, e todo mundo que gosta de games precisa experimentá-lo, mesmo que não goste de jogos de tiro.

content:
Posted: September 23, 2014
												I went into this game expecting an entertaining third person cover based shooter. What I received instead was a story centered game focusing on the difficult and ethical dilemmas faced in extreme wartime as well as the effects they have on relationships and one's sanity. The story alone makes the game worth playing but add in the gameplay which is excellently done third person shooter style, the game morphs into a surprising addition to my favorite games. Story: 8/10 - Interesting and surprisingly emotional storyline following three special ops soldiers attempted rescue of hostages in Dubai.Gameplay: 6/10 - The gameplay is excellently done in the way that it is a deeply addictive third person sprint to cover shooter. My one problem is that it does get fairly repetitive and while playing on the more difficult modes does add to the challenge and enjoyability it does not lessen the repetitive feel of the gameplay.

content:
Posted: August 27, 2014
												I highly enjoyed this game. It has the best story I have encountered in its medium and it addresses the player and not just the in game character. It is dark, wastes little time (~6 hours on suicide difficulty), and delivers harsh consequences for choices that the character makes in the story. A large amount of enemies are killed but it is not a bro-tastic shooting game. These characters have hardships which are legitimate instead of being cheesy and tacked on.Its gameplay is standard over-the-shoulder cover-based affair, but I enjoyed the challenging combat (I only have played on the hardest difficulties available and cannot speak for the easier settings). While the ally AI is sluggish and lacks judgement, the enemy AI flanks and suppresses and is effective at sending you to the death screen.This is a painfully obvious console port, though.The controls are not terribly intuitive. Sprinting, melee bashing, diving into cover, and vaulting over cover actions are tied to two different buttons. Sometimes one action is performed when the other was desired due to how they are tied together. It will take time to get used to their cover system, especially on keyboard. It does its job but is a bit clunky.There are limited graphical settings in the menu, most noticably the complete lack of AA. If you want to remove those jaggies, do so through other means. The game otherwise looks pretty good considering that not much graphically seems to have changed from its transition from console to PC. The settings are especially nice to look at.I enjoy this game even while reminds me that I am a virtual murderer. A third runthrough is in my future.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 20, 2014
												The perfect third-person shooter. Not necessarily for the gameplay or the graphics (although these are very good) but for the flawless story that highlights everything that is wrong with modern military shooters, making you stop and think about all the things you've ever done in computer games in the name of entertainment, then turn inwardly and question whether it was all worth it, and what it has turned you into (yes it's harmless entertainment, but then why does that entertain you hmmm?). Everyone and their dog has positively reviewed this game, and for once it's not overeager praise heaped onto a speeding bandwagon, it's a fantastic peice of storytelling, basically the Citizen Kane of videogames, and genuinely fun shooter, which as you'll find out is a massive ♥♥♥♥ing problem you mass murdering psychopath! In a generation or two, people will look back and ask their parents "What was it like to live in a time when a self-proclaimed hero-nation's military goose-stepped around the word thinking they were putting wrongs to right, when all they were doing was ignorantly applying violence to an already ♥♥♥♥ed-up situation, which actually needed some clear thinking and civil discourse to address their issues?" to which you'll reply "That's a pretty verbose sentence for a 9 year old!". And then point them to this game. Which you shouldn't because this game is rated M for 'Madness'.

Support this kind of games which are really rare to see these days

												This is an amazing game. What really captivated me is the dark and very emotional, in my opinion, storyline. It may seem like a "U.S.A. saves the day yet again!" kind of game but it's actually not. It's kind of a thought-provoking game instead. The decisions and actions you take will have repercussions on you and your squadmates psychology throughout the game. A lot of "dem feels" moments as the story progresses. Visuals are also very nice in this game despite being a 2012 shooter, Dubai looks great despite being not very immaculate due to the sandstorm. The gameplay is fine though, just a third person shooter with very simple mechanics to comprehend.I really recommend this game for its storyline though. It just blew my mind, really. It makes you want to seek for answers and even more answers... What the hell is going on in Dubai? 9/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 19, 2014
												"It's about doing what's right.""We didn't have a choice."These are two lines of dialogue that will stick with you the entirety of the time you play this game. They stuck around for me, definitely.This game is an irony. Everything pushes it to be that. The Line explores the story of Agent Walker and his squadmates, Adams and Lugo, as they go deep into Dubai under the pretense of reconaissance. Suffice to say, it all devolves and goes downwards from there. Far downwards.I commemerate Yager's courage to create a game like this. The game conveys a message by putting everything right there in front of you. You question it. And it all comes out to a satisfying conclusion and reasoning as to why it's all there. There is no subtlety needed in war, after all, is there?I'll just leave it at that. Come into this game braced for violent, depraved imagery and you will come out with a new mindset on things.As for the shooting itself, it's formulaic and simple. It felt oddly fitting for the game; there's nothing extravagant other than headshots and grenades slowing down the game to accentuate the action.Executions, means of finishing off downed enemies so that they don't get back up, serve an interesting purpose; exhibiting the Agent Walker's newfound animalistic nature. They become increasingly violent as you progress through the game, and in no due time you will find Walker shoving the barrel of a shotgun down the mouths of his opposition and firing.The sound assets are exceptional, notably the background tracks. Only on occassion do rock or vocal tracks accentuate action. Most of the time you'll be fighting in ambience, making a somber mood. The music fits when it needs to.My only complaint with the game is the squadmates; the AI can be a bit wonky and orders fail to go through when they should, and you can only give said orders during certain times. The cover and by extension running system can end up getting you killed, as well.I didn't bother with multiplayer, so this review may be a bit biased, but you'll be looking at this game for the single-player alone, anyways. Give it a go. This game will resonate with you for a long time as it did for me.

content:
Posted: June 23, 2015
												Graphics: 10/10 (See your soul die in post-apocalyptic-esque Dubai!)Audio: 9/10 (Apparently Denny from The Room is fighting against you.  Constantly.  Aside from that, it's nifty how the main "heros" get hoarser and coarser as the journey goes along.  Also, awesome soundtrack.)Gameplay: 8/10 (Mostly getting to the next shootout area/arena, kill the guys, move on.  Basic but solid, and the locations are varied enough.)Controls: 6/10 (They get the job done, but I had a few avoidable deaths mainly thanks to the cover system.)Story: 11/10 (Holy. ♥♥♥♥♥♥)Overall: 9.5/10 (Get it.  Now.)EDIT: I forgot to mention the multiplayer, because the multiplayer is completely forgettable.  Skip it; the main campaign is enough. The story really carries it; it's really one of the best in any game I've ever played.  Without spoiling anything: it starts as a COD clone with worse controls and a kick♥♥♥♥♥soundtrack, and becomes . . . well, I wasn't ♥♥♥♥ing around when I said "see your soul die."

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 30, 2015
												Where to start... I guess I could begin by saying wow.  This game was a roller coaster from start to finish to distingush between what is right and wrong is literally impossible as every choice you make influences your squad and your future decisions.  No matter what you do you will feel like a monster even if its the only logical choice.  Now on to the gameplay:  The controls take a bit of getting used to but are fairly smooth there are times where controls get a bit messy especially when you accidentally vault over cover rather than melee an enemy.  These were fairly annoying at times but nowhere near game breaking.  The cover system is fairly well done with smooth transitions in most cases.  Aiming can be a bit difficult but all you need is a gun you are comfortable with and its easy enough to hit targets.  TLDR:  It's worth the the time to play it and will make you question every decison you make.

content:
Posted: November 22, 2016
Smart writing saves average shooterSpec Ops: The line is a bit of an odd beast. It starts as a very average 3rd person cover shooter. You get to hear the usual gung-ho callouts, and slaughter the usual terrorists. Then, somewhere an hour in or so, the story starts to pick up speed. And what a story it is. Unlike the vast majority of shooters this isn't a story about heros slaughtering evil goons to save the world. This is a story about actions and their consequences, about atrocities commited in the name of a greater good. This is not a game for 18 year old kids who still think war is a fun adventure. Or maybe it is. Maybe it will make them stop and think for a few moments. Maybe it will make them read heart of darkness.For the adults, if you can look past the average game mecanics, it's well worth playing.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 25, 2013
												This game has its faults, but I'm glad I stuck with it till the end. Anyway, one of the strongest games I've played this year. I kept hearing it was dark, but it goes way darker than I had prepared for. It disturbed me enough that I've lost some sleep over it the last few nights.The way they handle illusion of choice is pretty interesting. Early on in the game you're given a choice which leads to 2 legitimately different outcomes in gameplay (battle vs. stealth) and how your squad reacts (failing to save civilians vs. failing to save CIA operative). So later in the game when you're under time pressure and forced to make bad choices, you wonder in the back of your head what the other options were (even if there were none).
