number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 8, 2014
												Right off the bat, I'm gonna say 6/10. This game, while it has an amazing story, was what a cover-based third person shooter was not supposed to be. The story about the three American soldiers sent in to find out what's going on in Dubai was just fantastic, but the gameplay just doesn't do the story justice. If they made a movie about just the story mode of this game, with little to no gameplay involved, it'd be a pretty good movie; probably an 8/10. It's only benefit is that the game is so short, that the story can at least be acknowledged. At less than 5 hours long, the gameplay for the game starts off like any other cover-based shooter, but eventually turns to be ridiculous as even in normal mode, you're spending 3 clips of ammo for a heavy machine gun into the head of an enemy foot-soldier. Why? Because helmets protect them from headshots, and the enemies ALSO know how to use cover. They also use some gimmicks here and there to keep you interested, but it's not enough to get past the horrible gameplay they made. I'm still recommending it, but only due to the story. Just watch it in a video, or play easy mode. You don't want to be playing this any longer than you have to.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 9, 2015
												Well, I finished this game almost at once, so we can kinda say it sucked me in. Let's start with a little summary of the game.Spec Ops: The Line is a rather linear TPS with a couple of places you can make your own decision between♥♥♥♥♥♥ and even bigger♥♥♥♥♥♥ And you'll feel♥♥♥♥♥♥in the end. The story:Delta Force sent to Dubai for a recon mission that quickly turns into a rescue mission, then into a "shoot everything that moves" mission. It gets confusing at times, but the end (which I won't spoil you) helps. It's...not what you'd expect. You start out as your standard US Soldier shooter with the grizzled veterans shouting commands, shooting baddies, being badass, but that quickly turns around. You are just a piece of the chess game of the forces behind the scenes. To give credit to the game, the story of Dubai getting hit by sandstorms, and getting Fallout'd is rather cool. And the visuals match, but bit later about that.Through the game I felt I was playing a TV series. Heck, it'd make a bloody good mini-series - about 6 episodes or so. The characters are good, and while not overdetailed, they do their job. And when I finished it, I felt like after a good TV show or movie. It left satisfied, but somehow empty. The conversions are awesome. I had a few laughs, but the interactions between the characters never went over the top, and kept me interested throughout the story. Nobody felt flat or uninteresting, so that's a pretty good thing too.Overall, 8/10. I had little to no expectations, but left with something I won't forget soon.Gameplay:It's a rather standard TPS with a decent selection of firearms. You get Assault Rifles, Shotguns, Pistols, SMGs, LMGs, and so forth. Most of them has a secondary mode, which is to say switch the sniper rifle's zoom (from 8x to 16x), or put a sound suppressor to the M4A1. It's fun, and while the diversity forces you to either be a really accurate shooter, or switch your weapons frequently. Ammo boxes scattered around the maps help you. The cover system while sometimes tad awkward, is good. Made me think of Mass Effect. In every section you can find pieces of intels - a great way for knowing the backstory a bit better, and adds to the overall feel to the game. You'll be more disturbed after you find them fo' sure. Sometimes they are at obvious places, but you gotta look for the to find all.The game is rather linear, but with a game like this, it's not much of a problem. I wouldn't list this as a pro, but neither as a con. It's just linear and that's it. 7/10 - you'll remember the game for the story, as the gameplay is, while rather flowing, brings nothing new.The visuals:Like in my Sleeping Dogs review (which you probably haven't read, but I like to mention my other written stuffs), I have to state I don't have the full specifics to play the game on High graphics. I went with medium, and it ran with about 30 fps. For me, it's solid, and the game, while not gorgeous, it looked good. The Sandstorm'd Dubai (which is almost Darude, but let's stay away from memes for a second) looks good. It's pretty detailed, and I never got bored of the environment. It wasn't exactly the same as far as I recall, and fighting on the top of a skyscraper is a nice change after eating sand on ground level. It matched the game, so I'm fine with it as is.Overall a 8/10.Sounds:Okay, this is awesome. The mad DJ with the hits of the 80s that he plays seemingly random, the ambient music, and the OST for the game is AWESOME. Fitting, believable, and you'll feel that it gives a lot to the game. You'll eventually search for the OST on Youtube, and save it to listen later. It's really good. Kudos to the composer.10/10Overall I'd give this game a 8.5 out of 10, totally worth playing, and totally worth your money. Be aware of the graphic images of gore, death, and the feeling of emptiness and guilt after you've finished the game, regardless of your choices.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 27, 2013
												The first thing to get out of the way is that this game is not fun, nor was it meant to be fun.  That said, I feel that it is an incredibly important game that everyone should play.  Like in all modern shooters, you get turned into a mass murderer, but this time it is openly acknowledged and you will feel terrible about it.  One of the best examples that comes to mind is a part where you are forced to kill 2 men right after listening to them have a talk about actual things that make you have feels.  That's right, THIS GAME WILL HIT YOU RIGHT IN THE FEELS.  Another great aspect of the game is the lack of black-and-white morality.  Pretty much the entire game is spent questioning who is in the right, and the answer pretty consistently ends up being nobody.  It seems like everybody is trying to do the right thing, but they're doing horrible things in the process.  I must say that one of my favorite things about this game was the way that they portrayed the mental deterioration of your character and your squadmates. You can see these people that used to be great friends start to fall apart and get in fights with each other over what's right.  Anyways, I suppose I should also discuss the gameplay.  It's not very good.  Everything about the game is pretty generic if not sub-par.  It's a cover-based 3rd person shooter, but the cover system sucks and the shooting is nothing special.  One of my biggest complaints is actually that sprinting and taking cover are bound to the same button, so sometimes I would sprint past cover into the open, and other times I would want to sprint and accidentally get attached to cover.  You also have 2 squad mates that you can "command" but that basically involves telling them to shoot at a specific person until the target is dead.  The game is driven very hard by the story/themes, and I'd say it safely gets away with it, especially since the game is only about 5 hours long.  Buy it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 26, 2014
												Simply amazing.A MUST PLAY for anyone who loves storytelling in games. This one is on par with the greats like Bioshock and Portal.WARNING:THIS IS NOT A CALL OF DUTY CLONE LIKE THE TRAILERS AND BOX ART WOULD HAVE YOU BELIEVE, IT IS BASICALLY THE MOST ANTI-CALL OF DUTY TRIPLE A SHOOTER GAME EVER MADE.THIS GAME ISN'T "FUN" IT'S ENGAGING AND THOUGHT PROVOKING AND YOU WILL NOT HAVE A TRADITIONAL GOOD TIME PLAYING IT!The best way to explain what this game is to start at it's creation.Spec Ops was a shooter series that nobody cared about in the late 90s/early 2000s.2K (the publisher) wanted Yager (the developers) to make a new Spec Ops game. It could be about ANYTHING so long as it was about the US military.What they made was a decent into madness that will make you rethink everything you knew about the Modern Military genre.Many games are "adult" because they have violence and sexual themes, though children still play and enjoy them. This game is adult because it's got mature themes and will make you think.I can't spoil ANYTHING because it's best to go in completely fresh but it's amazingly dark and you will feel awful after beating it, but in a good way.Gameplay's standard MMS fare but played from a third person perspective, similarly to Gears of War. The shooting feels good and they keep adding new, varied weapons to keep things at least somewhat varied. The cover mechanics are pretty clunky and awkward and It all gets kinda boring.But it's not about that, it's about the story.Play this if you want something that questions the MMS genre.Play this if you want to play something that makes you feel awful and think.DON'T play this if you want a pro-USA shooter where you kill the terrorists and stop World War 3.I wholeheartedly reccomend this.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 27, 2015
												In the end I would probably recommend this game. Not because it would be particularly delightful to play. Actually, at times, the cover shooting mechanics are totally infuriating, the hordes of enemies you encounter become dull very fast and your squad seems very, very useless.It is quite obvious that this game is played for its story. I'm pretty sure it is quite well known at this point that this game is about war crimes, sanity, reality and morality. Most of the time the choices are forced on you, which might feel like cheating, but I think the narrative wouldn't work as it does if the player really had a freedom of choice. It is pretty damn obvious that clear majority of human kind would not commit war crimes or other atrocities, as normal reality permits our minds to stay intact. If the player really would get to make a clear-headed decision whether or not kill civilians or be an all-around bad guy, the choice would be robbed of its meanings. Either the player does the sensible thing (from normality's perspective) or roleplays a total psychopath, doing bad things only because they are evil, not because there is actually some "logical" reasoning behind the choice. Engaging in small digression, I actually think many choices in RPG-games are bereft of true meaning in this way: it just is pretty difficult to assume a role and stay consistent when you are sitting behind a screen.The game attemps to shed some light on war crimes, PTSD and whatnot. It could be taken as giving jabs to violent entertainment in general, problematizing mindless violence that often serves as the greatest form of interaction games usually provide, especially in the genre of war-themed FPS games. I still would've wanted to see a game that takes a stronger stance on this. Even though the game puts you in an uncomfortable situation, massacring civilians and whatnot, the interaction it provides still revolves totally around killing endless hordes of faceless bad guys. Even though this could be taken as a part of the games morals, I believe a more sturdier anti-war sentiment could've been conveyed if developers would've attempted to mold the action scenes more elegantly. Possibly it wasn't the job for this game, but I certainly believe it is an important task for some game.Story is pretty good, mechanics are a bit poopy, what else. The game looks good, but it contains surprisingly little pre-arranged scenic views and sights for the player to stumble upon. A war-wrecked Dubai could very well have room for vistas like this, but some technical limitations have probably prohibited them. The optional collection quests are well integrated into the story and gives you a real reason to hunt for them. The length of 5-7 hours on normal difficulty is compact and I enjoyed it. The story did not need any dragging on and the game itself wasn't so good that I would've wanted to play it any longer.

content:
Posted: July 5, 2013
												Seemed to be some random TPS at first. But it definitely wasn't. It has an already seen but very solid and smooth gameplay, which is compiled with a realistic vision of gunfights. This results in an oppressing and hardened action, that comes with a pretty high level of difficulty for a modern game. Bots are quite hardcore and can surprise pretty often.  Visually, it is more about the wonderful artistic design and level design of the ruines of Dubai, then about AAA graphics. Same for the audio, good stuff. But the real originality of this game is it's story : In the beginning, it starts like the usual US special forces thingy. But it quickly becomes some disturbing cluster♥♥♥♥ (in the good way) of human crazyness. It puts the caracters and the player in the middle of the inner fight between the soldier and the man, when everything like order, brotherhood and moral codes go to♥♥♥♥♥♥ Largely inspired by "Apocalypse Now " in my opinion, it is a hard and cold journey  into the subjects of  soldiers' depression and  war sickness. Something rarely seen in a game until now. Really worth going for it, specially since you can get it for really cheap lately.

content:
Posted: August 15, 2014
												8/10Brilliant storyline. 10/10 for that. Immersive, shocking. Several moments that really highlighted the horrors of war, especially knowing that it ws you that pulled the trigger. This game will make you hate yourself.Gameplay, however, holds back this otherwise amazing experience.1. As a tactical shooter, cover plays a very important role. The cover mechanics in this game, however, are laughable. Often, the only way to get from cover to cover is to stand up and fully revealing yourself to the enemy. The game enters and exits cover in very counterintuitive ways, which, again, often means you will be stainging up in full view of the enemy.This shouldn't be a problem. Cover mechanics are nothing new. Mass Effect, Deus EX: HR, etc all have done infinitely better.2. The squad commands are limited to "kill this guy". Not even "hold back", which means your two vulnerable squadmates will sometimes rush, then require medical attention deep into enemy lines. Other than that, the game is amazing.

												Wow, now here's a suprise.  What starts off as a bland Gears of War style third person shooter, turns into a gripping war drama that looks at the horrors of war and what is right and wrong. Throughout most the game the shooting is functional albiet not that special but it's the story that really carries the experience and makes you want to keep playing. Spec Ops does what other modern shooters wish they could do, it makes you care, care about the choices you have to make along the way and about the characters that are involved. Spec Ops: The Line is a dark and gloomy ride that provides a refreshing experience from modern military shooters and whilst at first it seems just a shallow, this is done intentionally to lull you into a false frame of mind to make the experience all that more suprising. So if you see it on sale and you're up for a different kind of shooter that emphasis atmosphere and story then give it a try!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 27, 2014
												It's a shame that Yager have publicly stated that there won't be a Spec Ops sequel as there is enough evidence in this game to hint at rich promises.In Spec Ops: The Line you are Captain Walker in charge of an elite Delta squad consisting of Staff Sergeant Lugo, the sniper, and Liutenant Adams, the heavy gunner. The premise is simple, your mission is to enter Dubai, confirm the statuses of Colonel John Konrad; who with his squad, the Damned 33rd, attempted to lead a rescue effort for the storm ravaged city of Dubai, and any remaining survivors of the storm, then radio for extraction. What follows however is anything but simple as you find yourself led deeper into the heart of the city, coming directly into contact with the conflict between the 33rd, the civilians and the CIA.In an ever shifting narrative where the lines between good and evil are constantly evolving yet becoming increasingly blurred , it is without a doubt that the story is the work of breathtaking brilliance. The game does not shy away from showing the ravages of war and how it can take its toll on individuals. Playing through the game, there are evocative and poignant moments which causes one to pause, think and consider. Even the collectibles in the game demand to be sought after as they genuinely add further to the story, providing additional layers to the narrative and helping to provide some enlightening backstories to some of the characters in the game.Unsurprisingly there are certain parts in the game where you are given a decision to make, whether it be to save a few civilians here or rescue a potentially valuable informat there. Whilst this adds a bit of variety proceedings, it is disappointing to see that the consequences of these decisions have little bearing in the grander scheme of the story so there is little in the way of replayability. Furthermore the gamplay itself is rather subpar. There is little to excite the player with the now standard 'on-the-rails' vehicle section making its way into the game to inspire a change of pace. The shooting itself can prove clunky at times and your team are largely annonymous in a gunfight. However the subpar gameplay is never too intrusive as to ruin the experience. Indeed it may be appropriate for it complements the story. It feels restrained, modest and bare. This way, the gameplay perfectly chimes with the wider subdued tone of the game where the horrors of war unfold. As such your focus remains firmly on the narrative.Visually speaking, Yager have achieved that sun-kissed perished paradise look that suggests a ruined landscape shorn of its riches. A neat metaphor for Captain Walker's mission. There are memorably evocative passages in the game which arouse a number of emotions in the player. The behaviour of the waves of sand as they bury enemies underneath is also believable. Yet the sand really comes into its own element in online multiplayer where the shifting terrain can alter and shift the balance of matches, offering greater tactical depth and encouraging careful planning.Overall Spec Ops: The Line is a welcome addition to the bloated shooting genre. It stands out on its own with its daring original story, distinctive setting and complex characters. Whilst it does not offer the brash, over-the-top, adrenaline filled fun of other shooters, enjoyment can still be had from this slow-burning, emotionally affecting, multi-faceted adventure.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 14, 2014
A great third person shooter with a griping storyline (No spoilers!)There are many shooters on the market, the quip that the genre is overdone is thrown about constantly. Thankfully, Spec Ops: The Line has enough to set it apart and make it worth your attention.I didn't know exactly what to expect going into this game, but I had heard that it featured complicated morale choices and focused on the somber side of war. I bought it for a bargain on Steam Sale on the hunch that I might enjoy it for its storyline. To summarize my experience - this game is pretty much fantastic. You can tell a lot of attention was put into the story, and while the quality of the writing suffers at times, the overall cohesiveness of what they were trying to accomplish is successful.The story focuses on personal consequences in the face of total war. Your playable character's (and therefore your own) personal morality will be called into question at several points in the story. The utter and complete carnage of war may or may not grey the line between right and wrong - all depending on how you as the player choose to see it. There will be times when you can walk away and times when you cannot. Sometimes, circumstances may force your hand and you will be forced with a real Hobson's choice. It isn't necessarily a bad thing as after all, in war, sometimes things can come down to the choices of bad or worse.The gunplay is consistent and enjoyable with cover based shooting being the emphasis. Enemy AI is far from perfect, but is aggressive enough to pull off successful flanking and effective suppressive fire (against you and your teammates). Your two squad mates provide effective help throughout the campaign without being superhuman (AKA: immortal) or too dependent on you (incompetent).All in all, Spec Ops: The Line is a title well worth your consideration. Fans of third person shooters will enjoy the fast placed and fun gunplay. Teammate AI makes the experience all the more enjoyable with firefights often a real delight as suppressive fire rings out and precision shots drop exposed enemies. The storyline is what this game is really all about, the depravity of war. I assure you, you haven't played a shooter like this one before.8/10TL;DR- Acceptable visuals (2012 console-port title, forced FXAA recommended)- Fantastic voice acting by Nolan North (Cpt. Martin Walker)- Consistent and fun third person shooter- Good cover based system - works well with suppressive fire, grenades, sniping, et cetera- Gripping storyline focusing on the horrors of war, the often untold human cost at its core- Steam achievments- Tacked on multiplayer

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 15, 2014
												Do You Feel Like the Hero Yet?     What are your expectations when you start a military shooter? What are you willing to do just because the game tells you to? Do you think killing countless people will somehow lead to a happy ending? Why are you still playing? Do you think this is fun? Spec Ops: The Line forces you to think about these questions.      Let me begin by saying this is NOT a normal military shooter. Spec Ops is easily one of the darkest games I have played in years. It causes you to think about what you’ve done rather than just letting you mindlessly complete objectives. No, not a military shooter, but the opposite. This is a game about the horrors of military shooters.      Spec Ops is unique. It’s not about “fun” how we usually think of it. The story is where this game shines. Sure, you shoot things and hide behind cover just like every other third person shooter out there, but that’s not the point. The point is to make you think. The point is to make you question “Why am I still here?” While falling short in several areas, the narrative is what keeps you playing. You need to play this game.*Please note, this is only a review for the single player portion of the game. Multiplayer will only be mentioned once, right now.*GAMEPLAY     Spec Ops may not have the most polished gameplay, but it works well enough. The camera perspective is third person over the shoulder, which works well for this type of game. You feel more connected to the protagonist rather than him just being an empty vessel for you to possess. The gunplay is edgy, and the shooting mechanics are solid. The level design keeps things tense while providing for interesting ways to finish each area. The environments can frequently be used to your advantage, which is a wonderful addition to the gameplay.      Sand is your best friend and your worst enemy. If sand has blown against a window, shoot the window to drop it all on your enemies. However, sandstorms show up from time to time and make combat very difficult. Having the environment be a part of the gameplay is genius, especially considering how vicious the AI is. If left alone, they will murder you. Be prepared for some annoying sections where the pesky guy with a shotgun repeatedly flanks you.     The area where Spec Ops falls short is the controls. Having melee be the same button as vaulting over cover is annoying. There were several times when enemies were flanking me, so I went to hop over cover, but I just ended up punching it instead. That’s frustrating. However, the rest of the controls are mostly what you expect from shooters nowadays. It’s definitely not the worst control scheme I’ve ever seen, but it’s also not incredible.VISUALS     Spec Ops: The Line is a pretty game. From the moment I started the game, I could tell I was in for some eye candy. I wasn’t disappointed. Beautiful scenery, excellent detail, and horrifying deaths, this game has it all. However, the character models could have used some work. If you showed me a lineup of characters and told me to pick the protagonist from this game, I wouldn’t be able to do it. His personality makes up for his bland appearance, though. Nolan North’s performance as the protagonist is excellent, just like everything else he’s ever done.      Spec Ops’ aesthetics are fantastic. Set in Dubai, you wouldn’t think there’s much to see besides buildings and sand. You’re right! Yet somehow, they manage to keep it interesting. From giant billboards to war torn villages, it manages to keep your attention. One part that really stood out to me was when you reach the top of a skyscraper, you look out over all of Dubai. Off in the distance, you can see your ultimate goal, and you realize just how far you still have to go. This is great. It shows you how far you’ve made it, yet it also shows how beautiful the landscape really is.      Expect to be shocked by how brutal this game is. They will show you things you wish you hadn’t seen. Without spoiling anything, there’s a scene in the middle that is painful to see. They show you that your actions have consequences. Without these visuals, it wouldn’t have had the impact that it did. SOUND     Nolan North. Does anything else need said? It probably does, so I’ll continue. All of the sound is very believable. The gunshots have punch, and the sandstorms are terrifying. The banter between characters helps the world feel real. Your two friends will always let you know when someone is trying to flank you, and they’ll tell you when they kill a target you’ve told them to kill. This sort of feedback is excellent, and I want to see more games incorporate it on this sort of level. Also, the soundtrack is appropriate and well implemented. Overall, excellent sound.STORY     Now for the good stuff. The narrative is the greatest in any game since Bioshock. Seriously. I won’t spoil anything, but it needs to be played more than once to fully grasp just how deep it actually is. This is the most well-paced shooter I have played in years. Some shooters leave me worn out after a few hours of playtime, but Spec Ops always gives you a breather after you get through a tough section. Partly the writing and partly the level design, but it’s worth noting. If I say any more, I’m afraid I’ll spoil something, so I’ll close with this: play this game.CONTENT     Player discretion is advised. Be prepared for some very shocking visuals. You will see things you wish you hadn’t. It’s not pointless, though. It is essential to the narrative. Occasional language, including the “F” word. Not nearly as much language as GTA or Saint’s Row, but about as much as The Walking Dead. Don’t let your children play this game. The visuals are disturbing, even for adults.THE VERDICT     I highly recommend this game. Probably wait for a sale on Steam since the campaign is only six hours long. However, you will probably want to play it through more than once. Be prepared to be shocked, but also prepare to be amazed. This isn’t the game we wanted, but this is the game we needed. “Fun” is not in its vocabulary. Spec Ops: The Line sheds some light on the gaming industry itself, and it proves that a military shooter can truly be original. SCORINGGameplay: 7.5Visuals: 8.5Sound: 8.5Story: 9.5Overall*: 8.5(Scale of 1-10. 1 being terrible, 10 being perfection.)*(Not an average. This is the score I give to the overall product, not an average of certain aspects. This score is my recommendation for whether it should be played.)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 25, 2016
												Violence, bloodshed, and cruelty are unfortunate, likely indelible parts of our reality. As widespread as they are, it’s only natural they’re reflected in expressive media. Guns, for example, are always a hot topic, and a good fit for video games: point, shoot, be visually and technically rewarded. First and third-person shooting can provide such a compelling feedback loop for players that hundreds of these games are developed, and millions of copies are sold. Series like Call of Duty and Gears of War set the pace for the modern shooter. In a medium, in a society, so acclimated to this kind of violence, it is, in turn, only natural that opposing commentary arises. See Heart of Darkness, Apocalypse Now, and Spec Ops: The Line.A third-person shooter set in the near future or an alternate present, Spec Ops: The Line puts players in the shoes of Captain Martin Walker, an American soldier sent to Dubai with two companions to evacuate survivors from the city, long in ruins from hellish sandstorms. Upon arrival, the group picks up a distress signal from Walker’s old commander, Colonel John Konrad, apparently holed up in the city with his battalion, the 33rd. Walker decides to search him out, only to be met with extreme opposition from crazed members of the 33rd itself. Over the course of the game, Walker and his fellow soldiers cross paths with the CIA, cross swords with the 33rd, and make decisions that will change the lives of thousands.From minute one, the influence of Conrad and Coppola is clearer than a summer sky. Konrad (like, come on) may as well be named Kurtz; Walker, Marlow or Willard. The trek through Dubai is as hellish as the Conrad’s Congo or Coppola’s Vietnam. It is certainly a fitting setting for a modern retelling. Dubai is a rich man’s paradise built on the backs of thousands in a position no better than slavery. It’s in close proximity to areas heavily occupied by US armed forces for the last two or three decades; it’d believably be a point of interest and interference for our troops if such disastrous storms ever did strike. While The Line does hit these points, the classic story beats, and more, it’s held back by a lack of subtlety and a few key, sloppy moments. Narrative choices are peppered throughout, typically deciding between the life or death of nameless characters - only the final choice matters counts towards your ending, as far as I can tell. Those choices are further undercut by narrative choices you have no say in. This is summed up in an early chapter: you have a choice to save an informant or some civilians. One of your squadmates pushes for the informant and the mission, while the other wants to protect innocent lives - I went with the civilians. Hardly ten minutes later, your path is blocked with considerable forces, but there just happens to be white phosphorus mortars nearby. Now, strangely, your squadmates’ roles swap - the one who argued for the civilians now argues for completing the mission by any means necessary, while the other now vouches for finding another way. “There’s always a choice,” he says. Apparently not, because you’re promptly forced to melt a couple hundred people to continue towards your goal. This is made all the more baffling when, in later chapters, load screens directly chastise the player for killing without caring. I do appreciate that The Line asks these questions and poses them to players, many of which may be expecting just another action-packed military shooter. I’m just sure there’s a way to do so with more finesse and, ultimately, impact.Gameplay is serviceable, though drab. The closest comparison is probably Gears of War, owing to the focus on cover, roadie run, visible grenade arcs, and other nuances. Level and encounter design is, again, just serviceable. There are in-game challenges that offer a bit of engagement - get a hundred headshots, kill twenty rappelling enemies. I suspect this feature is a self-aware genre jab, juxtaposing arcade-like objectives with horrific and widespread death, but it ended up as the only thing maintaining my interest in each firefight. That’s the thing about this game: much like Apocalypse Now, it can feel like just another example of what it’s trying to criticize. It can come off as a cheap Gears clone made to sell units, and there isn’t always enough evidence present to say otherwise.I’ve been hard on it, but I do have a lot of respect for Spec Ops: The Line. Amidst the ocean of Duty, Battle, and Honor, this game stands out as a genuine effort to make these audiences, and this industry, to consider genre standards we may be too comfortable with. It’s worth attention, despite its missteps. Apparently, development was repeatedly delayed, some of it owing to story changes; with more time and a unified vision, Yager Development could’ve made something truly great. For now, we have a solid attempt at a Heart of Darkness for the modern age that deserves recognition for confronting complacency to violence.

												Spec Ops: The Line. What a game. I could quite possibly write a whole paper on the philosophical and ethical side of this game but I'm going to keep it rather short. GET THIS GAME. It's a brilliant middle finger to all of the jingoistic, gung-ho 'MERICA shooters that have been flooding the market. However, while the story is great the gameplay is merely okay and there are some occasional glitches (only ran into about 4 or 5 noticable ones throughout the game, other than that this is a fantastic port), but most of this is forgivable due to the short length of it's campaign (around 5-6 hours). It does have some issues but the big picture is what's most important here, it may get rather repetitive or frustrating at times, but stick with it and you'll get one of the finest experiences in all of gaming.Bottom line (heheheh...line), though: GET THIS GAME

And the sprint is like a gears of war sprint where you have little control over the direction and can't stop soon. But this game really shines on the second playthrough at a higher difficulty for two reasons: you're better adapted to the keys and mechanics and the the vague story is clear when you know the ending. You can get killed very easily at higher difficulties which forces you to be really slow-paced and tactical and that is when the game is really engaging and brilliant.

content:
Posted: August 13, 2014
												This game is incredibly underrated, and it actually annoys me a little that it hasn't gotten the attention it deserves. It starts off like a typical action/war-game would. You are on a mission and you have a task or a goal to achieve. Once you progress through  the game, you will encounter some tough desicions and some seriously tough outcomes. This game has an incredibly deep story which totally blew me away, because I seriously didn't expect it. I haven't played the game for a long time, but I finished the storyline, and it made a huge impression on me.I will not spoil the game's story, but it has a crazy turning point and some serious mind♥♥♥♥s beyond measure, that I never expected when I bought the game. If you decide to play through the story, make sure that you listen carefully to the dialogs and pay attention to the details. Seriously, it's worth it. This has been one of my best gaming-experiences in a long time. The game is very emotional, especially towards the end. It represents war in a realistic way, and shows the outcome and damages it causes. It's not just a typical action game where you kill  the bad-guys and save the day. It's so much more than that. It makes you really reflect over your choises and it's outcomes. The game has four possible endings, and you have the option to chose towards the end. You pick the one you want, and the one that you feel  is the correct one. Because as i said earlier, this game includes a massive mind♥♥♥♥ as you progress, and people would have different opinions on what they feel is the proper ending.One of the things I'm not a great fan of, is some of the awkward controls. They are not bad, but it is not something I'm used to in a game within the genre. But you can of course mess around with key-bindings till you find something that works alright for you. The graphics are good and the voice-acting as great.The game is also fairly cheap. But even if the game was more expensive, it would still be worth every cent. Very deep and very emotional game. The game is not perfect, but it is truly a great gaming-experience.Rating: 7,9/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 26, 2014
												Let me tell you a story guys.There was once a nice good looking middle aged lady called Call of Duty, she was a what you`d call a cougar. One day she visited a reception and met a charming young man named Bulletstorm. They caught each another`s eye and one thing led to another. One day Call of Duty calls up Bulletstorm and tells him that she is pregnant. They talk about it and all and decide they want to keep it. 9 months later the baby was born in a hospital. It was delivered by a nice doctor named Borderlands and assisted by the nurse... i think her name was Rage or Fallout or smth of that sort... it was decided that the baby would be called Spec Ops. But an unthought thing happened... once Spec Ops was given to Bulletstorm to hold it he started freaking out. You cant blame him he was just a young fella with the rest of his teenage days still ahead of him and big decisions to be made. He ran out of the hospital in panic fearing the responsibilities and the tied down life. He was never to be seen again.Call of Duty had been single handedly raising Spec Ops for awhile when another series of events followed. She met a foreigner visiting her place. She was still in her prime and some may call her a MILF even. The guy`s name was Gears of War. He was of a ripe age and of nice facial features and body built. They started talking often and found out a lot of interesting things about each other. Gears of War was a nice and reliable man... a perfect husband... a perfect father... and soon enough he became one. Spec Ops became a brighter kid ever since. They often went out to the parks, played baseball or soccer together, would go to the beach and splash water and run around... a perfect little family it was. Spec Ops would still have minor features of his biologica father Bulletstorm and have a few internal scars too but he was strong enough to look past them. Soon came his own time to shine... he was a bright student with an unorthodox mind. He loved watching movies by Steven Kubrik or Christopher Nolan, especially the Machinist and Fight Club. Eventually he had graduated college and went to a good medical school to become a doctor. As a matter of fate he happened to know the doctor that was delivering him - Borderlands and earn a scholarship in that name. What you see in this game that you might be about to purchase is that kid - Spec Ops standing on the stage and receiving his Masters Degree with Honors from the principal of the elitist university awaiting the outside world to embrace him with open arms.I wish a very happy ending to his story and the events till its` end.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 14, 2014
												I haven't reviewed this game, thats odd. Well,  better late than none at all..A TECHNICAL NOTE:This game was designed for WinXP, and therefore you need to set the combatibility options accordingly. Detailed explanation can be found at PCGamingWiki.com. There is also a bug regarding previously saved games, this causes the game to crash. The fix for this is also found at the wiki.SECONDARY NOTE:Since i'm aching all over, i'm just copying the review i made for this game on Greenman Gaming. (Lazyness FTW)__________________________________________________________________Valtheknight | Feb. 6, 2014 | Review of Spec Ops: The LineOh dear... Well i can for starters say that i'm at an disadvantage since i last played the game through about a year ago and i completely forgot that i bought it from Greenman. Also since there is a "credit"-gain from review so.. Might as well.Before i start, i really should mention that i really cant remember everything about this game. Because of the one year gap. So most of the stuff i say will be mostly about my personal experiences and should be taken with 'nth amount of salt. (Since i'm a little bit biased..)Well the first thing that needed to be done with the game, was to actually get it to run. Since it had some startup-problems with it, this caused some grey hairs at first, but a quick venture into the promised land of PC-GAMING WIKI. Helped to resolve that problem quickly. Unfortunately, since the game uses encrypted options files. Tweaking other aspects of it will prove difficult, if you wish to, for example, change the FOV.(I don't remember if the game was updated to include an FOV slider later on.. Again i last played it at the start of 2013.)Well i think that's the mandatory technical jabber out of the way, onto the game itself.The story is in itself deceptively straight-forward, it starts of with a group of soldiers, (Delta-Force if memory serves correctly.) On a mission to investigate what happened in Dubai after it was supposed to have been evacuated, before some heavy-duty sandstorms started wrecking up the place.And that is pretty much the easiest explanation of how the story starts, i really can't write about it that much since i feel i would be doing it no favors. Instead, i will only say that the story only gets more darker and stranger the further it goes. With some actual character-development and i don't mean the "put-points-to-sht-to get-the-biggest-deathcck" -way, but in the storytelling sense. Some of the stuff you see and hear the team say and do really start to show later down the line.That's enough spoilers for the story part, next!The gameplay is pretty standart 3rd-person cover-based shooting and that is pretty much the thing that kind of kills the novelty-value almost instantly, because people will automatically make references to any other Military shooter almost instantly. I on the other hand right now started thinking about the Normandy landing scene on Medal of Honor:Allied Assault, nicked almost to the T from Saving private Ryan... Oops Digressing statement.Later down the line, the game has a turret section, and another, and another yet again.. That kills the feel a bit, since you wonder "Why did it give me another turret section? Can't i just run around and shoot them in the head instead?" Actually, at one point you can, but it makes it a bit harder. But don't get me wrong, the helicopter segment at the start of the game (and the redo of it later) was well executed. I cannot really say the same from the rest though.Anyway, the biggest sin, i feel from the game-designs part is the linearity. It shows from the start and it carries through to the end. The strangest thing though... I noticed on my last playthrough that i had missed options in the story. All because the game told me to do this, instead of that and now i need to download it again to see the other parts i missed. Since i feel, "if i missed that one so obvious, what others i missed ?"CONCLUSION:Even with its story, The Line seems (to untrained eye atleast) a generic 3rd-person shooter. Even the changes the characters go through during the story, kind of brush by with a big red sign over their head saying "FEEL SH_T". And some of the stuff does have some shock value, but it loses even that rather quickly. All and all, the story (if flawed, yes flawed. Shoot me if you disagree.) is the only thing that is interesting about this game. Is it enough to carry it? No. Is it enough to make it stand out from the rest? Yes. Is it actually worth playing? Maybe.__________________________________________________________________I gave the game 80/100 on Greenman, and at second thought, it might have been a bit too generous. I should have given it a score middling 60-75, since it had all the classic modern era shooter problems. But as it stands, it is still worth the money.

content:
Posted: July 23, 2014
												Talk about a game that exceeded my expectations. I recently purchased that Humble Bundle for 2K and this was one of the games in the tier. I had never heard of it before and I thought, why the heck not. I was already going to get the bundle for the Bioshock series and that was enough justification for the purchase. A quick google search of the title revealed that it was a third person shooter, a genre that I was not familiar with. I went into the game with the bar set pretty low, expecting mediocre gameplay and a typical shooter campaign storyline. I was wrong in my expectations lets just say. The story was exceptional and unique while maintaining my interest and enveloping me in to the plot. The gameplay on the normal difficulty setting was a nice balance with combat progressively getting more challenging as the story progressed. If I had any complaints (petty they are at that) it would be that the control and combat style was a little basic though still better than some other shooter style games out on the market (cough cough COD cough cough). Overall, I really enjoyed the game and would highly recommend it to anyone looking for something fresh and unique. (PS: The soundtrack was also really good in terms of piece selection and timing. Made the game feel very authentic and exciting. A+)

content:
Posted: July 2, 2014
												Just fantastic -- I could simple leave it at that (but I'll elaborate anyway). Spec Ops: The Line combines some of the best third-person shooter action I've ever played with one of the most gut-wrenching literary works in history and ends up with a weekend-worthy masterpiece of gaming that, by the end, will leave you mouth agape and unsure of what to do with yourself.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 24, 2014
												There are few times in your life when you will have the chance to experience something as outstanding as Spec Ops: The Line.The setting is the city of Dubai, a few months after it has been hit by a devastating sandstorm and an evacuation operation has apparently failed. The focus is on three US Army soldiers sent to find out if there are any survivors and getting caught right in the middle of a conflict between the 33rd Infantry Battalion and local CIA operatives. The story shows the atrocities that the protagonists have to commit during their mission and the descent of the main character into madness, as he realizes that there are no redeeming choices in his reality and he can't cope with his own actions. The plot contains parallels from various horrifying situations of real-world war zones, particularly the use of white phosphorus mortar bombs on civilian populations in Iraq and Gaza. At its core, Spec Ops: The Line explores the concepts of PTSD, cognitive dissonance, escapism and the idea that the main character is not the player's avatar but instead, the player is the main character's super-ego.The story is amazing and it is delivered superbly by all aspects of the game. The cutscenes, the direction, the characters' models, the tone and content of the voice acting (not only during scripted sequences, but even in the way the main character addresses his companions during battles), the animations (most notably the executions of dying enemies), the level design and even the loading screen text snippets - everything in the game shifts and transforms in order to serve the story and highlight the increasingly obvious psychosis of the main character, his increasingly violent tendencies, his inescapable and growing guilt, his detachment from sanity (and reality) and his companions' gradual loss of respect, trust and faith in him, as one of the premises of the game is revealed and confirmed ("Ιt takes a strong man to deny what's right in front of him."). The game embraces literally everything at its disposal and raises every expectation regarding what we should accept as character development from modern works of art.The graphics are decent, including realistic and detailed shaders, rich well-crafted animations, just the right amount of post-processing and destructible environments. It is one of the best uses of the Unreal Engine that I've seen to date. When you are inside the extravagant but deserted buildings of Dubai, the art style is often reminiscent of that of the original BioShock.In the sound department, the game performs excellent - the voice acting is simply outstanding, while the soundtrack consists of a post-rock soundscape that blends perfectly with the environments and the psychological state of the characters, coupled with a plethora of known pieces from various artists, ranging from Deep Purple and Jimi Hendrix to Björk and Giuseppe Verdi.The gameplay is that of a typical third-person cover-based shooter, with the right balance between cool (to keep you interested), surreal (to underline that something isn't quite right) and repetitive (to make you feel even more desensitized before it hits you). The levels often seem open but the level design is actually quite linear. The game's idea of tactics revolves mostly (though not exclusively) around finding a good cover, adapting by changing your position, drawing enemies out of their covers and some micromanaging with weapons, bullets and grenades. At no point do you get to choose where you are going to fight your enemies and stealth tactics, wherever applicable, don't make a lot of difference compared to just charging in. You can, however, drown your enemies using tons of sand that's trapped on glass roofs and other places.Where the gameplay shines is in choices: instead of presenting choices with a bland menu that's disconnected from the rest of the game, Spec Ops: The Line embraces them tightly and features them exclusively as part of the gameplay. In many occasions, the game organically recognizes the intent behind your actions without having previously made the choice (or all of your options) explicit. This not only helps maintain the cinematic feel of the game, but also forces you to ponder your choices as real actions with real consequences (rather than items in a menu) and, most importantly, it makes you question your previous actions and constantly reevaluate situations retrospectively, highlighting another premise of the game, the idea that apparently you had choices all along ("There's always a choice!"), but you kept going ("None of this would've happened if you'd just stopped."). There are four endings for you to discover and they are all well-made and perfect epilogues to what your actions say about the protagonist (and you) by the end.Some final things:-The campaign is 6-12 hours long depending on your pace, not particularly difficult once you get used to the gameplay.-After you finish the campaign, a variable portion of the game's events are left open to interpretation. Almost all possible interpretations have at least some plot holes or unconvincing details. For me, they are forgivable but your mileage may vary.-There is a multiplayer mode that I simply won't consider in this review, because this game is essentially its campaign mode and the very existence of a multiplayer mode defeats the point that the story is trying to make.-Some people have said that there are bugs (particularly sound-related ones, which can be overcome, as they say), but I can't comment on those because for me it worked flawlessly.And that's it. This is an extraordinary game and every developer should take notes, because Spec Ops: The Line demonstrates what games should aim to be.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 29, 2014
												Ignored it upon release as I'd wrongly assumed it was another one-sided AMERRCUHHH, KILL THE TERRORISTS, BE A HERO game (the first 30 or so minutes kind of are, to lull you into a false sense of confidence and righteousness) but it quickly turns out to be anything but - throughout, and increasingly so, you'll be questioning whether you're doing more harm than good, and that's putting it lightly. Surprisingly deep and clever. Several references to Heart Of Darkness which it seems to be based on.Lots can be said about how well it manages it (I ended up writing an essay on the game for uni), but without spoiling anything, you'll feel like a monster by the end. In one small example, there's a part where you're fighting enemies in a shopping mall, with civilians hiding inside. I'd been fighting for roughly 10-15 minutes and hadn't seen a single civilian. An enemy ran down a hallway, and I chased him, ready to shoot back, when a civilian dives out from a gap and ran for cover. Before I had time to think, I shot them, and felt SO bad. It was clear that it was a mistake the game was counting on me to make, and I fell for it.Downsides: criticises military shooty games while being one (whether that works for or against it is up for debate), fairly unimaginative Gears Of War style cover/shooting mechanics.Overall: I really recommend anyone gives it a go, if they're into any shooter games, or are just looking for something different within the genre (hard to find, as anyone'll know). BUY IIIIIIT!(oh, and avoid multiplayer. the devs didn't want it in the game but the publisher got another studio to quickly hash it together, which completely misses/ignores the point of the story.)

content:
Posted: August 25, 2014
												Dark, gritty and very accurate about it's portrayal of war, If you want to get away from the glorified war game that is CoD this is worth it. The game pulls no punches displaying the carnage of war. The game is story driven in a compelling and addicting manner and well written.The game only has two outcomes for choices: Bad or Worse. You never feel like you made the right choice, but you do what you think is neccessary.The best part about this game is that it never dehumanizes the enemies you fight, in fact it tends to stress that fact that you are killing fellow human beings, you aren't supposed to feel good that you just shot the guy with the head wrapping, you did it because you had to survive.All in all this game rates a solid 9.5/10- Loved the game, hated myself.

												This game.. What can I say. Its beautiful and horrifying at the same time, a truly mature game. It shows all the Call of duties, modern warfares and battlefields and their various clones for the pretentious hogwash they are. It starts out looking like a bad COD clone, it even plays like one to start, but it uses that set up to rip the rug out from under ones feet. A great and insightful game, but by no means a fun game. I had to put it down on multiple occasions because I couldn't handle it for more than an hour at a time. This is a game that does the horrors of war justice.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 26, 2014
												This is basically PTSD: The Game.As a game, it's pretty standard.  You get into cover.  You shoot guys with guns.  Run to the waypoint to continue getting into cover and shooting guys with guns.  It feels fairly clunky to actually get into cover.  I felt like I had to hit the space bar a specific way to actually get into cover.  There are a handful of weapons in different categories like rifles, shotguns, small arms, snipers and heavy weapons.  Everything feels fairly generic with a few exceptions like shooting a part of the environment to dump sand on your foes and that's about it.  You can give orders to your team, but some orders only pop up at specific times and I could never seem to be able to use the attack order.  I was able to beat the campaign on the hardest availible starting difficulty in under 7 hours.  Again, as a game, it's pretty generic.As an experience, it's a completely different beast.  Never in my life have I played a military shooter that was this shocking.  If you thought the nuke scene and "no russian" from Call of Duty were hardcore, then you haven't seen anything yet.  It's really something you have to see for yourself and I wouldn't dare spoil it.  If I had to compare the story to anything, it feels a lot like the movie "Apocalypse Now" and if you've seen that movie then you should be aware of the levels of shock you are getting into...but even the story here goes above and beyond that.   Again, as an experience, it's quite unique.If you can get it cheap, do not pass it up even if you don't like cover shooters.  This is one game you need to see to the end...

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 2, 2014
												Overall I am a little broken on if I should suggest this game or not for many of the reasons outlined by both camps recommending and not recommending this game. So I figured I would give a well-rounded opinion of this game as I see it. I had to say that I would either recommend or not recommend it and I will wrap up at the very end why I eventually ended up recommending it. The GoodOverall the storyline is good, if you are looking for a modern shooter that falls in line with something like Mass Effect look elsewhere. ***SPOILERS HERE***The decisions you make have little impact until the VERY end of the game. That said the storyline itself is really quite good. ***NO MORE SPOILERS***Great voice acting unlike many other games, and on the note of voice acting the ambiance and stagnant dialogue given while you are walking around or just in a general area are also quite good. All adds to the rather interesting atmosphere created by this game. This game does have very interesting interiors if you take some time to look at them. They did seemingly put some detail there even if you don’t notice it. It was a fun added bonus that I appreciated time and time again. The characters develop throughout the plot as one would expect and the witty comments given throughout the game are quite good and keep things funny at times.  But other times create a very real sense of tension among the team mates. The general feel of this story starts off with you feeling great about yourself and your mission. But that slowly degrades and unlike COD or BF you aren’t left feeling like a hero at all. Even the loading screens about half way through the game start to become very macabre with things like “Do you feel like a hero yet?” and “This is all your fault.” So don’t play if you have a low self-esteem. This game will likely not help you any.  The combat in the game can be intense at times, leaving you with a sense of accomplishment if you have the game set on the correct difficulty. Literally don’t play this game on easy you are doing yourself a HUGE disservice by doing so. The BadThe actual gameplay can actually be really back braking at times. You want to do one thing but your character does another. And the game is over the right shoulder 3rd person so at times this is very frustrating. I felt like I needed the extra two side buttons on my mouse just to bind to grenade and melee.Speaking of which I can’t recall EVER using the melee button in the game at all.The controls aren’t intuitive and sometimes you want to do one thing but the game seemingly has a mind of its own. So this WILL get you killed a ton. Like a metric ton. No really…A TON. It is going to get annoying. Your fireteam doesn’t seem to have any real sense of direction when you direct them. About the only thing I found useful was having Lugo snipe people when someone was getting annoying. Really the other guy Adams was useless for the most part. The enemies do follow distinct lanes and don’t really vary from it much. However there will be times where you are thinking the fight is over and you are looking for that one LAST guy somewhere. He is always somewhere illogical and always armed with a shotgun it seems. Which never ends well. And by well I mean it usually ends with you dead and having to redo the entire firefight again. The SynopsisMany here suggest just watching a play through on youtube since many people play it for the storyline anyway. I can actually suggest this if you are going between buying and not buying the game. Since likely you will only enjoy it for the storyline anyway, the actual gameplay is a labor in futility and just frustrating at best. I found it to be a really welcome break from many other FPS games which is why I bought it discounted. If I had paid full price I would not have been happy with my purchase.  But it is a very good storyline and I enjoyed it as much as was honestly possible. But I can suggest it with one caveat, buy it on sale.

content:
Posted: September 1, 2014
												100% Completion ReviewForgive Them, For They Know Not What They DoThis game may just be one of the best single player experiences I have ever had. The story is mind-blowingly amazing, and nothing much comes close, except maybe the story of COD: Black OPS. This game features several choices of morality, which in turn don't affect the gameplay much, but in the end it's how they affect you as a person. This game really makes you feel for the characters and how that in turn reflects on you at the end.The atmospheric design and levels in this game are truly unique and offer something different to the typical shooter genre. The weapons are varied yet simple, and the shooting mechanics/cover system is simple but great. With the cover system, squad management and varied selection of weapons Spec Ops: The Line keeps the gameplay fresh and interesting, with a complex story that keeps you wanting more.All in all, I would highly recommend this game to anyone for the story alone, let's just hope you can live with the choices you make...

												Outstanding Story with a breathtaking plot with alternative endings.Spec Ops is about you, the effects of your actions, and events that are out of your control.This game defies the standard army shooter in a way that you have never seen before, it actually makes you question your actions, where you find yourself asking if killing is right or wrong.Multiplayer's a wash, but the campaign is worth replaying - seeing the same events while knowing what's really going on is uncomfortable in new ways, but the intelligent encounters and level design make each fight exciting, and the voice acting creates genuine and believable characters.Absolutely, and without a doubt, one of the best stories you'll find in any game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 24, 2013
												Spec Ops: The Line could have been amazing, but is merely good overall. However, aspects of it truly shines.The sense of progression in this game is simply amazing. Starting out as a typical military shooter, over time it becomes something more - and quite subtly at that. At first the killing seems inconsequential, you're following orders and being the archetypal soldier, mowing down the opposition for the greater good. As things progress though, it starts to challenge that notion, albeit vaguely at first. The loading screen text at the start of a level (or reloading a checkpoint in the case of death) even starts to change its tone, and it's these details that I admire so.As the plot progresses, so do the characters and their tone of communication. Your character model and the environment follows suit, ever altering as you move forward. There's a ton of commentary in the background and it's up to the player to explore it and read between the lines.Down to gameplay:This is where it stays typical, moving from cover to cover, shooting people in the head and waiting for your health to regenerate. That's pretty much what combat comes down to.One thing I loathed was my squad. The AI is so incompetent, I wanted to wrap my fist in an eisbein and punch them in the face. Forever. They're less trained combat operatives and more overconfident football players. They would've been more in place in a Serious Sam game. I got so♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥off at having to revive these guys all the time.You can order your squad to attack an enemy, but not to hold their position or to move to another. Game devs, what the♥♥♥♥♥♥ man? I hated those guys. And yes, they need to stay alive, as they're not just generic soldiers, but characters essential to the story.Other than that, solid stuff. Get it on sale. Experience your own Apocalypse Now.

content:
Posted: September 15, 2014
												First off if you ever think you are going to play this game stop looking for info on it and while the main hook may have already been spoiled that is far from the only one so don't write it off. The things I can say about this game are the mechanics are solid and satisfying, the slight time dilation when you get a head-shot really carries weight. The controls can be a little wonky at first but they work (mine only showed Xbox prompts which didn't help). The graphics hold up well so far and while the setting dictates the brown color palette there are some splashes of color provided by the graffiti spread around the world. There are also some pretty impressive establishing shots spread throughout. The story was a risk for the developer which definitely payed off but, while it was absolutely the best choice, I feel the intentionally bland marketing limited sales a bit and pushed the impact below the radar a bit. Please hold out through the end for this one, you owe it to yourself to dig into this story and let it impact you, however it touches you. Even if you find it hard to play. There is so much more I'd love to say and discuss about this game but I've already said too much. Just play this, as soon as possible.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 11, 2015
												This review is only for the single player campaign on normal difficulty.  Pretty well everything about this game was exactly what I would want out of a FPS campaign.  There was a decent variety of guns, some of them had secondary fire options, a few gernade choices and a melee option.  The best thing about the guns was that there wasn't one or two that were obviously the ones you had to take with you, you had the choice to pick whatever two you liked and make your way through the game.  Of course there were times that one gun was much more useful than another but for the rest of the time you could run with what you want, till you ran out of ammo anyways.  Enemies were not to difficult for the most part outside of a few areas that were tricky.  Later game enemies did start presenting a bit more of a challenge.  They used cover surprisingly well and did attempt flanks and the like.The setting, enviroment, graphics, etc... were all top notch, there is pretty well nothing that I could complain about in that department.  From the beauty of the open spaces in destroyed dubia to the smaller areas were unspeakable horrors abounded, everything was just so well presented.And the story.  Without getting into spoilers because this is a game that should be experienced spoiler free.  I loved the story, I'm still not sure I entirely got everything that there was to get from the story, but thats the great part.  The game did leave some choices to make, as to what exactly those choices decided at the end of the day, well thats why I want to play the game more than once, and I can't really think of any FPS single player campaings that made me want to come back for more.  The only big gripe that I had with this game was with your AI teammates and their use of cover, or well lack of cover I guess.  The two AI teamates that you travel the game with are better than a lot of other AI teamates other games have stuck you with, these guys actually can kill an enemy or two but they tend to walk stupidly out of cover every now and then.  They would end up dying foolishly and you'd have to break cover to revive them or mission failure.But to sum it all up.  This is exactly what I've wanted out of a FPS single player campaign.  Everything was presented beautifully.  There was a decent selection of weapons to keep the shooting interesting and a story that above all else makes the game stand out far above a lot of other FPS campaigns and is something that I would whole heartedly recommend to almost any FPS fan.

Posted: January 20, 2014
												A gamers must read as it were, it is so impactful and horrific that I often bring it up as an example of what video game stories can be. I played a demo for this game at pax east and left thinking it was nothing more than a 3rd person shoot the brown people game. I could not of been more worng. It teaches you a less in blood and ash that is impossible to forget. The highway to hell as it were is in fact a stairway. Each step on it seems more and more important and needed. You justify each and every transgretion in your own way. Further and further you go down the stairs until you look up and see the mountain of your sins behind you. There, you must ask the queston, could you ever even redeem yourself from that mountain or will it hang over you always.Play this game, I cannot say it simply enough and like anything good you will wisfuly think about it years later.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 28, 2015
												This game starts out as your typical first person shooter and quickly evolves into a memorable immersive experience. You will begin questioning if your doing the right thing or not. You will slowly learn what it means to be a true solder and experience the difficult decisions in front of you. And the many dead bodies you leave behind.This game is very story driven. It shows how war can change a person and make them question reality. By the end of the game I was stunned by the ending and even after playing it through a second time my feelings didn't change. If you want a regular FPS get something like CoD or Battlefield. If you want something that you wont forget and will tug your mind in different directions get this!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 31, 2013
												This game is absolutely amazing and has one of the best storyline I have ever came across in any video games. Make sure you pay attention to the dialogues as the game progresses, as not fully understanding the backstory or one event in a chain may drastically hamper the feelings of what the story is trying to push onto you. In my opinion, it's far more important than the gameplay at times in order to get the most of this game because of so. The plot development is very well thought out and unpredictable, and the chain of events plus the sudden twist near the end will really make you think deeply once the game concludes. A lot of the cutscenes in the game are not like typical ones you'd find in modern shooters, as they were made to emphesize the emotions felt by the characters as well as passing it to you. A movie should be made based on the plot of this game, as there hasn't been much military movies made with plot that will make you feel emotional about what the mental torments the soldiers have to go through.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												My overall experience of the game was great. 9/10Moral Choices: There were some choices in the game, but a bit difficult to actually notice them or understand how to make the choice for a couple of them.Story: Was alright, not entirely easy to follow and the end is a bit of a mind♥♥♥♥.Graphics: Some cheap explosive effects from cannisters, and the sandstorms could have used a little polishing.  Other than that the graphics were fantastic, they paid a decent amount to minor details such as injuries and bandaging them up as the game goes along.Guns: There was a decent variety, but I mostly stuck to the starting weapons, the pistol had amazing accuracy and stopping power, and the rifle had little kickback.Controls: Pretty good with some dashing/sprinting exceptions. IE: Trying to manuever around and taking cover on a column was tough.  Also the toggle mode for sprint was annoying as hell, holding it down and letting go would have been much better.AI: The AI was decent, but at some points there were glaring issues and oddities in their behaviour.  Not enough to detract too much from the gameplay.Some of what these guys were wearing made absolutely no sense for a desert. IE: A super heavy suit of armorDifficulty: Played it on the 2nd hardest mode, felt it was mostly well balanced.Theres a difficuly spike towards the end, which I found very frustrating.I don't think the game was done justice, for my first over the shoulder "FPS" I was quite pleased with it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 8, 2015
												Spec Ops: The Line, man oh man was that a great game.  While the game was a very generic third person shooter, it had an amazing story, very similar to Heart of Darkness or Apocalypse Now.   You see the transformation of a man into a monster as he makes his way through the game, and sometimes you fell really bad about some of the things that go down.   The Sandstorm and falling sand concept was interesting, though not much of a game changer.  Mutliplayer however is dead, I think I've managed to play five games the entire time I've owned it, and three of them were a friend and I against one random who popped into the game.  So the game looks good, plays well but bland, but its the story that keeps you hooked.  Don't bother with multiplayer unless you have some friends who might be kind enough to play with you.  I'd say this game is a 9/10 in my eyes, and yes this game has a few flaws, but its nothing game breaking, and to some people they might not even be flaws.  So I would recommend picking this game up, it isn't much since its been out for a while, or get it when it comes on sale, you won't regret it, and you'll get your money's worth out of it.  K thanks.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 26, 2014
												If you haven't played it yet, I suggest you do, as it has the greatest story ever written in my opinion.  While it's multiplayer may not be the best, it is the single player that it was made for.The game tricks you by making it look like a Call of Duty clone in the third person, but it than hits you with something that you never see in games.  The US Soldiers as the villians.  As you journey, the game shows you many of the terrible things that is happening, even showing you what you have done in a scene so full of emotion, that it should go down as one of the greatest scenes in gaming.  The further you go, the more your character becomes more violent, showing what war does to soldiers.  Soon you feel conflicted, as you don't want to kill the enemy, but you must... because you are the hero.  Than it wraps up with an ending that you will never see coming.  In the end, you are left with your thoughts, with the credits rolling, and asking yourself this "Am I doing this in every FPS and TPS I play?"If that doesnt get you to buy the game, I don't know what will.  This game gets an 9/10, only because of one major plothole in the game, and the floaty controls.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 7, 2015
												Unique TPS with good gameplay mechanics, an apocalypse-now type story and an excellent setting.Good♥♥♥♥♥♥+The setting is one of my favourites so far in gaming. Think a creative, beautiful and post apocalyptic Dubai.+Story is interesting and different than the norm with subtle clues and interesting decisions.+Gameplay mechanics worked well for me, but not for some. It's mainly a cover based shooter.+Style, sounds, weapons and music. The main title has (I think) Star Spangled Banner by Jimi Hendrix playing.+Melee finishers on downed enemies work nicely. No instant takedowns.+Multiplayer is actually pretty good. There's free co-op to but I havn't tried it yet.+(MINOR SPOILER) As the story progresses your character's finishing moves and "taunts" get more brutal. Nice touch.Don't feel right: -The shooting can get somewhat repetetive as there is not a lot of variation in what you can do.-Little replay value unless you want the story again from a more understanding perspective.Conclusion:The game is solid and of appropriate length for a shooter. I'm glad they didn't drag it out unecessarily and that the gameplay mechanics are of good quality. Nothing ruins immersion and good story like bad gameplay. Sadly the story didn't get a hold of me emotionally as it did for some, I really wish I could get into it but I just couldn't get real emotion from it as a whole. Certain parts got to me a little but not overwhelmingly. Still, it was a very satisfying take on one of my favourite tales: man goes into darkness and creates his own vision of society. Certain parts of the story/ending confused me a little but the whole thing is up to interpretation and certainly worth venturing into. Games like Far Cry 3, The Last of Us (especially), Mass Effect series and MGS series are examples of what engaged me emotionally. It's unfortunate that this did not but I still loved the experience and was always eager to play on and uncover the story unfolding. Maybe I've played too many shooters and become a little detached, who knows? Throughout the story you will get to make a few moral decisions but I won't say any more on that.Anyway, I'd give it a 9/10 easily, a full 10 if it had increased combat options/variation. I'm not gonna mark it down for failing to grab me as it did for others, however, as it deserves praise nonetheless.

content:
Posted: January 21, 2014
												Cover based third person shooter set in a sand-covered Dubai, the gameplay isn't too bad, but nothing very different.  The beginning is a tad slow, but that's alright.  The thing that makes Spec Ops: The Line so incredible is the story.  A story that focuses on the horrors of war and violence.  You'll be forced to do horrible things, and make horrible choices. If you're looking for a multiplayer game, you probably won't want this.  If you're looking for a game with a fantastic story, this is it.  When it's all over, and the sand settles, all you'll be able to think is "Dear God...what have I done?".Highly recommended.
