number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 25, 2012
												Spec Ops: The Line is a reboot of the old Spec Ops franchise which last game was released a decade ago. Despite being lauded for its "accurate" portrayal of the military life, The Line still plays like your typical third person cover shooter.Its cookie cutter mechanics aside, one thing The Line will certainly be remembered for is its dark and gripping plot. The player assumes the role of Captain Walker, one of three Delta Force soldiers tasked with locating a missing battalion.On top of the many twists and turns, the game will also ask the player to make several moral choices. Unfortunately, these moments are far in between, even in a game as short as 6 to 7 hours, and their impacts aren't played out to their fullest potential.In a game where the biggest threat comes from American soldiers and civilians, Spec Ops: The Line bends the expectation of modern shooters. Sadly, with its short campaign, subpar mechanics and dead multiplayer, full price is a tad too much.Grade: B-

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 18, 2013
												Gameplay is bland and mediocre, since everything it does HAS and WILL be done (I honestly thought we evolved beyond turret sections, but I was mistaken) and it's pretty short (took me about 8 hours in total on hard mode in my first playthrough). But the story is good; there are a few really good moments that simulate PTSD in your character, and the protagonist slowly grows a beard throughout the game. The multiplayer, as described by the lead designer Cory Davis, is a "low-quality Call of Duty clone in third-person" and a "waste of money." I played one match with a total of 4 people (including myself) and it crashed mid-match. I was never able to join a second one.

content:
Posted: January 20, 2014
												Spec Ops: The Line. Praised for the wrong reasons, bashed for the wrong reasons. As someone who took the time to complete all achievements in this game, I think I can safely say it has a special place in my heart. So maybe I'm biased. Oh well. Look, there's more to this game than the infamous scenes you probably know about by now. The game's so much more interesting in its subtle elements and references to previous works of literature or film. Look, just play The Line. Or don't. Some people played it and thought it was a pretentius piece of crap. Well, they're kind of right. It tries too hard sometimes. But for some reason, I can't keep forgetting about this little game. Something about it just feels... right to me. Maybe it's the 33rd's interesting personalities. Maybe it's the great music. Maybe it's the feeling of "what just happened?" you'll often experience. Just remember one thing: you can leave Dubai, but Dubai can't leave you.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 22, 2014
												Brilliant game, wonderful and insightful commentary on the tropes of first person shooters and the morality of conflict as a whole. By the end of the game, I was hating myself for what had simply seemed natural at the time.Let me qualify this, however, by saying that the game does box you into some of the "choices" you make. Where the game's intended plotline does not coincide with your actual wishes, there's a distinct dissonance that can lead to blaming the game rather than yourself, as I think was probably intended.Addionally, the gameplay was rather frustrating and not very well designed. I would often end up repeating certain segments again and again simply because of lack of cover, clunky controls, or unclear sources of damage. One segment, in which there was a helicopter shooting in through a window that had to be avoided, I ended up repeating over and over simply because I couldn't tell where it was shooting (where I could run) and nothing seemed to be working. In the end, I got through by pure chance. Also, these sections would frequently be in the vicinity of a cutscene (which would have to be rewatched every time), or at least take a rather large amount of time to reload, which contributed to an overall feeling of extreme frustration at times.Overall, do play this game, and do try to play it through to completion, but perhaps choose one of the easier difficulties to avoid the experience being ruined by poor gameplay design.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 19, 2014
												If you want a great single player experience, this really is a great game for that.Spec Ops The Line may look like your standard 3rd person shooter. In many ways, it is. However, this is somewhat deliberate due to the context of the game being a gritty, dark game in a unique setting that makes you question everything about shooters such as these.This is a game that reminds you the reality of war compared to war in video games. In many games, you gun through loads of enemies because thee game told you to without thinking why. This game makes you think why.  In many games, you're a hero that saves the  day. This game makes you think what makes you that hero. The game beats you up for doing tthings that it common practice in shooters, and really makes you think differently about modern day shooters we see all so much of. This is helped by some great voice acting and script work along with both subtle and shocking story devices that make this game feel unique. The story has some shocking moments that you'll want to experience for yourself. Those looking for a rich gameplay experience or a multiplayer masterpiece or even a game that makes you feel good for being an ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ that kills more people than he saves may want to go elsewhere. Those looking for a unique story and setting with developed characters and good enough gameplay that questions everything in the shooter genre to date, this game is for you.

content:
Posted: May 14, 2014
												Fantastic game that i have finished in two sittings today, kept me hooked with excellent gunplay and story telling. Guns feel weighty and have some nice recoil. The music soundtrack is fantatsic and utilised perfectly at the right times. The scripting, voice acting,  gun and all round sound design is just superb. Funny how the titles that seem to basically go unnotcied these days always end up impressing me the most. Only 5 hours so maybe best to purchase in a sale but really the work that went into this, having played this now, i can say it's worth it. Nice use of the Unreal Engine aswell at times with some nice eye candy. First game i have completed aswell in a day for a long long time.AI also desreve a big mention as they are what made it enjoyable for me. They flank and try to flush you  out with grenades if you try and hamper down too long. They also try to move if you pin them down and will jump away from nades. They still do dumb stuff every now and then, but 90% of the time they are actually really aggressive and realistic.

content:
Posted: May 16, 2014
												This game isn't GOTY by any means, at least not on modern terms anyway.This game isn't a fully-grown RPG or a thoroughly made shooter either. It's mechanics in both shooting and plot advancement are somewhat bulky and unfinished, and you will have to deal with it while playing all the time.This very game, however, excels at telling a story like few games I could recall over the last decade. Its story is grim, plainly simple and unhappy. The story isn't precisely original or ground-breaking, but you will not predict it all the way. And it'll take your breath away from time to time like rarely before.You will enter Dubai and perish there. There is no other choice, and you will understand why.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 11
												First, let me point out the things I didn't enjoy about the game. It's a corridor shooter where every event is scripted; you have little control over the development of the story, though you do have to make some decisions along the way. The game has a lot of cut-scenes and provides few challenges, other than just shooting people. There are not really any puzzles and the game points you to every direction you need to go. The controls can also be awkward at times, for example you cannot leap over a tiny obstacle, but move slightly and you'll be able to jump over the taller part of the obstacle. However, I did enjoy the game. The story is good, and it just keeps getting better and better throughout the game. I also really enjoyed the voice acting of the game and character development. If you like third-person corridor shooters, this is definitely a game worth your time.

content:
Posted: June 2, 2015
												I went into this game thinking I'd get a mindless third-person Call of Duty that I could play every once in a while when I'm bored.Boy was I wrong.Graphics are pretty good, especially lighting-effects, the fire and shadows look amazing and even though you're walking through sand the whole time. You get enough variety in the colors and set-dressing that it doesn't get boring.Some things that need to be fixed on the Linux version though:-Even when it's installed on an SSD there are multiple moments where the game freezes for several seconds in every level, usually when it's saving, which is pretty annoying. Other than that the performance is good (constant 60+FPS at max settings with a 560TI and a Core 2 Quad)-If you have two monitors the game seems so only start on the left one unless you put "--eon_force_display=1" into your launch-options but even then it will start with the resolution of the left monitor, so you have to disable or unplug it, which is annoying.-I got less than one FPS when enabling VSYNC, meaning the game would freeze for several seconds even in the main menu.I haven't tried the game on Windows, but I'm pretty sure those issues aren't present there. The port is very new and I'm sure these issues will be fixed very quickly.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 30, 2014
												Imagine you go to the movie theatre to watch what you figure will be a bombastic, Michael Bay action movie. Only every 15 minutes or so, the action stops, zooms in on one of the bodies and a voiceover comes on, telling you all about his parents, childhood dreams, and the 2 kids and cancer stricken wife he's left behind. And every time it ends with "and we wouldn't have had to kill this guy if it wasn't for you and your sick entertainment habits. You horrible, ♥♥♥♥ing monster, stop enjoying war." This game doesn't hold your hand, it doesn't make you feel self-rightous for playing the hero. It just tosses you a gun, throws you into a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ situation, and actually makes you feel for what's going on. You will not find another modern warfare game that dares make you think this hard, or even at all, about what it is you're actually "enjoying" doing. If you play games just for a bit of fun, move along. But if you think that gaming can tell affecting stories just as well if not better than other mediums, you have to pick this game up.

content:
Posted: September 25, 2014
												Let me start off with this important fact; this game is NOT fun. It is incredibly gripping, and engaging as all hell, but it is not fun. This is intentional, and it is a FANTASTIC decision by Yager. If you're looking for a millitary shooter wherein the multiplayer is used to put the campaign in passanger seat, this is not what you want. This game's campaign is the entire focus, there is a multiplayer mode, and it is entertaining, it's a distant second to the amazing piece of work that the campaign is. This is a shooter that manages to deliver on an absolutely astounding narrative and succeeds in critically examining the reasons we play these military shooters as frequently as we do. I cannot recommend this game highly enough.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 13, 2014
												This game is tedious, annoying, frustrating and simply not much fun.And that's what makes it so great."What?" You might be asking yourself. What makes a tedious, unfun game so great? Is it some kind of "So bad it's good" kind of thing? Absolutely not, it was made this way intentionally, and for very good reasons. Spec Ops: The Line is very much like Schindler's List. You're not supposed to feel good about it once you've gone throught he story.The real problem with reviewing a game like this is that, without giving out spoilers, it's impossible to find a way to say, "Ya, play it guys, seriously!" Without some kind of attempt to list out what makes this game special, all I can say is, "The gameplay is lackluster, there are obvious monster closets, the AI is horrid and the multiplayer should have just been ignored entirely. I totally recommend this, 8/10." And that comes off as just strange.So, to try and do this without spoiling too much (and if I do, I apologize for the unintentional spoil), Spec Ops is less a game and more a thematic deconstruction and criticism of modern military shooters. And by deconstruction, I mean a total, across the board deconstruction. The game goes all-in on many gaming tropes and points out various areas that could easily use improvement or development into a generally quality mechanic and also makes it a point to deconstruct the players who play military shooters themselves.The following topics are given a deep insight:- The player's relationship with the main character- Who really controls who? Does the player control the character or is the game controlling the player?- The effects of dehumanizing the enemy on a person and, by extension, the player- Tedious gameplay that highlights the effects and shock of what people experience in combat- Moral ambiguity and a lack of any real clear "good" or "evil" in the game- Demonstratably real effects of cognitive dissonance experienced by returning soldiers suffering PTSD- The illusion of choice in video games- How easy it is to convince people to blame others for "forcing" them into choices they don't have to makeA particular poignant point takes part in the final acts of the game where the game questions if you, the player, are beyond help and are incapable of seeing what's beyond Call of Duty and its clones and pre-emptively telling anyone that scores the game low due to monster closets and tedious third person cover shooting mechanics that they completely missed the point and are beyond help.Everything about the game is designed as intentional and develops a deep experience that's difficult to find in gaming. While games like The Stanley Parable do a good job parodying the insanity of player choice, it fails to truly get the player to stop and think about it, let alone cast a wide net over the entire first person shooter genre and intelligently question nearly every gameplay mechanic, enemy AI complexity, faceless enemy syndrome, plot decisions and concept of legitimate choice.If it wasn't for the deliberate end-game reveal, various load screen quotes and even the changing menu screen graphic, I would have simply thrown this game to the side as some kind of boring, derivitive shooter trying to be macho. But everything about this game is lovingly intentional, from the three man squad with token black man explosive expert and wisecracking white guy to wave after endless wave of idiot enemy. The whole game exists as a critique of the FPS genre, the games industry and the players themselves. And it's not a caustic, nasty critique, but one that asks us to think why we suffer through these mechanics and why we don't demand improvement or something better. Even using the fact that this game can be called "Spec Ops 11" is deep in and of itself since using a brand new IP would have missed out on critically adressing the excessive sequelitis that the gaming industry is stuck in.Spec Ops: The Line is a bad and tedious game, but it's meant to be, and with the plot and decisions made within the game itself turns it into a brilliant commentary on what has happened to the games industry and the modern games consumer. I highly recommend you experience it in full to understand for yourself what's happening. It's a game that needs to be played since those Let's Play videos will do it a disservice as your active participation is necessary to get the complete experience as to what Yaeger is attempting to tell us all.And I thank Yaeger for making me think.The gameplay is lackluster, there are obvious monster closets, the AI is horrid and the multiplayer should have just been ignored entirely. I totally recommend this, 8/10.

content:
Posted: March 5, 2013
												Spec Ops: The Line, to me, is an underrated game because it tells one hell of a story. While it doesn't offer a lot of innovation in terms of gameplay, the story truly makes up for everything it lacks. Set in a future, sand-ridden Dubai, you and your 2 Delta Force comrades are sent in to investigate the disappearance of a group of U.S. soldiers stationed in Dubai. What you and your team discover is something darker than expected and nothing ever goes the way you want it to. The way this game delivers the story is truly fantastic and story is truly gritty and will leave thinking about certain aspects in life. If you ever want a modern 3rd person shooter with a great story, get Spec Ops; you won't be disappointed. The gameplay is similar to many 3rd person shooters but like I stated previously, it's the story that makes this game truly shine.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 16, 2015
												Apocalypse Now:  DubaiThe combat is solid enough, controls are slightly strange but entirely passable.   I'm not personally a fan of games on rails but this one is a decent roller coaster ride that makes the rails a bit more acceptable for me.Enemies react to being shot in limbs appropriately and shotguns feel great, which is honestly a rarity in games.  The game gives a lot of forced prompts for commands and actions you have to or are only capable of doing at those moments which is strange and irritating.  The giant flashing prompts on the screen forcing your hand really take you out of the immersion of the story, which could be pretty good if the prompts didn't reinforce an arcade shooter feel.  The cover system is done fairly well, although i found myself fighting with the controls in many instances because it's just a few slight changes from what standard shooters bring you to expect.I have run into some instances where invisible barriers would block my shots and they threw in the generic heavily armored (Commonly known as bulldozer) type unit who can be frustrating to an extreme when most enemies react appropriately, a sticky grenade or an RPG on his facemask will do little more than break the mask off and stun him.  The bare face of his still requires significant amounts of shots to kill him with any weapon despite being unarmored which means damage is based on body parts and not types of armored cover.  In a shooter, this can be pretty irritating but expected from the lazier ones, so it might not bother other people as much.Ammo can be quite scarce for you and you alone as your team mates have unlimited ammo, dreadful aim, and unlimited grenades but can only be used in designated situations or of their own personal choosing.  They also pick their own cover in your general area which can occasionally put them on the wrong side of it, forcing your hand to go save them in the open during a bad enough situation to get them downed.  I haven't tried the Multiplayer or Co-Op yet so I can't comment on those.Combat  7/10Story      7/10Controls 6/10Visuals   7/10Docking score for the excessive HUD prompts and the heavily armored Bulldozer unit because those are just lazy, especially considering the environment.I'd have to give the game a 6/10 overallThe game is good for a few bucks, I would recommend it if you can catch it on a decent sale.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 16, 2015
												Spec Ops: The Line offers a campaign of approximately 8 hours in length when you play on the two hardest difficulties or about 18 hours if you seek to get all the achievements. I found the story engagging and thought provoking. The difficulty for this game is perfect but ultimately felt gamey as enemies shoot about enough lead to sink a large warship. I did not experience multiplayer as it appears to be dead at the time of this review. It looks to be a tack on that has nothing to do with the campaign anyway.Gameplay mechanics are solid offering a 3rd person shooter with a cover system. It is key to use this system in order to excel at the game so there really isn't any option to play differently. Ammunition is scarce enough that you must rely on accuracy and making your shots count. Your two squadmates that you work with are able to be given attack commands unless you are in the middle of a standstorm with them or seperated.I experienced no technical difficulties and no crashes whatsoever which is way too rare nowdays. Performance is superb; experienced no framerate issues or laggy input.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 9, 2015
												Well, I finished this game almost at once, so we can kinda say it sucked me in. Let's start with a little summary of the game.Spec Ops: The Line is a rather linear TPS with a couple of places you can make your own decision between♥♥♥♥♥♥ and even bigger♥♥♥♥♥♥ And you'll feel♥♥♥♥♥♥in the end. The story:Delta Force sent to Dubai for a recon mission that quickly turns into a rescue mission, then into a "shoot everything that moves" mission. It gets confusing at times, but the end (which I won't spoil you) helps. It's...not what you'd expect. You start out as your standard US Soldier shooter with the grizzled veterans shouting commands, shooting baddies, being badass, but that quickly turns around. You are just a piece of the chess game of the forces behind the scenes. To give credit to the game, the story of Dubai getting hit by sandstorms, and getting Fallout'd is rather cool. And the visuals match, but bit later about that.Through the game I felt I was playing a TV series. Heck, it'd make a bloody good mini-series - about 6 episodes or so. The characters are good, and while not overdetailed, they do their job. And when I finished it, I felt like after a good TV show or movie. It left satisfied, but somehow empty. The conversions are awesome. I had a few laughs, but the interactions between the characters never went over the top, and kept me interested throughout the story. Nobody felt flat or uninteresting, so that's a pretty good thing too.Overall, 8/10. I had little to no expectations, but left with something I won't forget soon.Gameplay:It's a rather standard TPS with a decent selection of firearms. You get Assault Rifles, Shotguns, Pistols, SMGs, LMGs, and so forth. Most of them has a secondary mode, which is to say switch the sniper rifle's zoom (from 8x to 16x), or put a sound suppressor to the M4A1. It's fun, and while the diversity forces you to either be a really accurate shooter, or switch your weapons frequently. Ammo boxes scattered around the maps help you. The cover system while sometimes tad awkward, is good. Made me think of Mass Effect. In every section you can find pieces of intels - a great way for knowing the backstory a bit better, and adds to the overall feel to the game. You'll be more disturbed after you find them fo' sure. Sometimes they are at obvious places, but you gotta look for the to find all.The game is rather linear, but with a game like this, it's not much of a problem. I wouldn't list this as a pro, but neither as a con. It's just linear and that's it. 7/10 - you'll remember the game for the story, as the gameplay is, while rather flowing, brings nothing new.The visuals:Like in my Sleeping Dogs review (which you probably haven't read, but I like to mention my other written stuffs), I have to state I don't have the full specifics to play the game on High graphics. I went with medium, and it ran with about 30 fps. For me, it's solid, and the game, while not gorgeous, it looked good. The Sandstorm'd Dubai (which is almost Darude, but let's stay away from memes for a second) looks good. It's pretty detailed, and I never got bored of the environment. It wasn't exactly the same as far as I recall, and fighting on the top of a skyscraper is a nice change after eating sand on ground level. It matched the game, so I'm fine with it as is.Overall a 8/10.Sounds:Okay, this is awesome. The mad DJ with the hits of the 80s that he plays seemingly random, the ambient music, and the OST for the game is AWESOME. Fitting, believable, and you'll feel that it gives a lot to the game. You'll eventually search for the OST on Youtube, and save it to listen later. It's really good. Kudos to the composer.10/10Overall I'd give this game a 8.5 out of 10, totally worth playing, and totally worth your money. Be aware of the graphic images of gore, death, and the feeling of emptiness and guilt after you've finished the game, regardless of your choices.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 7, 2014
												Nolan North voicing the main character is a strong selling point in this game. As tired as I am of 1st Person militaristic shooters like Call of Duty and Battlefield, with all their awestruck destruction and "omg" comradery moments, it's a tired genre. Well this is a 3rd person action adventure game with incredibly well done sand effects that apply to combat. Like shooting a glass ceiling and watching the sand envelop your enemies. Fighting in sandstorms provides intense drama during the impaired visibility. This game takes you on a journey, both storywise and comraderywise with your two cohorts. There's moments that blur the lines between right and wrong and survival and completing the mission. The lines really blur when you fight American troops because they shoot at you first. Trying to figure out what happened before the sandstorm took down Dubai and where all the survivors and the troops are, is so intense.

content:
Posted: December 21, 2013
												8/10Although the game is kinda short (it took me ~6 hours to complete at one of the higher difficulty settings) it is defniteley worth checking out and is IMO the best military shooter out there right now. Gameplay: Standard cover based shooting as we all know it from Unchated, GOW or Max payne 3. Nothing special but it is fun and works almost flawless.Story: It is the story the stands out the most in SO:the Line and is what seperates this game from other modern shooters. Games such as BF, COD or Medal of Honor often try to show the cruelty of war but always fail to do that. But SO:The Line differs from those games because it takes it's time and let you soak in the atmosphere. Scenes like walking through a mass grave or an execution give you goose bumps. Also the characters are well written and voiced.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 24, 2013
												What drew me initially to this game was the fact that it is indeed an offical part of the "Spec Ops" series (As in "Spec Ops: Rangers Lead The Way" and "Spec Ops: Ranger Elite", two of my favorite old school tactical third person shooters). I did some research, and the buzz/hype around the story for this game caught me off guard, as the older titles were not particularly known for their storylines, but instead for their difficult and tactical gameplay. I gave in, and decided to buy it, and was most certainly NOT dissapointed. The story was absolutely incredible, and definitely deserved every bit of praise it's been given. For me personally, it was pretty mind blowing. The gameplay however, did not quite match up. The tactical shooter gameplay was almost non-existant, and was traded in for a more bog standard Gears-like style of cover based third person shooting. I do admit the combat was punchy, and satisfying, but definitely nothing too note worthy. It's also a very good looking game, with the destroyed city of Dubai still managing to be stunning, even in sand dune filled ruins. Definitely recommended!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 30, 2012
												At a glance, you could easily dismiss this game as another generic military shooter. It is and it isn't. The mission structure is by the books Call of Duty style: move forward, stop, kill a million enemies, move forward a bit and do the same. However, what elevates it above other military shooters is the story.You're deployed to Dubai -- or what's left of it -- on a mission to locate survivors of a cataclysmic sandstorm. Simple enough, right? It would be, if not for the war raging within. As you explore the ruins of Dubai, questions are raised. How far is too far? Is the pursuit of your mission worth it, in spite of the casualties along the way?If a thought-provoking story is of interest to you, I strongly recommend Spec Ops. On the other hand, if you are simply looking to kill people with abandon, you're best to look elsewhere. Whilst the shooting is solid, it can't carry the game and actually becomes tedious towards the end.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 6, 2013
												8.2/10+ Interesting Story+ Amazing writing/script+ Great Characters and Nice Character Development + Engaging story that makes you feel emotionally involved+ You make decisions that affect outcomes+ Great Twist at the end+ Nice use of environments in play+ Different locations throughout Dubai that all are interesting- Some "choices" seem like you actually have no control- Nothing new with gameplay (Generic Third Person Shooter Gameplay)- Some controls were frustrating (ex. X [Gamepad] was used to get to cover AND to run)Overall Spec Ops: The Line was an interesting and engaging interactive cinematic experience. Spec Ops had the story of a big budget hollywood action movie, but also had the familiar third person shooter in it. The story kept me on the edge of my seat and wanting to know what happens next. At some parts Specs Ops was just another grindfest, but then again what sooter today isn't? Spec Ops did not have a huge selection of guns, which did not hurt the game at all. Instead of looking for the coolest weapon, you were looking for weapons to help you clear the level so you could find out what happens next. In conclusion Spec Ops: The Line is a great game that should not be missed out on due to the new emotional and mental take on war. The game will rank up there with my favorite games that would make me want to play again, to play the many different ending.P.S. The graphics for this game was pretty okay, nothing fancy, but nothing terrible. I put this at the end of my review as to not get this confused with pluses and minuses. I would NEVER include graphics as a means of judging a game.I hope you found this review helpful.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 30, 2013
												Ok, this game kicks♥♥♥♥♥  Its an over the shoulder third person squad shooter.  The controls are spot on ( i use x-360 gamepad) and the gameplay is a blend of shooting with some tactics and uses cover a lot.You get to order your other two squad members two basic commands, either focus fire (useful for heavly armorded targets) or stun grenade targetes.  You can also order them to move to different locations to flank enemies which is important if you are pinned down by a machine gun.  Overall their AI is pretty smart and they usually do fine on their own, providing you backup while you are the star.The best part of the game is the story and environment though.  The ruined city of Dubai has a life of its own, and even effects strategies to a certain extent.  The story shines and will really have you thinking and wanting to replay it to see just how your decisions during the game effect how things shape up.Graphics are really nice and ran flawlessly on my computer (nothig special here).  The sounds are realistic and high quality.I cant comment on the mulitplayer as I havent tried it yet, but I look forward to the co-op mode.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 20, 2014
												Spec Ops: The Line is really nothing at first glance. Any passerby would glance at this online and assume it to be a pseudo rip-off of Joseph Conrad’s Heart of Darkness and subsequently Francis Ford Coppola’s Apocalypse Now, complete with a generic third person shooter element and cover system.And thus the game has already tricked you, the first of many narrative and visual tricks The Line will pull. Maybe as a gamer you don’t want to be tricked. You want to be entertained or praised. But there is none of that here. So why play this game? Because quite simply, love it or hate it, there is simply nothing quite like this.storySpec Ops: The Line opens generically enough. Nolan North voicing the gruff captain Martin Walker, leading a Delta team consisting of Lieutenant Adams and Staff Sergeant Lugo, ordered by the US Army to do recon and bring in John Konrad (one of many nods to Hearts of Darkness), commander of the 33rd Battalion, lost in Dubai after sandstorms destroyed the city. As Walker and his team traverse the desert, it soon becomes clear that not all is clear, and the lines of good and evil are blurred to a point where you, the player, will be questioning whether you’re doing the right thing.narrativeIt’s clear that the dark narrative mixed with sensational sound and voice acting meant that Yager Development (the developers) took an extra step in ensuring that the player was giving a harrowing and memorable experience that would leave you talking about it for years to come. Special props must be given to head writer Walt Williams, who provides a sensational story with huge mature undertones. If anything, The Line must be experienced for the story alone.graphicsIn terms of graphics, the sand-covered Dubai is quite a stunning vista. The towering skyscrapers all half buried in sand, the gorgeous backdrop that makes you feel like a tiny ant in a huge (linear) world and the graphic depictions of violence all lend a hand to the amount of immersion you would feel. In terms of violence, the game goes all in and really makes you question how much fun you’re really having, as you sickeningly pop another head in a cloud of red.For a graphics comparison, the PC version remains the slight winner, with sharper graphics all around, along with the standard freedom of tweaking for your personal rig. But the differences are honestly quite small and on any platform of your choice you’ll end up with the same experience.gameplayIn terms of gameplay, The Line remains painfully average, though this, like everything in the game, is for a reason. It’s an unremarkable third person shooter that you would have played in dozens of past games (Gears of War comes to mind immediately), complete with wonky cover system. The game gives you different weapons from rifles and pistols to shotguns and launchers to dispatch your foes in appropriately gruesome ways, as you slowly make your way through the corpses of the Damned 33rd.There is a ‘sand’ mechanic that honestly feels a little like a missed opportunity, where the sand of Dubai plays a big part in firefights. This comes in the form of sandstorms and sinkholes that change the dynamic of the battlefield, but these happen very rarely and in a strictly linear and scripted sense. It would’ve been nice to see a bit more random events thrown in.shootingThere are also random ‘moral’ choice events that come up every now and then that throw up an interesting thought. For fear of spoiling, they aren’t as black and white as you’d assume in normal games (Mass Effect or Bioshock comes to mind), but really just shades of dark and death, and they are never what they same. It’s a relief to see that acknowledgements were made to the gamer for thinking outside of the box, as there is always a ‘hidden’ option to choose, if you did not want to choose between two face options.The soundtrack lends a huge hand in The Line’s final presentation. The orchestral score blaring in the background as you conduct firefights is spectacular and the choices of classic rock songs gives off a sense of atmosphere and feeling that you are in a war. The music that accompanies the final few minutes in particular will send shivers up your spine and result in an ending that you will never forget.conclusionSpec Ops: The Line is really an unremarkable game on the surface, but below the surface is one of the best narratives you could ever experience. The Line is one of the most exciting things to happen to a ‘modern military shooter’ game in a very, very long time, and it is something that should be experienced, whether or not you’ll end up liking it. The Line is one of the best games of 2012, from a year of winners, and deserves to be played, even once.

												Beneath what's apparently yet another generic shooter, watch as a man suffers an ongoing mental breakdown - denying the harsh reality of a disaster so strongly that he hallucinates a more convenient one for himself, losing his mind and alienating everyone that used to trust him. A wonderful kick-in-the-teeth deconstruction of the gung-ho military shooter.Do you feel like a hero yet?

												Truly amazing. A third-person shooter with a realy good story. At first glance it can look as an ordinary shooter. The cover system could use some work and also ther is a fricking button for vault and mlee combat. Very many times you are just smacking the obstacle then jumping over it. Unfortunatly I didn't have pleasure to play Co-op. Also Multiplayer is dead :( ,so don't even think about playing realy. A big plus for me gets also the soundtrack that is switching on in some shootout's. Story is short it should take tou about 5-6 hours to complete (depending on the diffculty).Conclusion:+Ok shooting+Superb story and characters+Soundtrack+Varaitety of locations+Dubai-Cover system-Length-You can miss a lot of intresting backstory when you aren't collecting intel

content:
Posted: December 8, 2015
												I don't usually write reviews, but this game definitely deserves it.  In the beginning, it seems like some cheesy, cheap shooter with pretty decent graphics that is going to be mediocre.  It will feel like you are just running and gunning to rock music playing in the background, trying to make you look like a hard[butt].  The controls can also use some work because the character will do stuff you didn't intend for him to do.  But really soon you find out there is more to it then just that....you forget about the glitchy controls, you forget about the cheesy music and gameplay.  The game grows on you!Throughout the game you taken through the brutality of war, and its consequences.  You see the main characters change over time and see how the war plays a role on them.  Without spoiling anything else, I definitely recommend playing this game at least once! If not, twice or more!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 29, 2016
One of the best games I have ever played.Spec Ops: The Line has one of the most intricate, ominous, and heart-wrenching storylines I have ever seen. Playing this game, you truly feel that every action you take has a lasting effect. With each ultimatum you face, it is difficult to decide between what is easy, what is ethical, and what is right; and it's even harder to decipher if you chose correctly.The gameplay, cinematics, and dialog throughout the game are incredibly immersive. You use your surroundings, you flank the enemies, you work together with AI teammates… When commanding my teammates to take out an imminent threat, I once heard the character shout, "Take out that shotgunner on the stairs to the right!" I couldn't have been more specific myself!I'm not sure I have ever been as captivated and emotionally tied as I have been while playing Spec Ops: The Line. Though the campaign goes quickly, I would HIGHLY recommend this game to everyone who could handle the intense story. It really does take you past the line you never thought you'd cross.

content:
Posted: September 25, 2013
												When I picked up this game, I thought I was buying another faceless brown-and-bloom military shooter on the cheap... you know, Call of Duty/Modern Warfare knock-off with a ruined Dubai gimmick.What I got was so much more. I wish I had purchased it at full price, because the developers deserve much more money than I gave them. This game was fantastic for the story alone. I can't give more detail without spoiling it, but with only a few games have I ever felt this affected or deeply moved by the gameplay. There's a lot of shooting and some of it is repetitive, but it's vastly over-shadowed by the narrative and it's damned beautiful the whole way through. If you haven't played it, I really recommend picking this game up immediately... it's SO much better than it lets on and one of the only games I've ever played that manages to prove its point through every facet of the gameplay.In fact, one of my favorite moments I've ever had in a game happened during one of The Line's loading screens... that's a tall feat, considering. It's that good.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 19, 2016
												On the surface, this game looks like anyother war shooter. You're an American soldier tearing through enemy forces and trying to be the God dang hero! To be honest, Spec ops' gameplay doesnt add much when compared to other third person shooters. But this isnt a game about being a hero, this is a game about war , and in some sense, a game about games. A game that holds you accountable for every life you take, every action you chose, and makes you really think everytime you pull the trigger.  Spec ops adds a new deminsion to the War genre, and blurs the lines between good and evil, right and wrong, etc. As you play, you will begin to notice a twist in the games identity from generic war shooter, to horrific game depicting the harsh reprocusions of war. The character development in this game is unreal and is what really drives this game home. You will see the degredation of your squads morals, mental health, and humanity as they have to deal with the reprocusions of your actions. While the gameplay is somewhat lackluster, the story is truly the best part about this game, and i would easily recommend it to someone who is looking for one heck of a story, and a life ruining experience!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 22, 2016
												Suicide Mission was chosen for my first run, and Fubar second time.No spoilers in this review, after all, there is no fun if you know any story of it before enjoying it.Compared with other shooting games, Spec Ops: The Line is not unique at all or even much more tedious about its gameplay. What players have to do is shoot targets, take cover from gunfire and  move on to a next point, continuously.Control is a bit clumsy, sometimes it may get you killed and repeating under some critical situations couple times. For instance, Sprinting to sandbags for cover, taking cover and vaulting through it, all of the movements do not seem to flow smoothly. Mere conditions that some spots look available to interact with, like beside a low closet of a bar table,  actually not for cover,  are annoying.Graphics is not that appealing even in 2012 , but it is still fine and acceptable. Personally, I like how the developer created the feel while a desert storm is striking. When headshots happen, there is a moment of slow motion effect. With some high-caliber rounded weapons, there is also a gore effect.Music is great, and some classic old rock songs are introduced as well.The essence of this game is about its storyline. I guess that is something worth playing, especially for players who have played lots of shooting games, shooting games especially like CODs. Spec Ops: The Line will definitely blow your mind and thought on shooting games.If you are an enthusiastic shoot'em up gamer and want something different, this game is absolutely for you.Strongly advised, do not read any articles related to its story before finishing the whole game.

content:

												This is an exceedingly unusual game and I don't entirely know what to make of it. It starts off as a fairly conventional good guys shoot up the bad guys desert army affair, but after a while it becomes apparent that something's different. It makes you do terrible things -- no, that's not fair, it doesn't *make* you do anything, but it allows you to do them and then confronts you with them.It's not a fun game in the conventional sense, it's actually quite harrowing and I came away from it feeling rather chewed up inside, but I'm really glad I played it and I'd urge anyone interested in a game that actually confronts the reality of war to give it a go.

content:
Posted: July 10, 2016
												I enjoyed the single player campaign. The story is very interesting and disturbing on many levels. I commend the writers.The gameplay is fairly mediocre. Not much new in this sticky cover shooter. Enemy AI is non existent, on normal difficulty ammo management was important. The guns are fairly standard military shooter. Shotguns encourage aggressive play, the AA12 is great fun. Squad management is present but not very good or original. Star Wars Republic Commando did it better 10 years ago.The graphics are very good, lots of extra effort put into detail. Everywhere you look are enviroments that look unique and add to the story. Level design is almost completely linear with only a few examples of paths for setting up flanking fire.Overall I recommend it, but wait for a steep discount. One playthrough at a fairly slow pace is about 8 hours. How much is 8 hours of good but not great entertainment worth to you?

content:
Posted: March 7
												What we have here is a true GOOD game. Spec Ops : The Line is a straightforward cover shooter, in a military setting with a twist. So what makes it special ?Of course, as many reviewers, I praise the writing first. It's on-par with the first Bioshock in my opinion, and share a few elements. The design is classic military brownfest, but this time, it serves the story. Also, exploring the weird ruins of Dubai's decadence is a really nice change of setting. But more than that, the gameplay is the real force behing this game. The guns feels good, the pacing is good, the difficulty is just right, each weapons feels really different and has its uses, yet you can't really abuse it or stick to one favorite gun, you'll have to make-do. And once again, this serves the story.A great lesson.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 27, 2016
												I think this game is one of the most powerful pieces of modern media and art out there. Many people say they are still waiting for the Citizen Kane of gaming yet completely overlook this. The horrors of the human mind are on display in the most grounded way possible. The genius of the game is the darkness wrapped on an easily digestible shell, you don't know what's wrong until it's too late. Of all the amazing, and I use that term lightly, moments in this game it's the little touches that get you. A good portion into the game you are given the option of executing two men. One stole water rations for his family, the other killed the man's family but he only did so under orders. Who do you choose? When you get to the end you understand what that choice means but in the moment you must weigh your options. I did what don't think most people know about, I shot the snipers who were waiting for me to choose. The two men died in the crossfire but I believed I had done the right thing. That is truly your first step into the madness. Most FPS games hardly tackle the atrocities of war but SO: The Line forces you to confront it, forces you to experience hell. As you descend further into depravity you will undoubtedly question yourself, and the game tries to reassure you, 'You are still a good person', yet in the next breath chastises you, 'Do you feel like a hero yet?'. This leads to the player ultimately coming to grips with the terrible things they've done, and for what? A man back home and a medal that gathers dust, never mind those whose life bled into that godforsaken sand. Never mind the mother clutching her child in a desperate attempt to safe them. Never mind that there was always a choice. There is always a choice, in the moment it might not seem like it but after the dust settles you have to live with the choice you made. You have to live with the blood on your hands, haunted by the sights that are forever burned into your mind so that every second is a nightmare. War is hell. And hell is human. Humanity feared the monsters they believed lurked in the trees, lakes, mountains, and deserts, but the true monster, the one we should all fear, is the monster inside each and every one of us. The darkness that claws and howls to be let loose, the beast that begs for blood, we all have it. Some are more in touch with it and give in, while others are scarred and forever changed by giving into their demons and living with the consequences. Spec Ops explores that beautifully and it can't be praised enough.﻿ I don't feel like a hero. Not in the slightest.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 4, 2016
												Playing this game is rather like watching the proverbial train wreck: you'll be horrified, but you can't look away. This is in no way a bad thing. Spec Ops wants to tell a story about soldiers in war. But unlike games such as Call of Duty, it doesn't want you to feel like an awesome, unstoppable killing machine that's fighting terrorism FOR 'MERICA!!! or whatever; it wants you to see that war is not glamorous, awesome, fun, or desirable. It wants you to see the terrible toll that combat can exact on those who experience it. And above all, it wants you to see that in real conflict, there are no "good guys" and "bad guys," and the world is full of gray areas. War is hell, and anyone who goes in will either join the fortunate dead...or have to live with what they've done to survive.Spec Ops is a third-person cover-based shooter that alternates between desert environments and crumbling urban ruin. You have two squadmates who can be directed to attack specific targets or heal a fallen comrade; they're pretty good at following orders in a timely fashion and, unlike some other AI partners, they're not highly prone to getting themselves shot constantly or hung up on the level geometry. Enemies are decently clever, more than willing to flank you, toss grenades to get you out of cover, or trick you into walking right into a Heavy Trooper's line of fire.The game also offers the clever idea of having drifts of sand piled up on fragile surfaces like windows, which you can shoot out to bury your enemies. It doesn't show up that often, but it's kind of neat when it's there.There's the usual shooter stable of weapons: pistols, heavy pistols, shotguns, sniper rifles, etc. They sound good and feel decently punchy, and aiming is never a problem. Most weapons also have an alternate fire mode, which does add a little depth to the combat.I didn't play the multiplayer, so I can't honestly review it. I will say the developers originally didn't even want multiplayer, and the campaign is designed well enough to stand on its own, so make of that what you will.I highly recommend this game. It is a breath of fresh air in an over-crowded genre that's becoming increasingly generic. This game is also visually stunning, with exceptional voice acting, and sound. It is definitely worth the money and the effort to play the game from the beginning to the end.Final Decision: 8/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 24, 2014
												An absolutely engrossing experience examining the human psyche through the eyes and minds of "hard boiled" American soldiers.  Spec Ops delivers one of the most enjoyable and thought provoking stories in both military shooters and video games to date.  The gameplay, the graphics, and the soundtrack helpt to carry the game well, but it's the story that will make you want to keep on going The gameplay is well refined, with the 3rd person shooting mechanics working very well as you would expect from a game within the past few years.  Decent amounts of environmental disasters and interactions help to keep things fresh and enjoyable.  I was able to complete the game in about 7 hours, though to be honest it seemed like much longer, but in a positive way as I enjoyed my time with this game.The multiplayer seems to be a bust and thats a shame because when there are others to play with it isn't half bad, especially considering the limited 3rd person shooter options for PC gamers.Overall I would absolutely recommend this game, it deserves a playthrough for anyone who enjoys 3rd person shooters and/or especially to those who like a good, thought provoking story.Please upvote this if you agree with this review and enjoyed this game!  I'd love to have as many people play this game as possible and I'd love anyone/everyone's help to attain this goal!  :)

content:
Posted: July 20, 2015
												For a shirt review read the next few lines, for a longer review then go read the shorter review you skimming ♥♥♥♥bag. So the Steam Summer Sale 2015 claimed another $9.89 of my money and thus this game gommba stomped its way to the top of my play priority list. Not at gunpoint this time so I have that going for me. Well it might as well be at gunpoint seeing as the state it left me in after the 4 hours of pure pain and suffering, and yelling to take cover. I knew a few spoilers before picking up this game, the white phosphorus bit, the bit where the black guy turns into Irish from BF4, the turret section, etc., etc. I wanted to get through this game with no surprises and shock. Well the game saw my wants and said,"Well this guy actually wanted a positive outlook on life, he gets the special treatment". I played through it, got frustrated but perservered. My mental state was pretty much neutral: shooting people that were already down, letting characters die, just to see what happens if I actually played the character like I was supposed to. This game made sure that playing the part would be ♥♥♥♥ing disturbing. Imagine Chris Pratt playing as Hitler but with a relatable personality and the whole role revolved around improvising around being cruel. He'll watch the footage and probably curl up into a ball and think on his thought based sins. That's how I felt after seeing what the actual hell Walker was thinking this whole game. No spoilers but when I remembered that the game is based directly on Heart of Darkness/Apocolypse Now near the end, I nearly pisses the bed when I thought I had it all figured out. In the end, the twist made me play through all the endings in a trans and afterwards I started sniffing fundip hoping that it'd improve my mood. Buy the game(on sale) and just go ♥♥♥♥in' nuts. I'll go back to listening to Mad World. All around me are familliar faces, worn out places, worn out face-e-e-e-es....

content:
Posted: September 3, 2015
												well, what can i say about Spec Ops the line?It's not fun to play it. But it's a great game. How do I mean this.You need to know that this game is a masterpiece. And every second of this masterpiece is against war. It must be quite hard to make a shooter, that is against war and this game is in this role not perfect. So for example you kill hundreds of enemy soldiers without really asking about that or an option to make themgive up. But what makes this game so great? It's the great atmosphrere of a beautiful Dubai which is falling into chaos.It is how the game shows what war makes out of humans. So for example the main characters get more and more brutalduring the story. So while the execution kills are in the beginnning a simple shot in the head, does the main character a jump onto the vitim, ramms him his rifle in the mouth and splatters his brain all over the floor.The game shows the player again and again how horrible war can be and much better the player often has the opportunity tochoose.to choose between life and death. To choose between cruelty and mercy. To choose between good and bad. Just too show theplayer in the next moment that his good was the real bad. And this is something you can see then in the protagonist too how he and his unit struggles with the crimes they have done...And way more the game talks to the player so for example in one of the loadingscreens after you killed douzends of civilians there is written, that usually this behaviour would be spoken about infront of the military court but that thisis not reality, right?I can just tell you that I really enyoed playing this game. But except of the great story and the parts that are mentionend up there is it almost a 08/15 shooter.But I can tell you if you want to play a game with a really intense, emotional and great story this game is it.So trust a not-trustfull random stranger and buy this game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 12, 2014
												It's difficult to say anything about Spec Ops: The Line without ruining what makes it what it is. Suffice to say, its strength lies completely in its story, its message, and the fascinating and morbid deconstruction of the modern action game it provides.Its not a 'good' game in the traditional sense; but then again, what it provides is hard to value. And many people will have to judge it for themselves. But I reccomend it, if only because its the only game of its kind to truly make an impact.After all these years, its (in)famous reputation has spread across the 'net, so spoilers are abound. Which is sad, because it's an experience people need to play through first to truly appreciate. But that experince has stood the test of time, and to this day is still just as brilliant and terrible as ever.So, if you've never/barely have heard of Spec Ops up to this point, and have a strong stomach, pick it up and play it. Because I can garuntee there's nothing that comes close to it. No matter what other people may say or think of it, Spec Ops is the only game that has ever changed the way I look at games, forever.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 3, 2014
												I've just finished this game, and I have to say that it is an excellent game overall. While it (like others have pointed out) has clunky controls which at times has made me say "grrrrr....", the story is nonetheless great -- it is thought provoking while depressing at the same time. The graphics are nice, and the audio/soundtrack is good. A non-so-classic take on a (classic?) genre. My total playtime was about 6 hours, which is in agreement with others' times. Hope this helps.Overall, I would recommend if you are looking for a great story, but not necessarily for gameplay. I have to think that the gameplay wasn't *that* bad though. I'm pretty sure that multiplayer is dead, but I'm not really sure. I suspect may be surviving in a dying state... on  the line  (hehe... get it?) 9/10 I'll probably edit this more later.Spoiler thoughts (caution):   I do wonder if I did make choices or if it was only the illusion of choice. An interesting thing is that I sometimes felt like I was doing a little right, even when doing the wrong. I also liked the witty/snarky remarks, like "Do you even remember why you came here?", in the loading screens. The allusions (e.g. "News of my survival have been greatly exaggerated," humored me.)

content:
Posted: June 13, 2016
												I'll recommend this game, but hesitantly. It really takes a certain kind of person to enjoy a game like this. I only say that because it's a boring, generic, and repetitive military shooter. There's quite literally nothing else to the gameplay except hiding behind cover and shooting at enemies. If you actually enjoy that sort of thing, then by all means, buy this game. Personally, I'm not one for that sort of thing in the slightest. I forced myself to finish it purely because the story was decent. Of all the military shooters I've played, this one actually had a story, and it was quite good. The setting is also pretty cool and vivid, which is uncommon in military shooters. So to sum it up, if you like shooting at people, get it. It's great and has an even better story. If you're like me and you need something more to your games, pass it up.

content:
Posted: July 28, 2016
												I just finished the first play through on "Suicide Mission" difficulty. Shooting and all that gives a pretty standard fps feel; there is nothing very unique, but I still enjoyed it. The graphic of the game, being one released in 2012, is looks pretty.The true shining bit of this game is the story. The story is touching; it makes me feel shooting is not fun. At some point of the storyline, you get to make hard decisions as to kill or let go, kill using this way or that way. In this game, your decisions have consequences and these consequences make differences in gameplay and story. So far I have discovered four endings.After the first play through, the most unforgiving difficulty is unlocked. I can’t wait to play it again and try different options.

content:
Posted: August 5, 2016
												When people bring up examples of games is art, chances are this game is brought up at some point or another because of it's subversion of the tropes common of FPS. And this isn't without good reason. Spec Ops works as a creative take on the sort of "War is Hell" stories we've seen a billion times such as "Apoclypse Now" (In fact, both those take inspiration from the book "Heart of Darkness"), but in a way that makes its interactivity mean something. It likely started a trend of games that are not meant to make the player feel good (with varying degrees of success). It's worth experiencing at least once.8/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 29, 2016
												This is a very strong and heavy title. It's really good but prepare for heavy material and emotional moments. The story is amazing, I won't spoil anything but it shows a very interesting side and has a few choices you can make throughout the game that can influence dialogue and scenes to strenghten the emotional immersion the player has regarding the story and actual real life events, to a degree. The gameplay, which is fully linear, is great. You move from point to point throughout beautiful setpieces with your team as you shoot down tons of 'baddies' (maybe?). There are a lot of grey areas explained in the form of extra lore 'Intel' spread about the battlefield that you can find. The voice acting is great, no flaws there and that's very important as they carry the weight of the story very well. Important: some people are saying the game is buggy or broken; it's not. I, in 10 hours of play (2 playthroughs) had 0 crashes. Running on Windows 7, max settings. If the game doesn't work for you, chances are it's on your end, or some uncommon problem you might want to search for online. The sound design and music is great, it really works to pull you in the story and the game itself isn't too hard.There are settings from really easy all the way to pretty darn hard (I recommend hardest settings because it enhances the story experience in my opinion) although going for just the story on easy mode is definitely a possibility. Overall this is a great game, and it does interesting things. I highly recommend this game to any and every fps gamer, or person who's looking for an interesting story. I absolutely loved it and after having completed it I went back immediately to beat the game on FUBAR (definitely the best way to play).

content:
Posted: March 18, 2015
												Usually I can't stand any of the modern, strictly scripted and linear shooters, for plenty of reasons. Most of them do not offer anything interesting in gameplay, and their scripts are generally so bad that they seem to be written by a trained monkey. Well, Spec Ops: The Line is quite an average shooter, when considering the gameplay, but the script and the story are something truly extraordinary and unforgettable. If you're a fan of the Heart of Darkness novella or any of its adaptations, for example Apocalypse Now, you should give this game a try.All in all, I have not encountered before any strictly linear modern warfare shooters with an interesting single player campaign and a truly thought-provoking story. Well, I really hope that this wasn't the first and the last time.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 26, 2014
												Simply amazing.A MUST PLAY for anyone who loves storytelling in games. This one is on par with the greats like Bioshock and Portal.WARNING:THIS IS NOT A CALL OF DUTY CLONE LIKE THE TRAILERS AND BOX ART WOULD HAVE YOU BELIEVE, IT IS BASICALLY THE MOST ANTI-CALL OF DUTY TRIPLE A SHOOTER GAME EVER MADE.THIS GAME ISN'T "FUN" IT'S ENGAGING AND THOUGHT PROVOKING AND YOU WILL NOT HAVE A TRADITIONAL GOOD TIME PLAYING IT!The best way to explain what this game is to start at it's creation.Spec Ops was a shooter series that nobody cared about in the late 90s/early 2000s.2K (the publisher) wanted Yager (the developers) to make a new Spec Ops game. It could be about ANYTHING so long as it was about the US military.What they made was a decent into madness that will make you rethink everything you knew about the Modern Military genre.Many games are "adult" because they have violence and sexual themes, though children still play and enjoy them. This game is adult because it's got mature themes and will make you think.I can't spoil ANYTHING because it's best to go in completely fresh but it's amazingly dark and you will feel awful after beating it, but in a good way.Gameplay's standard MMS fare but played from a third person perspective, similarly to Gears of War. The shooting feels good and they keep adding new, varied weapons to keep things at least somewhat varied. The cover mechanics are pretty clunky and awkward and It all gets kinda boring.But it's not about that, it's about the story.Play this if you want something that questions the MMS genre.Play this if you want to play something that makes you feel awful and think.DON'T play this if you want a pro-USA shooter where you kill the terrorists and stop World War 3.I wholeheartedly reccomend this.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 15, 2014
												This game is amazing because, like most people have pointed out, it breaks alot of "norms" in the shooter genre. The story is amazing, and by the end of it all you genuinely feel bad for walker and for yourself for the things you have done. Alot of reviewers have said that while the story is good the gameplay leaves alot to be desired. Im not really going to argue that but i will say that the shooting mechanics get the job done. This is a 3rd person cover based shooter. There is not really much room to "revolutionize" the industry in terms of shooting mechanics here. It gets the job done and thats it. I found the gameplay fun, and the AI, while not exactly Skynet level intelligent, DOES attempt to give you a hard time if you dont take them out quickly. They will flank you, and use grenades quite frequently (i was playing on the hardest initial difficulty, before unlocking the FUBAR difficulty). A wider choice in weaponry would have been welcome, and perhaps some sort of weapon customization options, but considering the type of game this is, weapon customization would have probably not been incredibly useful overall anyways.What i appreciate the most though, above everything else, are the subtle changes to Walkers character and personality as the game progresses. I dont want to spoil anything, but i will say this: from the start of the game pay attention to how walker acts. From reloading, to taking out enemies, to using the teammate commands. EVERYTHING. Then notice towards the end of the game how he handles taking out enemies, how he gets impatient and screams while reloading, how progressively more brutal and unneccesarily cruel executions become.This is definitely a game that deserves your time. It has an amazing story, amazing characters, and the gameplay is solid. I highly recommend playing this game on the hardest initial difficulty though, because on normal it can feel a tad on the easy side.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 19, 2014
												TLDR; I love this gameCaptain Walker is sexy, especially when he gets mad7/10 overall*This review is for single player campaign mode. I have not tried co-op.I played on a laptop with minimum specs. Framerate drops a lttile at times, but nothing unbearable. Personally I think graphics were great, the characters very well done, and the scenery at times is beautiful...Well, as far as bloody battlefield goes anyway. Don't expect amazing gameplay. Gunplay is clunky when I first played, but after a time I got used to it and ended up getting headshots with my pistol and whatever easy peasy. Gosh, but the sniping is difficult. Some of the guns in this game are a real pain, but I guess that's what's unique about the selection. Each gun is a little different from the next in various ways. After the initial awkwardness, shooting did get satisfiying, but also tired easily. No boss battles of any sort. No real challenges, just...A few obstacles that require just a little more effort than usual. You can spend a fair amount of time searching for hidden journals, which I highly suggest if you want to understand the story completely, but they're very few of these anyway.I actually found myself taking advantage of melee kills moreso than shooting; nothing like Rambo'in down the hallway and elbowing people's faces in.♥♥♥♥♥♥was waay funnn and much more rewarding than shooting. Oh, there are some other glaring problems. For example, there is this one feature where you can apparently command your buddies to shoot something for you...That feature don't work. Plain and simple. Cover system is wonky at best. Stealth? What the hell is the point? But you know, it's all small kinks. It really doesn't matter. It's still functional, enjoyable gameplay.Other than that...Well, you shoot baddies to progress to the next point in the story, and that's about it. No rewards system. Very straightforward get-from-point-A-to-point-B linear play, but that's okay for what this game is because...The game's selling point has to be its story. And this story has some serious DEPTH. The fantastic pacing, the storytelling, the relatable characters...All this coupled with amazing voice acting. I just love hearing Walker's battle cries. Really, talent at its finest. While you actually don't make many tough decisions much like you would in Mass Effect or whatever (in fact you hardly choose at all), the few times that you do, you quickly come to realize just how highly or how little you regard Walker, the MC, and his buddies. That's just how well this game builds you up towards the climax. I don't want to say too much for the story, else I risk spoiling it...Just play it and see for yourself! 7/10, damn well good and one for the records.

												Rife with choice and moral dilema, this game is one of the few thats ever actually made me feel something.This game isn't as finely tuned or glamorous as Battlefield or Call of duty, but it doesn't need to be, thats not the experience they're trying to deliver on. However this will still lead to frustrations when elements aren't explained properly, or are simply difficult for obscenely stupid reasons. This game tackles hard subjects, and does so well. Almost every encounter has one or two obvious choices, with maybe one or two other decisions to make that you may not be aware are things you can do, and I love that.The designers took a risky choice with some of the themes they tackled, and I believe how they handled it should be commended.

content:
Posted: May 10, 2013
												Под личиной типичного милитари шутера, а то и вовсе "каловдутия от 2К" на самом деле скрывается нечто совсем иное. Почему? Во-первых, явно вдохновленный "Апокалипсисом сегодня" сюжет в конце оставляет игрока в растерянности, чего я давно в играх не видел. Во-вторых, сеттинг не только подкупает своей определенной оригинальностью, но и дает возможность полюбоваться красивыми видами Дубая. В третьих, подход разработчиков к музыке нетипичен. То тут, то там нам дают послушать Хендрикса, Deep Purple, Mogwai, The Black Angels. Все остальное же время игрока сопровождает построковый саундтрек, который на удивление, как отлично вписывается в игру, так и интересно слушается отдельно от нее (и уже, само собой, отправился на ipod). Да, консольная механика с укрытиями, перекатами и "нажмите А, чтобы спрыгнуть" немного портят впечатление. Но в данном случае даже как-то не хочется ругаться. Очень приятный сюрприз, в общем.

content:

												Spec Ops: The Line. Praised for the wrong reasons, bashed for the wrong reasons. As someone who took the time to complete all achievements in this game, I think I can safely say it has a special place in my heart. So maybe I'm biased. Oh well. Look, there's more to this game than the infamous scenes you probably know about by now. The game's so much more interesting in its subtle elements and references to previous works of literature or film. Look, just play The Line. Or don't. Some people played it and thought it was a pretentius piece of crap. Well, they're kind of right. It tries too hard sometimes. But for some reason, I can't keep forgetting about this little game. Something about it just feels... right to me. Maybe it's the 33rd's interesting personalities. Maybe it's the great music. Maybe it's the feeling of "what just happened?" you'll often experience. Just remember one thing: you can leave Dubai, but Dubai can't leave you.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 22, 2016
Smart writing saves average shooterSpec Ops: The line is a bit of an odd beast. It starts as a very average 3rd person cover shooter. You get to hear the usual gung-ho callouts, and slaughter the usual terrorists. Then, somewhere an hour in or so, the story starts to pick up speed. And what a story it is. Unlike the vast majority of shooters this isn't a story about heros slaughtering evil goons to save the world. This is a story about actions and their consequences, about atrocities commited in the name of a greater good. This is not a game for 18 year old kids who still think war is a fun adventure. Or maybe it is. Maybe it will make them stop and think for a few moments. Maybe it will make them read heart of darkness.For the adults, if you can look past the average game mecanics, it's well worth playing.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 16, 2015
												Apocalypse Now:  DubaiThe combat is solid enough, controls are slightly strange but entirely passable.   I'm not personally a fan of games on rails but this one is a decent roller coaster ride that makes the rails a bit more acceptable for me.Enemies react to being shot in limbs appropriately and shotguns feel great, which is honestly a rarity in games.  The game gives a lot of forced prompts for commands and actions you have to or are only capable of doing at those moments which is strange and irritating.  The giant flashing prompts on the screen forcing your hand really take you out of the immersion of the story, which could be pretty good if the prompts didn't reinforce an arcade shooter feel.  The cover system is done fairly well, although i found myself fighting with the controls in many instances because it's just a few slight changes from what standard shooters bring you to expect.I have run into some instances where invisible barriers would block my shots and they threw in the generic heavily armored (Commonly known as bulldozer) type unit who can be frustrating to an extreme when most enemies react appropriately, a sticky grenade or an RPG on his facemask will do little more than break the mask off and stun him.  The bare face of his still requires significant amounts of shots to kill him with any weapon despite being unarmored which means damage is based on body parts and not types of armored cover.  In a shooter, this can be pretty irritating but expected from the lazier ones, so it might not bother other people as much.Ammo can be quite scarce for you and you alone as your team mates have unlimited ammo, dreadful aim, and unlimited grenades but can only be used in designated situations or of their own personal choosing.  They also pick their own cover in your general area which can occasionally put them on the wrong side of it, forcing your hand to go save them in the open during a bad enough situation to get them downed.  I haven't tried the Multiplayer or Co-Op yet so I can't comment on those.Combat  7/10Story      7/10Controls 6/10Visuals   7/10Docking score for the excessive HUD prompts and the heavily armored Bulldozer unit because those are just lazy, especially considering the environment.I'd have to give the game a 6/10 overallThe game is good for a few bucks, I would recommend it if you can catch it on a decent sale.

												Dark, gritty and very accurate about it's portrayal of war, If you want to get away from the glorified war game that is CoD this is worth it. 												Это шутер от третьего лица. В центре сюжета игры история капитана Американской армии Мартина Уолкера, которого отправляют в некогда роскошный город Дубаи.
