number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 7, 2015
												Unique TPS with good gameplay mechanics, an apocalypse-now type story and an excellent setting.Good♥♥♥♥♥♥+The setting is one of my favourites so far in gaming. Think a creative, beautiful and post apocalyptic Dubai.+Story is interesting and different than the norm with subtle clues and interesting decisions.+Gameplay mechanics worked well for me, but not for some. It's mainly a cover based shooter.+Style, sounds, weapons and music. The main title has (I think) Star Spangled Banner by Jimi Hendrix playing.+Melee finishers on downed enemies work nicely. No instant takedowns.+Multiplayer is actually pretty good. There's free co-op to but I havn't tried it yet.+(MINOR SPOILER) As the story progresses your character's finishing moves and "taunts" get more brutal. Nice touch.Don't feel right: -The shooting can get somewhat repetetive as there is not a lot of variation in what you can do.-Little replay value unless you want the story again from a more understanding perspective.Conclusion:The game is solid and of appropriate length for a shooter. I'm glad they didn't drag it out unecessarily and that the gameplay mechanics are of good quality. Nothing ruins immersion and good story like bad gameplay. Sadly the story didn't get a hold of me emotionally as it did for some, I really wish I could get into it but I just couldn't get real emotion from it as a whole. Certain parts got to me a little but not overwhelmingly. Still, it was a very satisfying take on one of my favourite tales: man goes into darkness and creates his own vision of society. Certain parts of the story/ending confused me a little but the whole thing is up to interpretation and certainly worth venturing into. Games like Far Cry 3, The Last of Us (especially), Mass Effect series and MGS series are examples of what engaged me emotionally. It's unfortunate that this did not but I still loved the experience and was always eager to play on and uncover the story unfolding. Maybe I've played too many shooters and become a little detached, who knows? Throughout the story you will get to make a few moral decisions but I won't say any more on that.Anyway, I'd give it a 9/10 easily, a full 10 if it had increased combat options/variation. I'm not gonna mark it down for failing to grab me as it did for others, however, as it deserves praise nonetheless.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 1, 2015
												Spec Ops is a strange, yet very interesting beast.It starts off like one of theses bombastic console shooters (Call of Duty, Gears of Wars 2, ...) both in terms of gameplay (lots of cutscenes and action set pieces), and story (Americans going at the opposite side of the world to kill baddies). But after the first mission, which is also the tutorial, it suddenly takes a more interesting turn.On the gameplay side, the game is a third person, cover-based, shooter but is more interesting than others cover based titles. A rudimentary command system allows you to give some orders to your AI teammates. The level design is also well done, with more verticality than most shooters. Combining the command system with a clever use of the map allow for nice flanking positions. That feels very satisfying when you can dispatch a wave of ennemies by being actually clever rather than just rushing in. It's also a lot more dynamic and interesting than the extremely static "first guy to raise his head above his barricade is dead" gameplay of Gears of War 2.On the story side, well...it's hard to talk about it without spoiling, but i will just say that it will soon take an unexpected turn. That story is interesting enough that i enjoyed playing the game twice (something i usually never do, even when i like a game). It allowed me to find some details that i didn't notice on my first playthrough (such as paintings on the walls, or references in the NPC dialogs) as well as better understand the story and its characters.The game however is not perfect. On the story side, it's not conveyed perfectly. It tries to be interesting with many stuff happening (again, i'm trying to not spoil), but it's sometimes more confusing than it should be due to some slightly wonky dialogs from time to tim (either too heavy-handed, or on the contrary not explaining enough). The second playthrough will of course help clear out any remaining doubt you may have on the storyOn the gameplay side, the controls are clearly made for console, and are therefore annoying to use on PC (many buttons have 2 or 3 roles, which lead to confusion and stupid deaths while in battle). I would have wished to be able to rebind all actions separately. Another annoyance is that there are still some of theses set action pieces (such as defending with an infinite ammo turret) that you get in the bombastic shooters. The kind of stuff that are exhilarating the first time you encounter them in a game, but get annoying when all games have them. Finally, and probably the biggest issue, is that it shares some of the usual problems of cover-based shooters. If you're next to a ledge/barricade, but not actually in cover, you magically can't fire down the ledge and you take more damage even though the barricade should protect you. That's annoying, but well, it's part of the genre that you have to stay in cover every single time.On the whole, Spec Ops feels like a game that has some slight issues, but is original and interesting enough to have its own charm, and i find it quite endearing. It will remain as an interesting experimentation, and i'm sad it didn't have more commercial success, as I'm sure a spiritual sequel would have fixed the small issues while keeping what makes it good. I recommend it if you like solo shooters, but want a deeper story experience than what Call of Duty-style game offer.

content:
Posted: October 12, 2014
												If you looked at this game and thought "oh great, another ♥♥♥♥♥♥ CoD clone", you're right; it would be a pretty ♥♥♥♥♥♥ clone - if that's what it was actually aiming for. No, ladies and gentlemen, this game's developers knew full well what you were expecting, so they use it to punch you in the gut. Even if you have a knowledge of this before hand, the punches just don't stop coming.I wouldn't exactly call this game fun, it didn't leave me feeling empowered and heroic. It ripped my heart out, made me feel guilty and disempowered, smacked me in the face with hard choices and left me feeling very discontent with the choices I had to make. So no, it's not fun in any real meaning of the word, but it's the most engaging game I've played recently. I couldn't close the game or quit because this darn thing had such an iron grip on me. This game actually tackles some pretty deep issues - PTSD, use of white phosphorus - actually I should let you see these for yourself. I don't want to spoil anything accidentally while trying to encourage you to play this game.While you're playing it (which you should), I do have some suggestions: listen to/read what's being said - they're not just talking to Walker; they're talking to you - even in the loading screen text; particularly as you get closer to the end. I should also mention that, if the controls and combat sequences feel a little dissonant, they're supposed to. I'd elaborate, but spoilers.I love this game, but I wouldn't play through it again unless I wanted to feel horrible about myself! :pIf that didn't convince you, perhaps the guys at Extra Credits will: 


YouTube™ Video: Spec Ops: The Line - I: How to Restart a Franchise - Extra Credits 

			Views: 346,723		

			Spec Ops: The Line questions the very nature of modern military shooters. It completely exceeded our expectations, so let's take a spoiler free look at how - and why.		

 Just don't watch part two until after you've played; it's spoilerific.

content:
Posted: May 12, 2013
SPEC OPS: THE LINEAn updated retelling of Joseph Conrad's Heart of Darkness shackled to an average cover based shooter.Rating 6/10If it wasn't for the story propelling the action I doubt the game would have been noticed amongst numerous other 3rd person cover based shooters. It doesn't do anything particularly well, enemies attack in waves whilst you hide behind waist high cover. This format doesn't change through the game but the enemies get smarter using grenades to try and flush you out and at times they destroy your cover. You have two other members in your squad, a sniper and heavy MG and they should be a help but the AI lets them down and they often become a hindrance especially on tougher difficult levels. There is a lot of good to be found in the game and it's not all bad, firstly the ruined setting of Dubai is well realised in places, the sand taking over many of the buildings and it's a beautifully eerie place as you make your way through the ruins of what was once a populated city.As the game progresses it also offers up a few moral choices, tough choices in a tough environment. Sadly though these choices have no effect on the ending, so no matter which path you choose you'll end up in the same place. It continues to ask moral questions throughout about the justification of your actions. If you've read Heart of Darkness or seen Apocalypse Now you'll know what to expect, I won't ruin the story but it has a few nice twists and turns as you discover what's really been happening in Dubai.So I recommend you buy the game for the story but don't expect much from the actual gameplay.

content:
Posted: September 30, 2013
												This is a third person shooter that stands out for its highly unconventional storyline. The plot is that the worst sandstorm in history has engulfed the glitzy city of Dubai. After six months of no contact from the city it is presumed that everyone has died, including a US infantry battalion that was there on a humanitarian relief mission. You're a special forces commando sent to investigate a garbled radio transmission that has started broadcasting from the supposedly dead city.Right from the beginning the plot grabs you by the throat and doesn't let go. I don't want to be too spoilerish, but I'll just say that moral ambiguity plays a big role in this game, and it is one of the few video games that has been able to evoke a strong emotional response from me. Like with Bioshock, expect to be wowed both by the unique setting and a complex storyline that can be interpreted on multiple levels.Graphically this game is on par with other AAA titles. You'll fight across a ruined cityscape of fallen skyscrapers, luxury hotels buried under sand dunes, squalid refugee camps, and impressive sandstorms. They really did a great job here, even little things like the graffiti on the walls is worth looking at.This is a cover-based third person shooter. I hated the cover-based combat in Mass Effect and Splinter Cell because I felt the controls were clunky and unintuitive. Fortunately Spec Ops The Line does the best implementation of cover-based combat I've seen yet, with controls that are both easy and allow for seamless movement. The battles used some interesting gameplay mechanics. Sometimes sandstorms will sweep across the battlefield, which severely affects your accuracy and visibility -- but this is a doubled-edged sword, because the enemies are likewise hindered. Many times you'll be fighting in skyscrapers submerged under the sand, and you can shoot out the windows to bury nearby enemies under an ocean of sand.Ammo is scarce in this game, so ammo management is important. This makes sense from a storyline perspective but also means that you're going to be switching weapons a lot. This forces the player to learn how to use all the different kinds of weapons, rather than just relying on a few favored guns.You'll have two AI-controlled teammates with you for much of the game, and you can issue orders to them. There are also a few mini-games, for example there's one scene where you're on a moving truck convoy and you've got to protect it. In another scene you've got to aim an artillery strike on an enemy encampment.The plot is mostly linear, but this is OK because the quality is high throughout.The music is a mix of an unobtrusive orchestral score and a few popular songs from the 60s and 70s. I never cared too much for those songs before, but they really fit the setting here.There is a multiplayer mode, if you're a fan of deathmatch-type games. There are also 4 maps designed specifically for co-op! If you like shooters or games with a strong story you'll like Spec Ops: The Line. You should be able to get it relatively cheap, I think I got mine for only $5, and that's a steal for 8+ hours of high quality entertainment.

												It's difficult to say anything about Spec Ops: The Line without ruining what makes it what it is. Suffice to say, its strength lies completely in its story, its message, and the fascinating and morbid deconstruction of the modern action game it provides.Its not a 'good' game in the traditional sense; but then again, what it provides is hard to value. And many people will have to judge it for themselves. But I reccomend it, if only because its the only game of its kind to truly make an impact.After all these years, its (in)famous reputation has spread across the 'net, so spoilers are abound. Which is sad, because it's an experience people need to play through first to truly appreciate. But that experince has stood the test of time, and to this day is still just as brilliant and terrible as ever.So, if you've never/barely have heard of Spec Ops up to this point, and have a strong stomach, pick it up and play it. Because I can garuntee there's nothing that comes close to it. No matter what other people may say or think of it, Spec Ops is the only game that has ever changed the way I look at games, forever.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 13, 2014
												Sometimes is sad for me to say that there are games who we judge of how they look at first instance, or how they sound by the tittle. Or hell even of just what they show on the trailer (which will make the most sense). Sometimes if you don’t do a lot of research you may come across one of those cases on which you expect sometime in a game and turns out to be sometime completely different. In most cases is a game that looked good but it turn out to be bad, but in the case of Spec Ops the Line is just some 3rd person shooter type of call of duty that in reality turns out to be a very much enhancing and twisted adventure that “plays with the player”, speaking of the traumas of war in a gory and dark way. It all comes down with the story and the pace that this brings to the game, the type of emotions that you may feel as you lead your squad who is looking for survivors in a post-apocalyptic Dubai after a massive sandstorm (in resume). That’s how you started the game, in an instance you may think that it is not too much in depth as I point out before, same may be said for the characters, there just your standard soldiers following orders (there is even a funny one). But it is as soon as all plans start to hit south when the game gets to shine, and it shines in a really messy pattern.Without getting to many spoilers, in the middle of your researching you encounter dead soldiers from the previous team that were trying to rescue the survivors of the recent apocalypse, followed by angry locals that you sadly will have to gun down. You quickly start to think that the rebels had gone crazy and are confronting the USA soldiers that came to help and that the story will move on a monotonous military style way, well not on this case since later on those same comrade soldiers will be trying to wipe you down for “invading and threating their mission” (wait what?) so you are forced to defend yourself and nail down basically everybody, looking who brainwashed this soldiers, but are they really? Here is when you begin to question the game itself of whether or not you’re making the right decisions, asking if you are the bad guy or the good guy, who is the hero? Because the enemy may have a point of their actions that could only be or may not be known until the end of the game, your squad is also asking themselves the same thing, Is this the reality of the situation or is it just an illusion caused by war traumas?I wanted to make a lot of emphasis to that because you as the player may also be in doubt every time you take a headshot, don’t get me wrong the game is scripted for the most part with merely some decision that really doesn’t affect the game’s outcome. These heavy story points and the fact that you are unsure of the protagonist’s actions is what really will make you feel the pain that the soldiers are having, as if you were there as well. That is a unique interactivity that is hard to get in other games of the same genre, especially military base shooter, it also helps that there is not a lot of cut scenes more than the necessary to tell the story, is a game that lets you play without killing the pace, maybe it was intentional or not, either way it works. As for the rest of the aspects, it plays as you may think a third person shooter is. You carry up to 2 weapons, each with different characteristics, you can crouch, take cover, give minimal orders to your teammates and even sneak on approach if you desire. It’s all very simple and solid, but sometimes the cover and sprinting system can be frustrating, doing things that you may not wanted that leads to a painful dead and then to repeat several minutes due to not so great checkpoints. There is of course the obvious turret and “scripted you have got to be kidding” parts of the game that you could expect by this style of shooter, which can actually be delightful (maybe because of the fact that are not a lot and very far between), but other than that there is not a lot of anything else than shooting until you go through the 6 to 7 hours of the campaign. So gameplay wise it’s not revolutionary and it doesn’t merge much with the storytelling, just kind of there in another room, working for the most part. There is also multiplayer, which is probably death by now so why bother, that can also be consider as an extra. Basically is the single player  gameplay in objectives of team death matches and so on, with unbalanced progression system and coop options, not really a lot to look at there and I really didn’t play it too much to know about it.Other things that have to be say here are the graphic and sound option, and the PC port itself. Game use unreal 3 engine with several light adjustments that make it look just beautiful, followed by nice post-apocalyptic worlds and the amazing sand storms that happen time to time, affecting even gameplay. Merge that with compelling and fairly accurate tracks on the background, as well as ambience sounds and themes) you will have a good taste of a Dubai filled with sand (interesting setting may have to tell). The port is also great, taking advantage of my pc as much as it could without lagging, even if I max it out, and you may argue that there is not a lot of graphic option or pc features, but in the end is still a console focused game, at least it doesn’t run poorly. Spec Ops the Line is like a kid in high cool trying to be one of the cool mainstream guys, hiding his characteristic that makes him great and innovative with layers of monotony and explosions. There is more than that on this game, like I explained extendedly, there is that emotional aspect that makes you feel a doubt of who is really the bad guy here or what is really happening, the plot or even the game is playing with you and that’s something not a lot of military shooters really have. Solid gameplay for the most part and good visual made this grim tale something to remember and also something that really deserved more attention back in 2012.

												8/10Brilliant storyline. 10/10 for that. Immersive, shocking. Several moments that really highlighted the horrors of war, especially knowing that it ws you that pulled the trigger. This game will make you hate yourself.Gameplay, however, holds back this otherwise amazing experience.1. As a tactical shooter, cover plays a very important role. The cover mechanics in this game, however, are laughable. Often, the only way to get from cover to cover is to stand up and fully revealing yourself to the enemy. The game enters and exits cover in very counterintuitive ways, which, again, often means you will be stainging up in full view of the enemy.This shouldn't be a problem. Cover mechanics are nothing new. Mass Effect, Deus EX: HR, etc all have done infinitely better.2. The squad commands are limited to "kill this guy". Not even "hold back", which means your two vulnerable squadmates will sometimes rush, then require medical attention deep into enemy lines. Other than that, the game is amazing.

												Wow, now here's a suprise.  What starts off as a bland Gears of War style third person shooter, turns into a gripping war drama that looks at the horrors of war and what is right and wrong. Throughout most the game the shooting is functional albiet not that special but it's the story that really carries the experience and makes you want to keep playing. Spec Ops does what other modern shooters wish they could do, it makes you care, care about the choices you have to make along the way and about the characters that are involved. Spec Ops: The Line is a dark and gloomy ride that provides a refreshing experience from modern military shooters and whilst at first it seems just a shallow, this is done intentionally to lull you into a false frame of mind to make the experience all that more suprising. So if you see it on sale and you're up for a different kind of shooter that emphasis atmosphere and story then give it a try!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 27, 2014
												It's a shame that Yager have publicly stated that there won't be a Spec Ops sequel as there is enough evidence in this game to hint at rich promises.In Spec Ops: The Line you are Captain Walker in charge of an elite Delta squad consisting of Staff Sergeant Lugo, the sniper, and Liutenant Adams, the heavy gunner. The premise is simple, your mission is to enter Dubai, confirm the statuses of Colonel John Konrad; who with his squad, the Damned 33rd, attempted to lead a rescue effort for the storm ravaged city of Dubai, and any remaining survivors of the storm, then radio for extraction. What follows however is anything but simple as you find yourself led deeper into the heart of the city, coming directly into contact with the conflict between the 33rd, the civilians and the CIA.In an ever shifting narrative where the lines between good and evil are constantly evolving yet becoming increasingly blurred , it is without a doubt that the story is the work of breathtaking brilliance. The game does not shy away from showing the ravages of war and how it can take its toll on individuals. Playing through the game, there are evocative and poignant moments which causes one to pause, think and consider. Even the collectibles in the game demand to be sought after as they genuinely add further to the story, providing additional layers to the narrative and helping to provide some enlightening backstories to some of the characters in the game.Unsurprisingly there are certain parts in the game where you are given a decision to make, whether it be to save a few civilians here or rescue a potentially valuable informat there. Whilst this adds a bit of variety proceedings, it is disappointing to see that the consequences of these decisions have little bearing in the grander scheme of the story so there is little in the way of replayability. Furthermore the gamplay itself is rather subpar. There is little to excite the player with the now standard 'on-the-rails' vehicle section making its way into the game to inspire a change of pace. The shooting itself can prove clunky at times and your team are largely annonymous in a gunfight. However the subpar gameplay is never too intrusive as to ruin the experience. Indeed it may be appropriate for it complements the story. It feels restrained, modest and bare. This way, the gameplay perfectly chimes with the wider subdued tone of the game where the horrors of war unfold. As such your focus remains firmly on the narrative.Visually speaking, Yager have achieved that sun-kissed perished paradise look that suggests a ruined landscape shorn of its riches. A neat metaphor for Captain Walker's mission. There are memorably evocative passages in the game which arouse a number of emotions in the player. The behaviour of the waves of sand as they bury enemies underneath is also believable. Yet the sand really comes into its own element in online multiplayer where the shifting terrain can alter and shift the balance of matches, offering greater tactical depth and encouraging careful planning.Overall Spec Ops: The Line is a welcome addition to the bloated shooting genre. It stands out on its own with its daring original story, distinctive setting and complex characters. Whilst it does not offer the brash, over-the-top, adrenaline filled fun of other shooters, enjoyment can still be had from this slow-burning, emotionally affecting, multi-faceted adventure.

content:
Posted: June 17, 2014
												8/10.As a shooter, Spec Ops is solid but shallow. There is a glaring lack of stealth gameplay; weapons loadout is forced on the player, with sniper rifles conveniently leaning against the wall 10 meters before each sniping opportunity; and the combat system itself misses the opportunity to capitalise on the three-man squad setup.This game leads you by the nose - little effort is made create the illusion of free roaming. This is forgivable, as the narrative by and large manages to stride between two cliches - the patriotic shoot 'em up, and the war is hell morality play - avoiding both (for the most part). Spec Ops does a good job of engaging the player by presenting meaty moral decisions with real impact. Given this, the times (one in particular) when choice is removed from the player, when you are forced to make one egregious choice when others are so obviously available, are both glaring and unforgivable.Despite all this, the game has a consistent, unique style. If played in one or two sittings, you may find yourself swept along by the narrative, and at times genuinely moved, like I did.

content:
Posted: July 6, 2012
												As PC Gamer states "Set my Brain on FIRE!" I have to agree; the most unique Single-Player game in ages; especially as a military shooter - I am surprised a company had the balls to pull off a story as dark and ♥♥♥♥ED UP as this games story; with moral choices you are forced to make that change the reactions and outcome; and three differing final endings (with an optional ending prior to those as well) - it's the only military shooter that focuses on being a dark amazing SP work of art rather than a cash cow yearly franchise of patrotism and heroism about saving the world from terrorists.Perhaps in Spec Ops: The Line no choice is good or bad at the moment. It's all just horrifying; overly disturbingly realistic in the best way possible and leaves you thinking for days after - a contender for best story in a game at the end of the year for SURE.

content:
Posted: May 15, 2014
												Apart from the somewhat clunky control mechanics, I really liked the story to this game. I wont give any spoilers, but if you want to do horri-bad things that seem good at the moment, buy this game as soon as possible. It's a very tough feat for a gaming company to really make their players attached to the characters of the game, and 2K Games really hit the nail on the head in that field. The Inception-like storyline really starts to stray from the road-most-travelled like COD usually does (no offense to COD fanboys), which is a great breath of fresh air for people like me, who like a good shoot-em-up, but get tired of the average FPS.

												This cover to cover first-person-shooter seems a run of the mill at first, but hits a spot alot of other first-person-shooters missed for me. The well written, adult plot starts basic, but the development the charakters make true visual and physiological makes this game!  Spec ops: The Line is dirty and shoves it in you'r face; gore, torture, posttraumatic stress disorder, all kinds of craziness. It all comes together graphics, sound, gameplay. Downside thats its short, 8 to 10 hours.I will come back for another playtrought in the future. Very well done Shooter, i recommend it!
